Curious Kids and Prime Time Childcare will also be closed, officials added.\n\nThe closure is to \"allow families and our community (to) begin to recover\" from the storms that tore through Southwest Michigan on Tuesday, May 7, officials said.\n\nA possible tornado was seen by radar around 6:05 p.m. northwest of Portage in Kalamazoo County, weather officials said. Portage experienced a tornado touching ground at 7:20 p.m., officials said.\n\nThere were large trees and power lines both downed with roof shingles scattered around Portage due to a possible tornado, weather officials said. The FedEx building on Portage Road and Stryker Way also partially collapsed, officials said.\n\nRead more: Major damage reported at FedEx facility in Portage from possible tornado\n\nAn MLive reporter at the scene said the storm appeared to have ripped a big section out of the building, with the middle part collapsed and the roof missing.\n\nThere was debris on top of FedEx vehicles. {"uri": "8119458460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:14:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:14:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:14:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/2024/0509/tornado-hail-storm-midwest-southeast-michigan", "title": "Michigan gets its first-ever tornado emergency as massive hail batters Southeast", "body": "Severe storms tore through parts of the United States again May 8, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nOn May 8, a tornado emergency - the weather service's highest alert level - was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill, and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Mr. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, marketing and communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition, and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Nashville on the evening of May 8 issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri, and Tennessee until 3 a.m. CDT. The weather service continued issuing tornado warnings into the night, mostly in Tennessee, but also in Missouri, Alabama, Georgia, and Texas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County the evening of May 8 following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of May 8 evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down May 7 in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer, and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there as well. The strong storms also brought hail and heavy rains to the state and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, the first-ever tornado emergency in Michigan was issued Tuesday. Weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass, and, Branch counties - all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties. Kalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nOn May 8, Samantha Smith she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles west of Detroit. Being able to recover some cherished items offered Ms. Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out May 7 at night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Mr. Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early May 8. The Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures, including homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband, and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Ms. Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas, and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported on May 8 in areas just southwest of St. Louis. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nOn May 6, parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail, and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Nashville, and Memphis, Tennessee - cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.", "source": {"uri": "csmonitor.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Christian Science Monitor"}, "authors": [{"uri": "christian_science_monitor@csmonitor.com", Elsewhere in the state, thousands of residents are without power and face a deluge of hail and tornado warnings amid severe thunderstorms.\n\n\"TAKE COVER NOW,\" the National Weather Service in Grand Rapids warned in a post directed at Portage residents on their Facebook page.\n\nFirst responders are trying to get people out but are impeded by downed power lines, said Kalamazoo emergency management.\n\nFedEx said the company is monitoring the situation and issued a statement expressing concern. \"Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road. We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service. Customers with questions about their shipments can check fedex.com for updates,\" Shannon Davis with FedEx media relations said.\n\nThe tornado targeting Portage, about 80 miles south-west of Lansing, Michigan's capital, has been reported on the ground damaging buildings and knocking down multiple trees and power lines throughout the area, according to Facebook posts from the Kalamazoo county sheriff's office. The NWS also declared a tornado emergency in Union City, more than 120 miles east of Portage.\n\nMichiganders join more than 10 million people in parts of Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky who also face storms and tornadoes on Tuesday.\n\nThe severe weather in Michigan follows a deadly tornado and storm in Barnsdall, a small town in Oklahoma that is home to around 1,000 residents, that left one person dead, five injured and dozens of homes damaged on Monday night and early Tuesday morning, according to the local television news station KOCO. This was just one of more than a dozen tornadoes that tore through central US states including Kansas, South Dakota, and Missouri on Monday and Tuesday.\n\nLess than two weeks before this, another tornado ripped through Nebraska and Iowa, with the most damage happening in Omaha, where hundreds of homes and structures and several miles of farmland were destroyed, the Associated Press reports. And in Lancaster county, home to Lincoln, the capital of Nebraska, 70 people were trapped inside an industrial building that had collapsed.\n\nThis most recent devastation in Michigan follows nearly two months of destruction across the midwest, including a cluster of more than 10 tornadoes in mid-March that swept through five states including Indiana and Ohio. {"uri": "2024-05-350506381", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:05:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:05:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.fox13memphis.com/news/powerful-storms-kill-3-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_5b61c812-0dec-11ef-947b-032c6011711e.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 3 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "WATCH: Tornadoes tear through southeastern US, killing two in Tennessee, one in North Carolina\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through parts of the U.S. again Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Nashville on Wednesday evening issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee until 3 a.m. CDT. The weather service continued issuing tornado warnings into the night, mostly in Tennessee, but also in Missouri, Alabama, Georgia and Texas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. The strong storms also brought hail and heavy rains to the state and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday. The Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures, including homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nOn Monday, parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Nashville and Memphis, Tennessee -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nDownload the FOX13 Memphis app to receive alerts from breaking news in your neighborhood.\n\nCLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD\n\nTrending stories:\n\nTornado Watch issued {"uri": "8116545670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "02:52:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T02:52:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T02:52:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/07/about-50-people-trapped-at-fedex-facility-after-tornadoes-hit-michigan-officials-say/", "title": "About 50 people trapped at FedEx facility after tornadoes hit Michigan, officials say", "body": "Debris is seen from a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Mich. on Tuesday. Brad Devereaux/Kalamazoo Gazette via AP\n\nAbout 50 people were trapped inside a FedEx distribution facility after a tornado hit Portage, Mich., on Tuesday evening, Kalamazoo County authorities said.\n\nFirst responders were trying to get the people out but were waiting for the power company to clear downed wires blocking the way, Taylor Koopman, Kalamazoo County spokeswoman, said Tuesday evening.\n\nFedEx said the company was monitoring the situation.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road,\" company spokeswoman Shannon Davis said. \"We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service.\"\n\nPart of the roof collapsed after the tornado struck, mlive.com reported. Photos showed walls caved in.\n\nNo deaths had been reported in the city as of about 8 p.m., Portage Mayor Patricia Randall said, though crews were still assessing the damage.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe storm caused \"extensive\" damage in several areas of the city and leaving more than 21,000 of roughly 49,000 residents without power, Randall said in an email. As of about 8 p.m., she had heard of no deaths.\n\nPolice were assessing the damage, \"but with so many trees and wires down, travel is slow,\" Randall said.\n\nA mobile home park in nearby Kalamazoo was also \"hit hard,\" Koopman said, with \"entire homes destroyed.\"\n\nOn X, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer urged people in southwestern Michigan to \"continue monitoring severe weather alerts and follow the advice of emergency officials.\"\n\nSeveral intense tornadoes plowed across parts of southern Michigan on Tuesday evening, causing damage and leaving injuries in their wake. Areas around Kalamazoo and Union City, about 30 miles to the southeast, appeared to be hard hit. More than 30,000 customers were without power across the region following the storms.\n\nTwisters were also confirmed in Indiana and Ohio as storms swarmed the Great Lakes, Midwest and Ohio Valley. Tornado watches stretched from southern Kentucky into southern Michigan on Tuesday evening, where severe storms capable of producing tornadoes, large hail and damaging wind were possible into the night.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn Michigan, one large tornado was seen crossing U.S. Route 131 near Kalamazoo just after 6 p.m. Significant damage was reported just to the south in Portage. A second tornado was also observed near Portage a little more than an hour after the first. The National Weather Service issued \"particularly dangerous situation\" warnings for both storms, which are reserved for confirmed large and extremely dangerous twisters.\n\nEarlier in the evening, a rare tornado emergency was hoisted by the Weather Service for another storm that tracked through Union City in south-central Michigan and probably produced either a long-track tornado or multiple tornadoes that touched down intermittently for more than an hour.\n\nThe tornado emergency in Union City - reserved for the most dire situations when a large tornado threatens a population center - was the first issued in Michigan by the Weather Service.\n\nThe tornadoes struck the Midwest, Great Lakes and Ohio Valley just one day after a violent EF4 tornado on the 0-to-5 Enhanced Fujita scale for intensity devastated parts of the city of Barnsdall in northeast Oklahoma, killing one person.\n\nThe severe storms that spawned tornadoes erupted as low pressure swept from the southern Plains on Monday into the Great Lakes on Tuesday. A warm front extending east from the low pressure zone served as the main conduit for the tornado-producing thunderstorms in southern Michigan.\n\nAt one point there were multiple concurrent \"particularly dangerous situation\" tornado warnings in addition to the tornado emergency for Union City. More than three dozen tornado warnings had been issued in the Midwest and Great Lakes through 8 p.m. Eastern time.\n\nLarge hail was also observed from the rotating thunderstorms that erupted throughout the Midwest. At least 100 reports of large hail were logged by the Weather Service, growing as large as four inches in diameter in Union City and three inches in diameter in Steuben, Ind.\n\nTuesday marked the 13th day in a row with tornadoes in the Lower 48. As the active storm pattern persists, additional twisters are possible in the Tennessee Valley and Mid-South on Wednesday. Scattered severe storms could hit the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast on Thursday, before a break in severe weather Friday through the weekend.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nComments are not available on this Customers with questions about their shipments can check fedex.com for updates.\"\n\nIt was unclear at the time of publication how many people were inside the facility when the tornado hit or how many suffered injuries.\n\nThe storms in Michigan followed a burst of severe weather on Monday when at least 15 tornadoes were reported to have struck parts of the central U.S.\n\nSeveral other states on Tuesday night were under tornado watches, including parts of Missouri, Illinois and Arkansas, according to the National Weather Service (NWS).\n\nIn Michigan, NWS forecasts warned of more dangerous weather through Tuesday night. About an hour after confirming one tornado made landfall around 6 p.m., the NWS office in Grand Rapids and the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office confirmed after 7 p.m. that another one was tearing through the area.\n\nNewsweek reached out via email on Tuesday night to the NWS and Michigan State Police for comment and updates on storm damage across the state.\n\nVideos shared on X, formerly Twitter, show a tornado on the ground near Kalamazoo and the destruction at the FedEx facility.\n\nIn one clip, X user Jim Morrison showed storm damage, writing: \"Lot of damage from the tornado in Kalamazoo and Portage. {"uri": "8118727940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:06:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:06:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:05:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2024/05/09/3082535/at-least-3-killed-as-storms-slam-se-us-after-tornadoes-bring-devastation-to-midwest", "title": "At Least 3 Killed As Storms Slam SE US After Tornadoes Bring Devastation to Midwest - Other Media news - Tasnim News Agency", "body": "TEHRAN (Tasnim) - Severe storms tore through the central and southeast US late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and another in North Carolina.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees. Claiborne County Mayor Joe Brooks also confirmed the death in a social media post, CBS News reported.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the National Weather Service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles south of Nashville.\n\nColumbia Mayor Chaz Molder confirmed in a statement at least one person died because of the storm, but no details on the cause of death were immediately provided.\n\nMolder said there was a \"number of sightings of confirmed tornado touch-downs\" in the area that resulted in \"bodily injuries and property damage.\"\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Maury County Office of Emergency Management in a statement urged \"everyone to stay out of the areas hit\" by the storm, adding that all schools in the county, which includes the city of Columbia, would be closed Thursday.\n\nNortheast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Nashville on Wednesday evening issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee until 3 a.m. CDT. The weather service continued issuing tornado warnings into the night, mostly in Tennessee, but also in Missouri, Alabama, Georgia and Texas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 152,000 customers were without power in North Carolina and Tennessee Wednesday night, according to utility tracker PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central US were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the US, the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.", "source": {"uri": "tasnimnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u062e\u0628\u0631\u06af\u0632\u0627\u0631\u06cc \u062a\u0633\u0646\u06cc\u0645"}, "authors": {"uri": "8116861789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "07:22:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T07:22:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:21:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://rsoe-edis.org/eventList/details/620137/0", "title": "Tornado - United States - About 50 people trapped at FedEx facility after tornadoes hit Michigan, officials say", "body": "About 50 people were trapped inside a FedEx distribution facility after a tornado hit Portage, Mich., on Tuesday evening, Kalamazoo County authorities said.\n\nFirst responders were trying to get the people out but were waiting for the power company to clear downed wires blocking the way, Taylor Koopman, Kalamazoo County spokeswoman, said Tuesday evening.\n\nFedEx said the company was monitoring the situation.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road,\" company spokeswoman Shannon Davis said. \"We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service.\"\n\nPart of the roof collapsed after the tornado struck, mlive.com reported. Photos showed walls caved in.\n\nNo deaths had been reported in the city as of about 8 p.m., Portage Mayor Patricia Randall said, though crews were still assessing the damage.\n\nThe storm caused \"extensive\" damage in several areas of the city and leaving more than 21,000 of roughly 49,000 residents without power, Randall said in an email. As of about 8 p.m., she had heard of no deaths.\n\nPolice were assessing the damage, \"but with so many trees and wires down, travel is slow,\" Randall said.\n\nA mobile home park in nearby Kalamazoo was also \"hit hard,\" Koopman said, with \"entire homes destroyed.\"\n\nOn X, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer urged people in southwestern Michigan to \"continue monitoring severe weather alerts and follow the advice of emergency officials.\"\n\nSeveral intense tornadoes plowed across parts of southern Michigan on Tuesday evening, causing damage and leaving injuries in their wake. Areas around Kalamazoo and Union City, about 30 miles to the southeast, appeared to be hard hit. More than 30,000 customers were without power across the region following the storms.\n\nTwisters were also confirmed in Indiana and Ohio as storms swarmed the Great Lakes, Midwest and Ohio Valley. Tornado watches stretched from southern Kentucky into southern Michigan on Tuesday evening, where severe storms capable of producing tornadoes, large hail and damaging wind were possible into the night.\n\nIn Michigan, one large tornado was seen crossing U.S. Route 131 near Kalamazoo just after 6 p.m. Significant damage was reported just to the south in Portage. A second tornado was also observed near Portage a little more than an hour after the first. The National Weather Service issued \"particularly dangerous situation\" warnings for both storms, which are reserved for confirmed large and extremely dangerous twisters.\n\nEarlier in the evening, a rare tornado emergency was hoisted by the Weather Service for another storm that tracked through Union City in south-central Michigan and probably produced either a long-track tornado or multiple tornadoes that touched down intermittently for more than an hour.\n\nThe tornado emergency in Union City - reserved for the most dire situations when a large tornado threatens a population center - was the first issued in Michigan by the Weather Service.\n\nThe tornadoes struck the Midwest, Great Lakes and Ohio Valley just one day after a violent EF4 tornado on the 0-to-5 Enhanced Fujita scale for intensity devastated parts of the city of Barnsdall in northeast Oklahoma, killing one person.\n\nThe severe storms that spawned tornadoes erupted as low pressure swept from the southern Plains on Monday into the Great Lakes on Tuesday. A warm front extending east from the low pressure zone served as the main conduit for the tornado-producing thunderstorms in southern Michigan.\n\nAt one point there were multiple concurrent \"particularly dangerous situation\" tornado warnings in addition to the tornado emergency for Union City. More than three dozen tornado warnings had been issued in the Midwest and Great Lakes through 8 p.m. Eastern time.\n\nLarge hail was also observed from the rotating thunderstorms that erupted throughout the Midwest. At least 100 reports of large hail were logged by the Weather Service, growing as large as four inches in diameter in Union City and three inches in diameter in Steuben, Ind.\n\nTuesday marked the 13th day in a row with tornadoes in the Lower 48. As the active storm pattern persists, additional twisters are possible in the Tennessee Valley and Mid-South on Wednesday. Scattered severe storms could hit the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast on Thursday, before a break in severe weather Friday through the weekend.", "source": {"uri": "rsoe-edis.org", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8116553889", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:02:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:02:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:01:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/news/kalamazoo/2024/05/reported-tornadoes-rock-southwest-michigan-leaving-people-trapped-and-homes-destroyed.html", "title": "Reported tornadoes rock Southwest Michigan, leaving people trapped and homes destroyed", "body": "A series of tornadoes reportedly tore through Southwest Michigan on Tuesday, causing a large section of a FedEx building to collapse and destroying some mobile homes.\n\nThe storm, which also included reports of hail, left dozens of people trapped inside the FedEx facility in Portage hours after it hit.\n\nNational Weather Service officials are investigating possible tornado touchdowns near Leonidas in St. Joseph County and three in Kalamazoo County, including two in Portage and one in Galesburg.\n\nA first tornado was reported traveling northeast at 5:54 p.m., May 7 south of Leonidas in St. Joseph County, weather officials said.\n\nMultiple areas sustained damage in St. Joseph County, confirmed county Undersheriff Jason Bingaman in a statement. Police are focused on life-saving efforts before beginning damage assessments, Bingaman added.\n\nThe first possible Portage tornado was seen by radar around 6:05 p.m. northwest of the city in Kalamazoo County, weather officials said. Portage experienced another possible tornado touching ground at 7:19 p.m., officials said.\n\nThe FedEx building, 6701 Portage Road in Portage, partially collapsed, officials said. An MLive reporter at the scene said the storm appeared to have ripped a big section out of the building, with the middle part collapsed and the roof missing.\n\nThere was debris on top of FedEx vehicles. The area near the FedEx building also had damage to trees and traffic signals.\n\nRead more: Major damage reported at FedEx facility in Portage from possible tornado\n\nThe FedEx building has about 50 people trapped inside as of 10 p.m., May 7, said Taylor Koopman, spokesperson for the Office of the Kalamazoo County Administrator.\n\nDowned wires in the building need to be removed before first responders can rescue the individuals, officials said. It is still an active scene, officials added.\n\nThe Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Park, 6830 E. N Ave. southeast of Kalamazoo, was also \"hit hard\" by the reported tornadoes, officials said. Entire homes at the park were destroyed, officials said.\n\nResident Tracy Schlotterback was moving his daughter into a mobile home when he felt the storm pass over it. He said he saw a lot of destruction after the storm passed and smelled nothing but gas.\n\n\"The trailer just shook,\" he told MLive.\n\nWestnedge Avenue, Centre Street and Oakland Drive also sustained heavy damage, officials said. There are multiple reported downed wires and piles of debris in roadways, officials said.\n\nLess than 20 minor injuries were reported at Bronson Hospital as of 10 p.m., hospital officials told MLive.\n\nThe possible Galesburg tornado was reported at 7:35 p.m. There were also multiple funnel clouds spotted in these storms that pushed across the state.\n\nAs of 10 p.m., there were about 26,000 customers without power in Kalamazoo, St. Joseph and Branch counties, according to the Consumers Energy outage map. About 500 customers were without power near Marshall in Calhoun County around 8 p.m., but those outages cleared, the map shows.\n\nRead more: Tornado Watch covering 4 states includes Southwest Michigan, Grand Rapids, Kalamazoo\n\nRelated: As reported tornadoes roll through Southwest Michigan, more than 25,000 without power\n\nThere were additional severe thunderstorm warnings across Southeast Michigan. The warnings included 60 mph winds and hail the size of golf balls, officials said.\n\nMore than 3,200 customers are without power in Washtenaw, Oakland, Wayne and Macomb counties, according to the DTE Energy outage map.\n\nThere were multiple tornado watches issued May 7 that included the Michigan counties of Allegan, Berrien, Cass, Kalamazoo, Kent, Ottawa, St. Joseph and Van Buren.\n\nGov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency late Tuesday night for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those affected by tonight's severe weather in {"uri": "8117701587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:02:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:02:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:02:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.clickondetroit.com/weather/2024/05/08/experts-assessing-tornado-damage-unsure-how-many-hit-michigan/", "title": "Experts assessing tornado damage, unsure how many hit Michigan", "body": "KALAMAZOO COUNTY, Mich. - Members of the National Weather Service were on the ground Wednesday morning in southwest Michigan to assess tornado damage following a night of severe weather.\n\nAt least one tornado touched down on Tuesday, May 7 in the western Michigan city of Portage, where significant damage was done to structures and homes. At least 20 people were injured amid the dangerous weather, though no injuries were serious, officials reported Wednesday morning.\n\nCity officials report that two tornadoes touched down in Portage, but the NWS -- which is responsible for officially confirming whether a tornado occurred -- has only confirmed one tornado, as of this writing.\n\nThe NWS told Local 4 on Wednesday that they received 11 reports of tornadoes in southern Michigan on Tuesday night. Those reports were preliminary, however, and the NWS said it could just be multiple reports of the same tornado.\n\nIt's possible that one tornado caused all of the damage, rather than several. But officials won't know for sure until they survey the area and assess the damage. That process began Wednesday, and could continue through Friday, officials said.\n\nThe NWS' Grand Rapids office, which oversees the area, was expected to release more information after they've finished assessing damage.\n\n---> Related: Update on major damage, outages, traffic issues in Michigan city hit by tornado\n\nMany people displaced\n\nThe most significant damage caused by the at least one tornado occurred in an area bound by Centre Avenue, Oakland Drive, Schuring Road, and Westnedge Avenue, officials said.\n\nOfficials with the city of Portage also said many people in the city have been displaced due to the damage. One of the areas hardest hit was a mobile home park. You can see that footage below.\n\nAt least one shelter was open for residents who were displaced. That shelter is at First Assembly of God on Oakland Drive.\n\n\u2b07\ufe0f Watch: Our damage report from the Kalamazoo County mobile home park\n\nFedEx facility destroyed\n\nResidential and commercial buildings were badly damaged during the storm, including a FedEx facility.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road,\" a FedEx spokesperson said in a statement. \"We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service. Customers with questions about their shipments can check fedex.com for updates.\"\n\nEmergency declaration in Portage\n\nPortage Mayor Patricia Randall issued an emergency declaration that will allow the city to receive resources from the state and federal governments.\n\nOfficials from Michigan State Police, the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office, Kalamazoo Public Safety, the West Michigan 5th District Technical Rescue Team, LifeEMS, and others were helping in the aftermath of the storms as of Wednesday.\n\nResidents were asked to check on their neighbors and stay off the roads to keep them clear for first responders.\n\n---> Video: Watch as tornado touches down in small Michigan town\n\nState of emergency also declared\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch, and Cass counties following the storms.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in {"uri": "8117085507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:41:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:41:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:41:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.highlandstoday.com/tornado-damages-fedex-facility-mobile-home-park-in-west-michigan/", "title": "Tornado damages FedEx facility, mobile home park in West Michigan", "body": "Severe thunderstorms barrel through southern Michigan producing multiple tornadoes that cause significant damage.\n\nIn western Michigan, several tornadoes touched down in Kalamazoo County near Portage and Calhoun County.\n\nIn southeast Michigan, a tornado watch is active for Lenawee, Monroe and Washtenaw counties, as well as severe thunderstorm warnings for southeast Livingston County and southern Oakland County, including hail and strong winds.\n\nAbout a dozen residents of the Pavilion Estates mobile home community in Pavilion Township outside Portage were injured in Tuesday's storms. At least one woman was trapped inside her home, which was destroyed, according to neighbors. Nick Ormold, director of public safety for the city of Portage, said emergency crews will have until Tuesday night to get a full account of residents and make sure no one is still trapped inside.\n\nA tornado moving out of St. Joseph County destroyed seven structures in Sherwood Township, mostly homes, Branch County Emergency Manager Tim Miner said, with no deaths or serious injuries.\n\nCity officials say there were no serious injuries after Tuesday night's tornado tore through several residential and commercial buildings in Portage, Mich.\n\nIn a 10 p.m. news release, Portage officials urged residents to continue sheltering in place and stay off roadways to allow access for first responders.\n\nMichigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for several counties in southwest Michigan following the storm. Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties are included, according to a release from the governor's office.\n\n\"My heart goes out to everyone in Southwest Michigan who was affected by the severe weather tonight,\" said Governor Whitmer. \"State and local emergency crews are on the ground and working together to help Michiganders. I have declared a state of emergency and activated our State Emergency Operations Center to ensure resources are expedited to the area. We will continue to monitor the situation and coordinate efforts overnight. Thank you to all first responders who are working hard to keep Michiganders safe. I want to say. We'll get through this together.\"\n\nAn hour after a major tornado destroyed Portage, the National Weather Service in Grand Rapids, south of Kalamazoo, reported a second tornado touched down near Portage at about 7:20 p.m.\n\nAt 7:43 p.m., a separate tornado was confirmed by the National Weather Service west of Battle Creek near Galesburg, moving northeast at 40 mph. A severe thunderstorm warning, including quarter-sized hail and 60 mph winds, is in effect for parts of Calhoun County until 9 p.m.\n\nAfter the first tornado in Portage, several buildings were significantly damaged, including the FedEx facility.\n\nJude's Barber Shop in Portage on Center Road also posted damage to its Plaza building: \"The tornado hit our barber shop in Portage on Center Road. Thankfully, everyone is safe.\"\n\nDrone footage taken in Portage shows the extent of the damage caused by the tornado.\n\nWBND-TV (South Bend, Indiana) Portage Mayor Particia Randall said, \"Two tornadoes hit Portage this evening causing extensive damage to residential and commercial property. ... No injuries or fatalities have been reported at this time.\"\n\nAs of 1:10 a.m. Wednesday, more than 25,000 Consumer Energy and 2,700 Midwest Energy & Communications customers were without power.\n\nSt. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman confirmed damage was reported at several locations in the southwestern Michigan county Tuesday evening.\n\n\"Right now, we are focusing on {"uri": "8119231048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:35:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:35:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:35:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/486511/Tornadoes-tear-through-southeastern-US-as-storms-leave-3-dead", "title": "Tornadoes tear through southeastern US as storms leave 3 dead - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Emergency crews are seen along Cranford Hollow Road after severe storms tore through the area Wednesday, May 8, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn. (AP Photo/George Walker IV)\n\nForecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could march through parts of the South early Thursday, after storms a day earlier spawned damaging tornadoes and massive hail, leaving two dead in Tennessee and one dead in North Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern U.S. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this {"uri": "8118265570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:02:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:02:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:58:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_580630d9-23af-5def-a26f-aae01c132c69.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "Storm damaged mobile homes are surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. A tornado ripped through the area the evening of May 7.\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-350118321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:58:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:58:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:53:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/tornadoes-southeastern-us-storms-9318023/", "title": "Tornadoes tear through southeastern US as storms leave 3 dead", "body": "The storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern US. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\" Rita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville. \"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. The National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\" Tornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia.\n\nThe West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9548085", "eventUri": "eng-9548085", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.388235294117647, "wgt": 202, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-349633604", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:07:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:07:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:41:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_42c5a277-8c92-5312-80cc-7b604a3275cd.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "By JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nMore from this section\n\nLong Time Ferret Activist Pat Wright Files Lawsuit Against California Fish and Game Commission President Eric Sklar Stack Sports launches Stack Rewards to Save Youth Sports Families $100M Monterra Credit Union elevates the member experience with the Empower Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees. Claiborne County Mayor Joe Brooks also confirmed the death in a social media post.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the National Weather Service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles south of Nashville.\n\nColumbia Mayor Chaz Molder confirmed in a statement at least one person died because of the storm, but no details on the cause of death were immediately provided.\n\nMolder said there was a \"number of sightings of confirmed tornado touch-downs\" in the area that resulted in \"bodily injuries and property damage.\"\n\nThe Maury County Office of Emergency Management in a statement urged \"everyone to stay out of the areas hit\" by the storm, adding that all schools in the county would be closed Thursday.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 152,000 customers were without power in North Carolina and Tennessee Wednesday night, according to utility tracker PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central U.S. were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live.
