"originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9548085", "eventUri": "eng-9548085", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3725490196078431, "wgt": 200, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118414980", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:00:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:00:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:51:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://wgxa.tv/news/nation-world/powerful-storms-kill-3-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-severe-southeastern-us-damage-tennessee-north-carolina-nashville-gaston-columbia-michigan-kalamazoo-power-electricity-customers-confirmed-national-weather-service-federal-aviation-administration", "title": "Powerful storms kill 3 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Severe storms were tearing through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Nashville on Wednesday evening issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee until 3 a.m. CDT. The weather service continued issuing tornado warnings into the night, mostly in Tennessee, but also in Missouri, Alabama, Georgia and Texas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. The strong storms also brought hail and heavy rains to the state and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday. The Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures, including homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nOn Monday, parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Nashville and Memphis, Tennessee -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "wgxa.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGXA"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wgxa.tv", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "8118270976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:05:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://journalnow.com/news/state/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_d3732db3-3c84-5128-b0b8-130bb1ec7942.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "Storm damaged mobile homes are surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. A tornado ripped through the area the evening of May 7.\n\nBy JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8118488127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:04:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:04:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:04:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/powerful-storms-kill-3-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/articleshow/109967474.cms", "title": "Powerful storms kill 3 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US - Times of India", "body": "COLUMBIA: Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina. A storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency - the weather service's highest alert level - was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties - all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... {"uri": "2024-05-349157453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:40:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:40:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:23:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.kadn.com/news/national/destructive-tornadoes-storms-pummel-michigan-millions-more-face-severe-weather-threat/article_a3231764-7aa5-5b12-b9f7-c615e5e32e12.html", "title": "Destructive tornadoes, storms pummel Michigan; millions more face severe weather threat", "body": "Homes damaged by a tornado at Pavilion Estate Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, Michigan, on Tuesday.\n\n(CNN) -- Powerful tornadoes and storms swept through southwestern Michigan Tuesday evening, destroying or damaging homes and businesses and injuring several residents - and millions more from northeast Texas to the Carolinas face at least a slight risk of severe weather Wednesday.\n\nAt least a dozen people were injured at a mobile home park in Pavilion Township following a tornado Tuesday, according to a county official. The township is located in Kalamazoo County, where 15 to 20 people had minor injuries and were transported to two area hospitals, according to the county's emergency management spokesperson Andrew Alspach.\n\nIn the neighboring city of Portage, about 7 miles south of Kalamazoo, pictures and videos showed a FedEx facility with significant roof and structural damage after a storm hit the area Tuesday evening. However, there were no serious injuries, a FedEx representative told CNN.\n\nAbout 50 people were trapped in the building due to downed wires, Taylor Koopman, a spokesperson for Kalamazoo County administrator's office, told MLive.com, adding work to clear the wires was ongoing as of 9:30 p.m. ET. However, city of Portage spokesperson Mary Beth Block told CNN in an email the building had been cleared by authorities.\n\nTwo tornadoes hit the Portage area Tuesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\n\"We have significant damage, including damage to residential and commercial buildings, trees down across many roads in the city, and several reports of gas leaks,\" Portage city officials said in a news release.\n\nThe city pleaded with its residents to \"stay home\" and \"please stay off the roads. First responders are stuck in gridlock.\"\n\nThe Village of Centreville was hit hard during a possible tornado on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County officials. Multiple buildings, residential and commercial, were destroyed after a possible tornado touched down in Centreville on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman. The storm damage ripped off roofs and flattened homes \"completely down,\" Bingaman told CNN.\n\nIn Branch County, about 60 miles south of Kalamazoo, at least seven homes were destroyed, according to Emergency Management Director Tim Miner, who added he was unable to get out and assess damage to other parts of the county.\n\nOne city in the county, Union City, was under a rare tornado emergency earlier that went into effect when \"a large and destructive tornado\" was over the area, about 10 miles northwest of Coldwater and moving northeast at 45 mph, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAccording to the Storm Prediction Center, at least nine tornado reports were made in Michigan on Tuesday. Hail the size of softballs was also reported in some parts of the state.\n\nMore than 34,000 homes and businesses in Michigan were left without power as of early Wednesday, according to poweroutage.us. Elsewhere in the Midwest, more than 16,000 residents were in the dark in Ohio.\n\nGov. Gretchen Whitmer said her heart was going out to those impacted by the severe weather in southwest Michigan. The governor declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties, she said Tuesday night.\n\n\"We will work with emergency teams overnight to monitor the situation and coordinate resources for those affected. Michigan is strong and together we will rebuild,\" the governor said.\n\nAfter Tuesday brought tornadoes, large hail, damaging wind gusts and heavy rainfall mainly across the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley, much of the Eastern US braces for another round of storms Wednesday. More than 145 million people could see some sort of storms Wednesday from Texas to Maine.\n\nTornado threat continues Wednesday\n\nA population of over 2 million people will be under the strongest severe storm threat Wednesday. The Storm Prediction Center has issued a level 4 of 5 moderate risk of severe thunderstorms across parts of southern Missouri, southern Illinois, southwestern Kentucky and northwestern and central Tennessee. Severe storms in the area are expected to ramp up Wednesday afternoon, producing some strong tornadoes greater than EF2 strength, large hail greater than 3 inches in diameter and damaging wind gusts greater than 74 mph.\n\nNortheastern Texas to western West Virginia is under a level 3 of 5 enhanced severe storm threat. That includes the cities of Memphis, St. Louis, Louisville and Little Rock. The area could see some tornadoes, hail greater than 2 inches and gusts greater than 74 mph.\n\nNumerous severe thunderstorms are likely Wednesday from parts of the mid Mississippi, Ohio and Tennessee Valleys into the southern Plains, according to the Storm Prediction Center. As severe storms hit, tornadoes, very large hail, and damaging winds are expected over the large area. Some of the tornadoes may be strong, according to the center.\n\n\"The greatest flash flooding threat also overlaps with the risk of severe thunderstorms, centered over Kentucky and Tennessee as well sections of neighboring states,\" the National Weather Service said. \"Residents and visitors are advised to have multiple ways of receiving warnings and never drive across flooded roadways.\"\n\nLower severe storm threats spread from central Texas to the southern tip of Maine and includes the cities of Dallas, Austin, Atlanta, Chicago, Washington D.C., Baltimore, New York City, Boston, Philadelphia, Indianapolis and Charlotte. There, the threats are more likely to be large hail and damaging wind gusts, but tornadoes cannot be ruled out.\n\nThere have been 13 consecutive days of tornado reports across US\n\nSpring is known for severe storms and tornadoes - and Spring 2024 is no exception. There has been at least one tornado report every day since April 25, a streak of 13 consecutive days, according to the Storm Prediction Center. A total of 287 tornadoes were reported in that time span.\n\nApril to June is peak tornado season across the US, with May traditionally seeing the most tornadoes. This month is coming off a particularly active April, where there were 300 tornadoes, the second most on record, according to the center. The all-time record occurred in April 2011, when there were 757 tornadoes.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. Downed powerlines in the area delayed first responders from beginning their rescue mission.\n\nThe roof partially collapsed as a result of the tornado, reported mlive.com. The number of casualties has not yet been confirmed.\n\nFedEx issued a statement regarding the current situation.\n\n'Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road,' company spokeswoman Shannon Davis said.\n\nPortage Mayor Patricia Randall said first responders are still assessing the widespread damage (Pictured: Tornado damage in Kalamazoo, MI)\n\nPictured: Footage of a large tornado crossing U.S. Route 31 near Kalamazoo, MI\n\n'We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service.'\n\nA mobile home park was also suffered mass destruction after a tornado tore through the park, leaving homes in ruins and multiple injured.\n\nThe destruction in Michigan comes just a day after at least 15 tornadoes moved through the southern Plains. Officials confirmed one dead after a tornado that was two miles wide came through Barnsdall, Oklahoma.\n\nIn the storm zone, which stretches from Chicago to Nashville, Tennessee, are over 35 million Americans.\n\nParts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, and Kentucky were under a tornado watch through Tuesday night.\n\nThere could be a few tornadoes, severe gusts of up to 70 mph, and hail the {"uri": "2024-05-348577414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:32:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:32:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:23:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/08/weather/tornadoes-michigan-tuesday-storms-wednesday/index.html", "title": "Destructive tornadoes and storms pummel Michigan Tuesday, and millions more face a severe weather threat Wednesday", "body": "CNN --\n\nPowerful tornadoes and storms swept through southwestern Michigan Tuesday evening, destroying or damaging homes and businesses and injuring several residents - and millions more from northeast Texas to the Carolinas face at least a slight risk of severe weather Wednesday.\n\nAt least a dozen people were injured at a mobile home park in Pavilion Township following a tornado Tuesday, according to a county official. The township is located in Kalamazoo County, where 15 to 20 people had minor injuries and were transported to two area hospitals, according to the county's emergency management spokesperson Andrew Alspach.\n\nIn the neighboring city of Portage, about 7 miles south of Kalamazoo, pictures and videos showed a FedEx facility with significant roof and structural damage after a storm hit the area Tuesday evening. However, there were no serious injuries, a FedEx representative told CNN.\n\nAbout 50 people were trapped in the building due to downed wires, Taylor Koopman, a spokesperson for Kalamazoo County administrator's office, told MLive.com, adding work to clear the wires was ongoing as of 9:30 p.m. ET. However, city of Portage spokesperson Mary Beth Block told CNN in an email the building had been cleared by authorities.\n\nTwo tornadoes hit the Portage area Tuesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\n\"We have significant damage, including damage to residential and commercial buildings, trees down across many roads in the city, and several reports of gas leaks,\" Portage city officials said in a news release.\n\nThe city pleaded with its residents to \"stay home\" and \"please stay off the roads. First responders are stuck in gridlock.\"\n\nThe Village of Centreville was hit hard during a possible tornado on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County officials. Multiple buildings, residential and commercial, were destroyed after a possible tornado touched down in Centreville on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman. The storm damage ripped off roofs and flattened homes \"completely down,\" Bingaman told CNN.\n\nIn Branch County, about 60 miles south of Kalamazoo, at least seven homes were destroyed, according to Emergency Management Director Tim Miner, who added he was unable to get out and assess damage to other parts of the county.\n\nIn a screengrab taken from a drone video, homes are left damaged after a tornado at Pavilion Estate Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, Michigan on Tuesday, May 7. Chicago & Midwest Storm Chasers\n\nOne city in the county, Union City, was under a rare tornado emergency earlier that went into effect when \"a large and destructive tornado\" was over the area, about 10 miles northwest of Coldwater and moving northeast at 45 mph, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAccording to the Storm Prediction Center, at least nine tornado reports were made in Michigan on Tuesday. Hail the size of softballs was also reported in some parts of the state.\n\nMore than 34,000 homes and businesses in Michigan were left without power as of early Wednesday, according to poweroutage.us. Elsewhere in the Midwest, more than 16,000 residents were in the dark in Ohio.\n\nGov. Gretchen Whitmer said her heart was going out to those impacted by the severe weather in southwest Michigan. The governor declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties, she said Tuesday night.\n\n\"We will work with emergency teams overnight to monitor the situation and coordinate resources for those affected. Michigan is strong and together we will rebuild,\" the governor said.\n\nAfter Tuesday brought tornadoes, large hail, damaging wind gusts and heavy rainfall mainly across the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley, much of the Eastern US braces for another round of storms Wednesday. Over 140 million people could see some sort of storms Wednesday from Texas to Maine.\n\nHomes damaged by a tornado at Pavilion Estate Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, Michigan, on Tuesday, May 7. @NISWweather/X\n\nTornado threat continues Wednesday\n\nSevere thunderstorms are likely Wednesday across parts of the southern Plains into the mid Mississippi, Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, according to the Storm Prediction Center. As severe storms hit, tornadoes, very large hail, and damaging winds are expected over the large area. Some of the tornadoes may be strong, according to the center.\n\nA population of nearly 20 million people will be under the strongest severe storm threat. The Storm Prediction Center has issued a level 3 of 5 enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms from northeast Texas to western Virginia, which includes much of the lower Ohio Valley, Tennessee Valley and middle to lower Mississippi Valley. Cities in the strongest threat for severe storms include Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Louisville.\n\n\"The greatest flash flooding threat also overlaps with the risk of severe thunderstorms, centered over Kentucky and Tennessee as well sections of neighboring states,\" the National Weather Service said. \"Residents and visitors are advised to have multiple ways of receiving warnings and never drive across flooded roadways.\"\n\nLower severe storm threats spread from central Texas to the southern tip of Maine and includes the cities of Dallas, Atlanta, Chicago, Washington D.C., Baltimore, New York City, Boston and Charlotte. There, the threats are more likely to be large hail and damaging wind gusts, but tornadoes cannot be ruled out.\n\nDebris is seen from a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Michigan, Tuesday, May 7. Brad Devereaux/Kalamazoo Gazette/AP\n\nThere have been 13 consecutive days of tornado reports across US\n\nSpring is known for severe storms and tornadoes - and Spring 2024 is no exception. There has been at least one tornado report every day since April 25, a streak of 13 consecutive days, according to the Storm Prediction Center. A total of 287 tornadoes were reported in that time span.\n\nApril to June is peak tornado season across the US, with May traditionally seeing the most tornadoes. This month is coming off a particularly active April, where there were 300 tornadoes, the second most on record, according to the center. The all-time record occurred in April 2011, when there were 757 tornadoes.\n\nCNN's Mary Gilbert, Steve Almasy, Joe Sutton, Amy Simonson, Lucy Kafanov and Andi Babineau contributed to this report.", {"uri": "2024-05-349930501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:08:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:08:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:32:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.gpb.org/news/2024/05/09/tornadoes-tear-through-the-southeastern-us-storms-leave-3-dead", "title": "Tornadoes tear through the southeastern U.S. as storms leave 3 dead", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could march through parts of the South early Thursday, after storms a day earlier spawned damaging tornadoes and massive hail, leaving two dead in Tennessee and one dead in North Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern U.S. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this {"uri": "2024-05-349570768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:55:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:55:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:30:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/8/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-/", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central U.S.", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties - all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nPHOTOS: 3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nJust outside of Pittsburgh, a weather service team confirmed that a brief tornado with maximum winds of 105 mph (169 kph) overturned a trailer and snapped more than a dozen trees early Wednesday in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier, destroying a bar and damaging the high school. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati - cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks - a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.", "source": {"uri": "8118336049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:24:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:24:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:23:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.wcpo.com/weather/8-tornadoes-confirmed-in-ohio-3-in-michigan-as-severe-storms-cross-us", "title": "Severe storms kill 2 people in Tennessee and 1 in North Carolina", "body": "Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nWeather\n\nTornadoes strike Central US; Oklahoma towns devastated by twister Scripps News Staff 7:21 AM, May 07, 2024\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Nashville and Memphis, Tennessee -- cities where more than 21 million people live. There were also reports of injuries and damage at residences in nearby Kalamazoo.\n\nCity officials in Portage took to social media to urge drivers off the roads so first responders could get through.\n\n\"Several supercells erupted late this afternoon and multiple churned down tornadoes in southern Michigan,\" said weather.com digital meteorologist Jonathan Belles. \"One of the tornadoes likely swept northeastward from Dowagiac toward Portage and the Kalamazoo airport, causing apparent wall collapses and roof damage at the FedEx facility, along with some local homes and businesses in Portage.\"\n\nIn an average month of May, Belles notes, the entire state of Michigan gets three tornadoes.\n\nTornado watches for parts of Indiana and Michigan extended until at least 11 p.m. local time, and tornado watches for southeastern Indiana, northern Kentucky and southwestern Ohio (including Cincinnati and Columbus) were up until at least 1 a.m. EDT. {"uri": "8118277176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:14:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:14:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:13:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-u-s-1.6879499", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern U.S.", "body": "Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometres) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the U.S. National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometres) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometres) north of Louisville, Ky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Mo. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118306669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:46:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:46:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:46:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/5/9/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Bulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118883820", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:49:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:49:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:48:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/tornadoes-tear-through-southeastern-us-as-storms-leave-3-dead/", "title": "Tornadoes tear through southeastern US as storms leave 3 dead - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could march through parts of the South early Thursday, after storms a day earlier spawned damaging tornadoes and massive hail, leaving two dead in Tennessee and one dead in North Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern U.S. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
