"eng-9548085", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.5686274509803921, "wgt": 183, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118056050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/05/08/8-tornadoes-confirmed-in-ohio-3-in-michigan-as-severe-storms-cross-central-us/", "title": "8 tornadoes confirmed in Ohio, 3 in Michigan as severe storms cross central US", "body": "By JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY (Associated Press)\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- At least eight tornadoes have touched down in Ohio and three have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. late Tuesday and early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nThe National Weather Service says confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in Ohio, including five in Warren County in the state's southwest region. The confirmations came Wednesday after crews were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nWeather service meteorologist in Michigan Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nIn addition to the five in Warren County, confirmed tornadoes in Ohio were in the western part of the state in Greenville in Darke County, west of Coldwater in Mercer County and west of New Knoxville in Auglaize County. The weather service says crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nJust outside of Pittsburgh, a weather service team confirmed that a brief tornado with maximum winds of 105 mph (169 kph) overturned a trailer and snapped more than a dozen trees early Wednesday in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier, destroying a bar and damaging the high school. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-349391105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:34:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:34:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:02:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-tennessee-as-severe-storms-cross-central/article_42c5a277-8c92-5312-80cc-7b604a3275cd.html", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US", "body": "By JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Randall said in a statement that her city was struck by two tornadoes on Tuesday, with no reports of injuries or death so far.\n\nOne of the vortexes ripped off the side of a massive FedEx facility there, leaving about 50 workers trapped as first responders hoped to clear live electrical wires blocking their safe exit, Kalamazoo County spokesperson Taylor Koopman said by email.\n\n\"The FedEx building in Portage sustained significant damage and is still an active scene,\" she said.\n\nAt Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, entire residences were destroyed by a tornado, Koopman said. Rescue crews were on-site searching for survivors and those in need of temporary shelter, which was set up at Portage Senior Center, she said.\n\nResidents were urged to stay put as first responders sort out the situation.\n\n\"We have multiple scenes across the County and heavy damage,\" Koopman said. \"There are several reports of power outages, wires down, and debris in the roadways. We ask that folks stay off the road if they're able.\"\n\nMore than 32,000 utility customers in Michigan were without power Tuesday night, according to utility tracker PowerOutage.us.\n\nImagery of a strip mall barber shop in Portage showed its front ripped away to reveal its interior.\n\n\"Due to downed power lines and trees and possible gas leaks we are urging residents to stay in their homes so first responders can reach those who need assistance,\" Randall said.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement Tuesday afternoon for an area, including Union City, southwest of Portage.\n\nA weather service meteorologist said that one tornado and likely one or two others were all but confirmed Tuesday night, even as the service customarily waits until the next day to send trained crews to the sites of possible tornadoes for confirmation.\n\nThe severe weather since mid-April is the result of waves of cool, low pressure storms moving east from the Pacific Northwest and clashing with the warmers climes of states near the Gulf Coast. The colliding air has produced unsettled weather ripe for tornadoes, flooding and hail.\n\nThere were 19 reported tornadoes in at least seven states on Monday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said heavy weather, including possible thunderstorms and flash floods, was in store for many of the same regions for the next couple of days.\n\nAn estimated 53 million people from northeast Texas to as locals are told to brace for MORE\n\nOther videos shows trees toppled by heavy winds, and cars wading through inches of water that had collected on roads.\n\nThe sheriff in Claiborne County, which lies about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, also in Tennessee, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: 'We're getting overloaded right now.'\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nStorm debris litters a portion of Cranford Hollow Road, Wednesday, May 8, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn. (AP Photo/George Walker IV)\n\nGreenville, Ohio, resident Brenda Pollitt wipes the tears from her eyes as she removes important papers from her bedroom\n\nStorm damaged mobile homes are surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. A tornado ripped through the area the evening of May 7. (Neil Blake/The Grand Rapids Press via AP)\n\nRead More Michigan declares first tornado emergency in state's history as twisters rip through Midwest, trapping 50 people in FedEx distribution facility\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency - its highest alert level - for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n'Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,' the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nFedEx trucks sit outside a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Michigan\n\nA mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo\n\nA home damaged by severe weather is pictured Wednesday, May 8, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn. (AP Photo/George Walker IV)\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nRead More Houses are destroyed as tornados rip through Oklahoma after storms cause 1,100 flight delays at Denver's airport and evacuations at military bases in latest wild weather to hit the Midwest\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nKalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were 'totally destroyed.' At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n'The clean-up efforts are tremendous. We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they\u00b4ve been demolished,' Fuller said.\n\nSeveral states are set to be battered by tornados and storms\n\nUtility workers survey storm damage along a severely damaged road in Columbia, Tennessee\n\nResidents work to remove downed trees at their home along Cothran Road after severe storms tore through Columbia, Tennessee\n\nHomes were completely flipped over and cars were smashed by debris and trees moved by the storm.\n\nA home where seven people were living 'is totally on its top,' he said. 'They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.'\n\n'We found homes in the roadway,' the sheriff said late Tuesday. 'We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.'\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n'There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,' Wycoff said. 'It was just a lot of chaos.'\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother\u00b4s partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother\u00b4s ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n'I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,' she said. 'My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.'\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this {"uri": "2024-05-349325196", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:21:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:21:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:32:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://news.wttw.com/2024/05/08/destructive-tornadoes-and-storms-pummeled-michigan-tuesday-and-millions-more-face-similar", "title": "Destructive Tornadoes and Storms Pummeled Michigan Tuesday, and", "body": "Wreckage from a tornado is seen at a FedEx building in Portage, Michigan, on May 7, 2024. (Credit: Chicago & Midwest Storm Chasers via CNN Newsource)\n\n(CNN) -- Powerful tornadoes and storms swept through southwestern Michigan Tuesday evening, destroying homes and businesses and injuring several residents, scenes that could play out once again in the central and eastern U.S. Wednesday.\n\nHere's the latest on the destruction in Michigan and ongoing storms:\n\n* Mobile home park struck by tornado: More than a dozen people were injured at a mobile home park in Pavilion Township in Kalamazoo County, Michigan, following a tornado Tuesday, according to a city official. Fifteen to 20 people had minor injuries and were transported to two area hospitals, according to the county's emergency management spokesperson Andrew Alspach.\n\n* One Michigan town may have been hit twice: At least one tornado, possibly two, hit Portage Tuesday evening, as the area faced two tornado warnings in just over an hour, the National Weather Service said. Homes and businesses in the city sustained significant damage, but there were no serious injuries, according to town officials. A tornado ripped a large hole into a FedEx facility. Downed wires nearby trapped about 50 people in the facility for a few hours, a spokesperson for the Kalamazoo County administrator's office, told MLive.com.\n\n* Damage reported in at least two other Michigan counties: Multiple homes and businesses were destroyed after a possible tornado touched down in Centreville on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman. The storm damage ripped off roofs and flattened homes \"completely down,\" Bingaman told CNN. At least seven homes were destroyed in nearby Branch County, according to Emergency Management Director Tim Miner.\n\nFirst-ever tornado emergency in Michigan: Parts of Branch County, including Union City, were placed under Michigan's first tornado emergency when \"a large and destructive tornado\" was over the area Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service. Tornado emergencies are the most extreme form of a tornado warning and are only issued when a tornado threatens catastrophic damage and loss of life, often in a populated area.\n\n* Chaotic severe weather stretch: April to June is the most active time for tornadoes in the US, and May is typically the busiest month. This year has been no exception. At least one tornado has been reported in the US every day since April 25 - a streak of 13 days and counting. Nearly 300 tornado reports - at least two of which were confirmed EF4s - were submitted in that time span, according to the Storm Prediction Center.\n\nHomes are left damaged after a tornado at Pavilion Estate Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, Michigan, on May 7, 2024. (Credit: Chicago & Midwest Storm Chasers via CNN Newsource)\n\nTornado Threat Continues Wednesday\n\nNearly 4 million people are under a Level 4 of 5 risk of severe thunderstorms Wednesday, according to the Storm Prediction Center. Within this risk are parts of Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky and Tennessee -- including Nashville.\n\nAn additional 50 million people from Texas, through much of the Ohio Valley and into the mid-Atlantic, are under a Level 2 of 5 or Level 3 of 5 risk.\n\nSevere storms started to bubble to life around sunrise in parts of eastern Kansas. These storms will expand in scope and strength through the morning and push into parts of Missouri. This morning activity will heavily influence how the rest of the day unfolds.\n\nIf morning storms form into a powerful and organized line, damaging winds will be the biggest threat into the afternoon hours. Hail and tornadoes will also be possible. If this organized line doesn't form, the threat for individual storms to produce strong tornadoes - at least EF2 strength - will increase.\n\nParts of Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky and Tennessee face the greatest risk of strong tornadoes, especially from the afternoon onward.\n\nAdditional storms will fire up from the Southern Plains to the mid-Atlantic throughout the afternoon. Storms capable of the strongest winds and largest hail are most likely from Texas to Kentucky and Tennessee, but any storm could unload damaging wind gusts and hail up to the size of softballs.\n\nSome areas may encounter an initial round of severe storms early Wednesday only to be hit with another round later in the day. Tennessee is a prime example. Additional severe weather is likely after thunderstorms unleashed hail, damaging winds and triggered multiple tornado warnings Wednesday morning.\n\nThe repeated rounds of storms Wednesday will also deliver torrential rainfall and raise the risk of flooding.\n\n\"The greatest flash flooding threat also overlaps with the risk of severe thunderstorms, centered over Kentucky and Tennessee as well sections of neighboring states,\" the National Weather Service said. A Level 3 of 4 risk of flooding rainfall is in place here, according to the Weather Prediction Center.\n\nRainfall rates could reach 2 inches per hour, which could dramatically increase the possibility of flash flooding. Locations worked over by multiple heavy storms could record more than 4 to 5 inches of rain.", "source": {"uri": "news.wttw.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTTW News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-05-349788141", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:32:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:32:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.fox16.com/news/national/ap-tornadoes-tear-through-southeastern-us-as-storms-leave-3-dead/", "title": "Tornadoes tear through southeastern US as storms leave 3 dead", "body": "by: By GEORGE WALKER IV, JOEY CAPPELLETTI and ED WHITE, Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could march through parts of the South early Thursday, after storms a day earlier spawned damaging tornadoes and massive hail, leaving two dead in Tennessee and one dead in North Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern U.S. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\n___\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-349796904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:43:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:43:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:24:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/tennessee/articles/2024-05-09/tornadoes-tear-through-southeastern-us-as-storms-leave-3-dead", "title": "Tornadoes Tear Through Southeastern US as Storms Leave 3 Dead", "body": "Greenville, Ohio, resident Brenda Pollitt wipes the tears from her eyes as she removes important papers from her bedroom, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. Pollitt and her children were home at the time of the strong storm that hit Tuesday evening, May 7. She and her family ran downstairs and were all safe. (Marshall Gorby/Dayton Daily News via AP)\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could march through parts of the South early Thursday, after storms a day earlier spawned damaging tornadoes and massive hail, leaving two dead in Tennessee and one dead in North Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern U.S. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8116504289", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "02:05:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T02:05:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T02:03:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/05/07/nation/50-people-trapped-tornado-michigan/", "title": "About 50 people trapped at FedEx facility after tornadoes hit Michigan, officials say - The Boston Globe", "body": "First responders were trying to get the people out but were waiting for the power company to clear downed wires blocking the way, Taylor Koopman, Kalamazoo County spokeswoman, said Tuesday evening.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road,\" company spokeswoman Shannon Davis said. \"We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service.\"\n\nPart of the roof collapsed after the tornado struck, mlive.com reported. Photos showed walls caved in.\n\nNo deaths had been reported in the city as of about 8 p.m., Portage Mayor Patricia Randall said, though crews were still assessing the damage.\n\nThe storm caused \"extensive\" damage in several areas of the city and leaving more than 21,000 of roughly 49,000 residents without power, Randall said in an email. As of about 8 p.m., she had heard of no deaths.\n\nPolice were assessing the damage, \"but with so many trees and wires down, travel is slow,\" Randall said.\n\nA mobile home park in nearby Kalamazoo was also \"hit hard,\" Koopman said, with \"entire homes destroyed.\"\n\nOn X, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer (D) urged people in southwestern Michigan to \"continue monitoring severe weather alerts and follow the advice of emergency officials.\"\n\nSeveral intense tornadoes plowed across parts of southern Michigan on Tuesday evening, causing damage and leaving injuries in their wake. Areas around Kalamazoo and Union City, about 30 miles to the southeast, appeared to be hard hit. More than 30,000 customers were without power across the region following the storms.\n\nTwisters were also confirmed in Indiana and Ohio as storms swarmed the Great Lakes, Midwest and Ohio Valley. Tornado watches stretched from southern Kentucky into southern Michigan on Tuesday evening, where severe storms capable of producing tornadoes, large hail and damaging wind were possible into the night.\n\nIn Michigan, one large tornado was seen crossing U.S. Route 131 near Kalamazoo just after 6 p.m. Significant damage was reported just to the south in Portage. A second tornado was also observed near Portage a little more than an hour after the first. The National Weather Service issued \"particularly dangerous situation\" warnings for both storms, which are reserved for confirmed large and extremely dangerous twisters.\n\nEarlier in the evening, a rare tornado emergency was hoisted by the Weather Service for another storm that tracked through Union City in south-central Michigan and probably produced either a long-track tornado or multiple tornadoes that touched down intermittently for more than an hour.\n\nThe tornado emergency in Union City - reserved for the most dire situations when a large tornado threatens a population center - was the first issued in Michigan by the Weather Service.\n\nThe tornadoes struck the Midwest, Great Lakes and Ohio Valley just one day after a violent EF4 tornado on the 0-to-5 Enhanced Fujita scale for intensity devastated parts of the city of Barnsdall in northeast Oklahoma, killing one person.\n\nThe severe storms that spawned tornadoes erupted as low pressure swept from the southern Plains on Monday into the Great Lakes on Tuesday. A warm front extending east from the low pressure zone served as the main conduit for the tornado-producing thunderstorms in southern Michigan.\n\nAt one point there were multiple concurrent \"particularly dangerous situation\" tornado warnings in addition to the tornado emergency for Union City. More than three dozen tornado warnings had been issued in the Midwest and Great Lakes through 8 p.m. Eastern time.\n\nLarge hail was also observed from the rotating thunderstorms that erupted throughout the Midwest. At least 100 reports of large hail were logged by the Weather Service, growing as large as four inches in diameter in Union City and three inches in diameter in Steuben, Ind.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8117906010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:40:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:40:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:39:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/05/08/nation/midwest-storms/", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US - The Boston Globe", "body": "National Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.", "source": {"uri": "8117902856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:37:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:37:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:37:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/indiana/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-tennessee-as-severe-storms-cross-central/article_71800f50-023d-548d-95d4-8c0837930221.html", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US", "body": "A mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo, Mich. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nBy JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8117704386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:05:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:05:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:04:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://brudirect.com/news.php?id=187124", "title": " Read More", "body": "Alex Melendez/Twitter | The damaged FedEx building in Portage\n\nDozens of people have been rescued from a FedEx depot in Michigan that had partially collapsed after a tornado.\n\nThe rare tornado hit the small town of Portage, eight miles (13km) south of Kalamazoo, on Tuesday evening.\n\nOfficials said all 50 people trapped inside escaped with no serious injuries.\n\nSevere weather warnings are still in place from Ohio to Mississippi with a few tornadoes still expected.\n\nMichigan's tornadoes damaged buildings and power lines in the region, and on Wednesday, more than 56 million people remained under threat in at least 18 states.\n\nMore than 30,000 people are still without electricity, according to the PowerOutages US website.\n\nThe severe weather marks the first-ever tornado emergency - the highest level - issued for Michigan from the National Weather Service (NWS).\n\nOfficials said up to 16 people suffered non-severe injuries after the tornadoes ripped through nearly 200 mobile homes in the area.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway, we found homes in neighbours' homes. We found large trees in homes. We found many vehicles that had been smashed by large trees or homes,\" Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said on Tuesday.\n\nHe credited the low injury rate to people's awareness and readiness for the severe weather, as well as the swift and coordinated response by emergency crews.\n\nThe tornadoes also damaged the FedEx facility in Portage, Michigan. Officials said collapsed wires and debris had to be removed in order to reach those who were stuck inside.\n\nAll were safely rescued by early Wednesday, the Kalamazoo County Government said in a statement.\n\nLate on Tuesday, FedEx said in its own statement that it is \"grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from damage to our facility\".\n\nOver a dozen tornadoes were reported on Tuesday evening in Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. A few others were reported on Wednesday morning in Arizona and West Virginia.\n\nOfficials are bracing for a third day of \"particularly dangerous\" tornadoes on Wednesday, predicting threats of severe weather in an area stretching from Springfield, Missouri to Louisville and Nashville in the east.\n\nIn addition to severe storms and tornadoes, powerful wind is also expected for parts of Tennessee, stretching down to Dallas, Texas.\n\nIf you have any stories or news that you would like to share with the global online community, please feel free to share it with us by contacting us {"uri": "2024-05-349194359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:12:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:12:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:50:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/national/article288411060.html", "title": "Severe Storms Batter Midwest, Damaging Buildings in Michigan", "body": "By Orlando Mayorqu\u00edn, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christine Hauser NYT News Service/Syndicate Stories\n\nTornadoes ripped through communities in Michigan on Tuesday evening as severe storms battered the Midwest, officials said, bringing more destruction a day after tornadoes in the southern Plains killed at least one person and damaged dozens of homes.\n\nOfficials in Kalamazoo County in southern Michigan said they were responding to a tornado that struck Portage, a city of about 50,000, leaving streets littered with downed power lines, trees and building debris.\n\nGov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo and the neighboring counties of St. Joseph, Branch and Cass, which were also pummeled by storms and large hail.\n\nAt least two tornadoes had swept through the region, the governor said.\n\nThere was destruction throughout Kalamazoo County, including significant damage to a FedEx facility in Portage, according to Andrew Alspach, a spokesperson for the Kalamazoo County Office of Emergency Management. FedEx said in a statement that there were no serious injuries at the facility.\n\nMary Beth Block, a spokesperson for the city of Portage, said late Tuesday night that there were no reports of serious injuries in the city, though some residents were displaced.\n\nShe added that there were several reports of gas leaks in the city.\n\nRoughly 18,000 customers in Kalamazoo County were without power, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nAs storms moved through the region Tuesday, the National Weather Service issued a string of tornado warnings in cities across Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Ohio.\n\nThe storms were expected to continue for a third day. Forecasters said roughly 9.5 million people in cities in Ohio and Kentucky, including Columbus, Cincinnati and Louisville, faced an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms Wednesday, with the possibility of strong tornadoes and large hail, according to the weather service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe weather service had warned earlier that storms passing over the Midwest on Tuesday would produce heavy rain that may create some localized areas of flash flooding. Urban areas, roads, small streams and low-lying areas were most vulnerable, meteorologists said.\n\nMonday night, at least 15 tornadoes were reported to have struck parts of the Plains. One tornado that was up to 2 miles wide ripped through Barnsdall, Oklahoma, a city about 40 miles northwest of Tulsa, killing one person, an Osage County official said.\n\nOne Osage County official said it had leveled about one-third of the small city, which has a population of about 1,000, and caused multiple injuries. The Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported that up to 40 homes in the town had been damaged.\n\nThe tornado also lifted the roof off a nursing home in Barnsdall, though all residents were accounted for with no injuries or deaths, officials said.\n\nMayor Johnny Kelley said one person was reported missing.\n\n\"We are going through the debris very thoroughly,\" Kelley said at a news conference Tuesday.\n\nConsidering the widespread destruction, it was \"shocking\" there were so few casualties, he said: \"The devastation is pretty substantial.\"\n\nThe tornado also caused power outages in Missouri, Arkansas and Oklahoma. But by early Tuesday, power had been largely restored.\n\nIn Bartlesville, Oklahoma, about 45 miles north of Tulsa, city officials said that emergency responders had rescued people trapped at a Hampton Inn and were recovering downed power lines early Tuesday. Only minor injuries had been reported.\n\nRescue operations were also ongoing at the Osage Nation Reservation, where officials warned residents to stay clear of the roadways and damaged areas.", {"uri": "8117313780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:58:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:58:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:57:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://conservativeangle.com/tornadoes-rip-through-midwest-destroying-buildings-in-michigan/", "title": "Tornadoes rip through Midwest, destroying buildings in Michigan - Conservative Angle", "body": "KALAMAZOO, Mich. (NewsNation) -- Severe storms barreled across the Midwest Tuesday with heavy rain and gusty winds, with as many as 25 tornadoes spotted in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio.\n\nPortions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAs the storms raged in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes hit the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings -- including a FedEx facility that collapsed.\n\nAccording to the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office, about 15 to 17 homes at the Pavilion Estates, a mobile home park in the Portage area, were destroyed. The sheriff's office said 16 to 20 people were injured in Tuesday's storms; their injuries were not life-threatening.\n\nCity officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, at least 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. Shannon Davis, a company spokesperson, said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nJeff Nazarians, a resident of Portage living near the FedEx facility, recounted to NewsNation how he was on his porch when he noticed a giant funnel cloud and debris flying through the air in his direction. He quickly ran through his house to seek shelter.\n\n\"It's not like you see on TV shows; outside it's pitch-white, swirling everywhere. I run to my basement as fast as I can. You just hear things outside dropping, flying, crashing, trees falling,\" he recalled. \"I thought the house was going to come up. My garage is torn off the ground. I come out, look around, and the FedEx building is destroyed across the street.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service issued its first-ever tornado emergency in Michigan Tuesday, the most dire of tornado alerts, for Union City and Sherwood.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency Tuesday night for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass Counties.\n\n\"Michigan is strong and together we can rebuild,\" she wrote on X.\n\nIn a statement, Whitmer wrote that the state of emergency was declared to expedite resources and Michicagion's State Emergency Operations Center to the impacted areas.\n\n\"My heart goes out to those impacted by tonight's ever weather in Michigan,\" Whitmer wrote.\n\nTuesday's storms came after parts of the central U.S. were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the small 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph.\n\nStitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four {"uri": "8118790035", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:49:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:49:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:48:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/09/storms-leave-3-dead-in-tennessee-nc/", "title": "Storms leave 3 dead in Tennessee, N.C.", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. -- Severe storms tore through parts of the U.S. again Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening after a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews were still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday. The Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures, including homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in Central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann of The Associated Press.\n\nA storm damaged mobile home is surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. A tornado ripped through the area the evening of May 7. Randall said in a statement that her city was struck by two tornadoes Tuesday, with no reports of injuries or death so far.\n\nOne of the vortexes ripped off the side of a massive FedEx facility, trapping about 50 workers as first responders hoped to clear live electrical wires blocking their safe exit, Kalamazoo County spokesperson Taylor Koopman said by email.\n\n\"The FedEx building in Portage sustained significant damage and is still an active scene,\" she said.\n\nA tornado destroyed entire residences at Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, Koopman said. Rescue crews were on-site searching for survivors and those in need of temporary shelter, which was set up at Portage Senior Center, she said.\n\nResidents were urged to stay put as first responders sort out the situation.\n\n\"We have multiple scenes across the County and heavy damage,\" Koopman said. \"There are several reports of power outages, wires down, and debris in the roadways. We ask that folks stay off the road if they're able.\"\n\nMore than 32,000 utility customers in Michigan were without power Tuesday night, according to utility tracker PowerOutage.us.\n\nImagery of a strip mall barber shop in Portage showed its front ripped away to reveal its interior.\n\n\"Due to downed power lines and trees and possible gas leaks we are urging residents to stay in their homes so first responders can reach those who need assistance,\" Randall said.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement Tuesday afternoon for an area, including Union City, southwest of Portage.\n\nA weather service meteorologist said one tornado and most likely one or two others had all but been confirmed Tuesday night, even as the service customarily waits until the next day to send trained crews to the sites of possible tornadoes for confirmation.\n\nThe severe weather since mid-April is the result of waves of cool low-pressure storms moving east from the Pacific Northwest and clashing with the warmer climes of states near the Gulf Coast. The colliding air has produced unsettled weather ripe for tornadoes, flooding and hail.\n\nThere were 19 reported tornadoes in at least seven states Monday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said heavy weather, including possible thunderstorms and flash floods, was in store for many of the same regions for the next couple of days.\n\nAn estimated 53 million people from northeast Texas to Virginia
