{"uri": "8118529875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:41:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:41:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:40:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://journalnow.com/news/state/tornadoes-tear-through-southeastern-us-as-storms-leave-3-dead/article_8f912c35-4454-5804-89f7-bf41790dc1d1.html", "title": "Tornadoes tear through southeastern US as storms leave 3 dead", "body": "Storm debris litters a portion of Cranford Hollow Road, Wednesday, May 8, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn.\n\nBy GEORGE WALKER IV, JOEY CAPPELLETTI and ED WHITE - Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could march through parts of the South early Thursday, after storms a day earlier spawned damaging tornadoes and massive hail, leaving two dead in Tennessee and one dead in North Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue an outbreak of torrential rain and tornadoes that has cut across the country this week, from the Plains to the Midwest and now the southeastern U.S. At least four people have died in storms since Monday.\n\nAmid Wednesday's storms, the National Weather Service continued issuing tornado warnings that stretch past midnight in North Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, Missouri and Kentucky. Parts of Arkansas and Mississippi were also under a tornado watch through the pre-dawn hours.\n\nOne storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee on Wednesday brought high winds that knocked down power lines and trees. Bob Brooks, the sheriff in Claiborne County about an hour north of Knoxville, said a 22-year-old man was in a car when he was fatally struck by one of the trees.\n\nA second person was killed in the city of Columbia in Maury County, where the National Weather Service said a likely tornado had touched down. Columbia is just south of Nashville.\n\nHomes were damaged and people injured, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nRita Thompson, a spokesperson for Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients, including the person who died. Another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening, she said.\n\nThe storms also prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport and the National Weather Service to issue a tornado emergency -- its highest alert level -- for other nearby areas south of the state's capital, including Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nMeanwhile, torrential rain and thunderstorms led to water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the National Weather Service warned when it issued a flash flood emergency.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, following a large storm that toppled power lines and severed trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms rolled into the region Wednesday after parts of the central United States were battered Monday by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. Then, on Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe National Weather Service said tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana on Tuesday.\n\nIn Michigan, tornadoes swirled through the southwestern part of the state, in and around Kalamazoo County, according to the National Weather Service. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, leaving about 50 people temporarily trapped inside because of downed power lines.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from another home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn the adjacent Pavilion Township, more than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon outside her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. Randall said in a statement that her city was struck by two tornadoes on Tuesday, with no reports of injuries or death so far.\n\nOne of the vortexes ripped off the side of a massive FedEx facility there, leaving about 50 workers trapped as first responders hoped to clear live electrical wires blocking their safe exit, Kalamazoo County spokesperson Taylor Koopman said by email.\n\n\"The FedEx building in Portage sustained significant damage and is still an active scene,\" she said.\n\nAt Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Park in Kalamazoo County, entire residences were destroyed by a tornado, Koopman said. Rescue crews were on-site searching for survivors and those in need of temporary shelter, which was set up at Portage Senior Center, she said.\n\nResidents were urged to stay put as first responders sort out the situation.\n\n\"We have multiple scenes across the County and heavy damage,\" Koopman said. \"There are several reports of power outages, wires down, and debris in the roadways. We ask that folks stay off the road if they're able.\"\n\nMore than 32,000 utility customers in Michigan were without power Tuesday night, according to utility tracker PowerOutage.us.\n\nImagery of a strip mall barber shop in Portage showed its front ripped away to reveal its interior.\n\n\"Due to downed power lines and trees and possible gas leaks we are urging residents to stay in their homes so first responders can reach those who need assistance,\" Randall said.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement Tuesday afternoon for an area, including Union City, southwest of Portage.\n\nA weather service meteorologist said that one tornado and likely one or two others were all but confirmed Tuesday night, even as the service customarily waits until the next day to send trained crews to the sites of possible tornadoes for confirmation.\n\nThe severe weather since mid-April is the result of waves of cool, low pressure storms moving east from the Pacific Northwest and clashing with the warmers climes of states near the Gulf Coast. The colliding air has produced unsettled weather ripe for tornadoes, flooding and hail.\n\nThere were 19 reported tornadoes in at least seven states on Monday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said heavy weather, including possible thunderstorms and flash floods, was in store for many of the same regions for the next couple of days.\n\nAn estimated 53 million people from northeast Texas to {"uri": "8116607841", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "04:01:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T04:01:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T04:00:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/severe-thunderstorms-isolated-tornado-possible-145135882.html", "title": "Buildings destroyed, trees down after tornadoes in SW MI", "body": "PORTAGE, Mich. (WOOD) -- Residents are dealing with the damage following multiple tornadoes in southwest Michigan.\n\nSign up for the Storm Team 8 daily forecast newsletter\n\nMost of the damage happened in the Portage area in Kalamazoo County and in Centreville in St. Joseph County.\n\nStorm Team 8 tracked a tornado in the Centreville area around 5:50 p.m. St. Joseph County dispatch confirmed to News 8 a potential tornado touched in Centreville.\n\nAt Main Street and Eleanor Drive in Centreville, a News 8 crew saw uprooted trees and debris from the damaged roof of nearby Nottawa Gas Company scattered through the area.\n\n\"They just moved back here within the year or so, and they sustained some pretty heavy damage on all their buildings back here,\" St. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman told News 8. \"We'll have to see what the overall damage is, but they've got extensive damage.\"\n\nHe said several buildings, both residential and commercial, have been damaged. There have been no reports of fatalities or serious injuries, he said, and first responders are working to make sure people are safe.\n\n\"When the storm came in it was pretty chaotic,\" he said. \"It moved through here quickly, but it created a lot of damage in its path.\"\n\nIn Portage, Storm Team 8 tracked a large tornado around 6 p.m. Around 7:30 p.m., another tornado warning was issued for Kalamazoo County, a tornado touched down and Storm Team 8 tracked that twister as it cut through the area.\n\nA News 8 crew on scene in the Portage area saw significant damage to a FedEx facility. The roof was damaged, as were multiple loading docks. No one was hurt in the facility, workers told News 8, and everyone in the building was accounted for.\n\nThe building opened in May of 2022 on Portage Road and was double the size of the company's former ship center on Sprinkle Road, according to the facility's senior manager when it opened. More than 400 employees worked there at its opening two years ago.\n\nJeff Nazarians, who lives nearby, said he has never seen rain switched directions so fast.\n\n\"We just saw everything was just spinning and the water on the ground was spinning. So we just ran to the bathroom That's what we did, we just took shelter. But now coming out everything is a mess. It's crazy,\" he said.\n\nAt Pavilion Estates, a mobile home park in the Portage area, people walked through a field to get into the park, which was blocked off. Storm Team 8 saw multiple first responders on scene, including three ambulances.\n\nMany people were displaced and gathered at a nearby gas station. The park is blocked off, and residents tell News 8 the facility is trying to contain a gas leak and look for anyone who may be injured in the debris.\n\n\"It is absolute destruction in there. And there are trailers completely gone. There are trees down ... There are gonna be a lot of people with no homes tonight,\" said resident Taylor Kuehl. \"It shows the force of nature and how quick it can change and unfortunately, you know a lot of families in here just trying to make day by day survival and they just lost everything.\"\n\nThere are also several trees down in the area, and viewer video shows damage to other businesses in the Portage area.\n\nJude's Barbershop location on Centre Road was hit by the reported tornado, according to a social media post.\n\n\"Luckily, everyone is safe,\" Jude's Barbershop wrote.\n\nThe Portage Department of Public Safety is asking people to avoid travel in the city. The Kalamazoo Department of Public Safety reported no significant injuries or damage within the city of Kalamazoo.\n\nAround 6:15 p.m., a tornado emergency was issued for Union City in Branch County. A tornado emergency is a rare, severe warning.\n\nThe areas of tightest rotation were captured on radar.\n\nThe first tornado's path, which likely caused more significant damage, was most pronounced in Portage. There was a possible touchdown in parts of northern Cass County and southern Van Buren County. The second tornado's path most likely caused damaged in the Centreville area and north of Colon.\n\nThe storms and tornadoes caused power outages in West Michigan. The Consumers Energy map shows 27,041 customers in Michigan without power. The following West Michigan counties had more than 100 Consumers Energy customers without power as of 9:40 p.m.:\n\nBingaman reminded people to stay away from downed power lines. If you see one, assume it is energized and call 911 and Consumers Energy at 800.477.5050.\n\nPortage Public Schools announced it would close the district as well as Curious Kids and Prime Time Childcare on Wednesday so families and the community could \"begin to recover from tonight's storms,\" it wrote in a social media post. \"Be safe and take care.\"\n\n-- News 8's Anna Skog, Blake Harms {"uri": "8117456309", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:23:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tornadoes-tear-west-michigan-emergency-121612300.html", "title": "After tornadoes tear through West Michigan, emergency workers searching through wreckage", "body": "Thunderstorms and tornadoes mauled the Midwest, tearing through several western Michigan communities Tuesday evening, leaving a trail of wreckage that weather and emergency officials will have to evaluate more closely in the light of day.\n\nAt least two tornadoes touched down in Michigan, one in Portage and the other in Branch and St. Joseph counties, National Weather Service officials in Grand Rapids said early Wednesday, adding teams would be out later surveying the damage.\n\n\"The early warnings saved lives,\" said Ernie Ostuno, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Grand Rapids, adding that the awareness building up to the dangerous weather event helped. \"The warnings went out and people reacted to them.\"\n\nIn a rare move, a tornado emergency, the weather service's highest alert level, was issued, meaning that catastrophic damage was eminent with a dangerous, perhaps deadly tornado headed toward populated areas.\n\nUtility crews were scrambling early Wednesday to reconnect electricity to tens of thousands of homes.\n\nMore: West Michigan tornadoes leave multiple injuries at mobile home park, damage FedEx facility\n\nAnd Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer assured residents that help was on the way.\n\nInjuries, emergency officials said, included at least 20 people who were taken to hospitals and destruction to 176 homes in Kalamazoo County alone, a FedEx facility, and damage to other buildings in Portage and in St. Joseph and Branch counties.\n\nBut no one, it appeared early Wednesday, had been killed.\n\nWhere tornadoes didn't touch down, the threat ended, in most places, by midnight.\n\nIn western Michigan, first responders in the worst hit areas have been looking for residents whose whereabouts were not immediately known, but as the storms headed east, weather service officials said, they lost potency.\n\nThere was some storm damage in metro Detroit, the weather service in White Lake Township said, mostly along the shoreline of Lake St. Clair and in parts of Macomb County, but it was nowhere near the destruction Michiganders on the other side of the state faced.\n\nOn the state's west side, several homes seemed to have been flattened as if smashed from above, and buildings had parts torn apart, with twisted metal siding and missing rooftops.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those affected by tonight's severe weather,\" Whitmer said around 8 p.m. Tuesday, as she declared a state of emergency for southwest Michigan. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nIn Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Communityw, some of the manufactured homes -- which are especially vulnerable to destructive twisters -- looked in photographs as if they had been rolled over or picked up and tossed about.\n\nKalamazoo County, which includes Portage and the mobile home park, seemed to take the brunt of the destruction, with more tornadoes reportedly hitting Indiana and Ohio, which meteorologists said should be expected this time of year.\n\nIn a Tuesday night news conference, Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said a tornado tore through the county, sweeping across the area from Texas Township, through Portage and into Pavilion Township, with \"significant damage\" to homes, including 15 or more that were \"totally destroyed.\"\n\nHe described a community filled with wreckage.\n\nHomes were in roadways and on top of other homes, as were trees, tree limbs and smashed vehicles.\n\nMore: Portage, Michigan tornado destroyed mobile homes, injured about 12\n\nAt one point, Fuller said, more than 100 first responders were in the mobile home park treating people for injuries and going door-to-door accounting for residents and looking for anyone who might have been harmed or missing.\n\nAnd even as emergency workers were helping residents, another storm cell swept through the area.\n\nFuller, however, said he was relieved to learn that many of the residents were paying attention to the weather alerts and warnings, and as the night went on, the dire forecasts may have helped because there did not seem to be any life-threatening injuries.\n\nHe said the alarms and sirens worked.\n\n\"The good thing is we're hearing more and more,\" Fuller said, adding that first responders have \"done multiple searches to ascertain the information, but there was nobody in those homes that were hurt significantly. There are injuries.\"\n\nMore searches, he said Tuesday night, are necessary.\n\nThe Red Cross, Fuller added, was working to find shelter for residents who lost their homes, and wireless telephone companies were trying to set up temporary networks to allow families -- and anyone who might need help -- to communicate.\n\nMichigan power outage map: How to check your status after latest round of storms\n\nBy one count early Wednesday, an estimated 32,000 homes and businesses in Michigan were without power, as utilities, mainly Consumers Energy, which said it had about 24,000 customers without electricity, scrambled to secure and reconnect downed lines.\n\n\"Our Storm Response Teams are working around the clock to restore power as quickly as possible,\" Consumers said, urging people to report serious concerns to 911 and by calling the utility at 800-477-5050, to stay at least 25 feet away from downed power lines and \"keep children and pets away.\"\n\nContact Frank Witsil: {"uri": "8117885995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:23:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:23:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:22:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-tennessee-as-severe-storms-cross-central/article_580630d9-23af-5def-a26f-aae01c132c69.html", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US", "body": "Storm damaged mobile homes are surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. A tornado ripped through the area the evening of May 7.\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8117126919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:08:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:08:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:05:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.westhawaiitoday.com/2024/05/08/nation-world-news/severe-storms-batter-midwest-damaging-buildings-in-michigan/", "title": "Severe storms batter midwest, damaging buildings in Michigan - West Hawaii Today", "body": "A scene of destruction is shown on Tuesday in Barnsdall, Okla., a day after a tornado hit it and nearby towns. (David Robert Elliott/The New York Times)\n\nTornadoes ripped through communities in Michigan on Tuesday evening as severe storms battered the Midwest, bringing more destruction a day after tornadoes in the southern Plains killed at least one person and damaged dozens of homes.\n\nOfficials in Kalamazoo County in southern Michigan said they were responding to a tornado that struck Portage, a city of about 50,000, leaving streets littered with downed power lines, trees and building debris.\n\nThe extent of the damage was not immediately clear, but local news outlets shared images from social media that showed damaged buildings.\n\nAnother a tornado warning was issued for Kalamazoo County, including Portage, even as emergency workers were responding to damage from the tornado that had hit earlier.\n\nOfficials in Kalamazoo County could not be immediately reached Tuesday evening. Roughly 20,000 customers in the county were without power in the county, according to PowerOutage.us, which aggregates utilities information across the U.S.\n\nAs storms moved through the region Tuesday afternoon, the Weather Service issued a string of tornado warnings in cities across Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan.\n\nAbout 13.5 million people in parts of Indiana, northern Kentucky and western Ohio were warned about an enhanced risk for severe thunderstorms through Tuesday evening, with the possibility of strong tornadoes and large hail, according to the Storm Prediction Center of the National Weather Service.\n\nThe roughly 60,000-square-mile area may also experience frequent lightning and strong wind gusts, according to the Weather Service.\n\nA larger section of the Midwest, encompassing nearly 16 million people across portions of Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee, was facing a slight risk of severe weather Tuesday.\n\nThe Weather Service also warned that storms passing over the region would produce heavy rain that may create some localized areas of flash flooding. Urban areas, roads, small streams and low-lying areas were most vulnerable, meteorologists said.\n\nAt least 15 tornadoes were reported to have struck parts of the Plains on Monday night. One tornado that was up to 2 miles wide ripped through Barnsdall, Oklahoma, a city about 40 miles northwest of Tulsa, killing one person, an Osage County official said.\n\nIn the predawn hours, it was difficult to assess the damage caused by the tornado, but one Osage County official said it had leveled about one-third of the small city, which has a population of about 1,000, and caused multiple {"uri": "8117788632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:06:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:06:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:05:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/article_580630d9-23af-5def-a26f-aae01c132c69.html", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "Storm damaged mobile homes are surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. A tornado ripped through the area the evening of May 7.\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck a Michigan city and surrounding area, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured from his southwestern Michigan home Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nWednesday morning, he handed out water and offered to help cut fallen tree branches around the Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\n\"It's community. I can't sit a mile away from here when I was perfectly safe,\" said Wycoff. \"I couldn't sit there in good conscience and not come down to try to help in some way.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and the adjacent Pavilion Township, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nKalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were \"totally destroyed.\" At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" the sheriff said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the buzz of chainsaws and the snap of tree limbs filled the air as cleanup began at a mobile home park.\n\n\"The clean-up efforts are tremendous. ... We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day Wednesday at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nPavilion Township is about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the Portage area, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" Sutton said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8118245814", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:34:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:34:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:32:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/8-tornadoes-confirmed-in-ohio-3-in-michigan-as-severe-storms-cross-us/article_26f2e9db-ec59-5b99-b55f-a049101e6b9f.html", "title": "8 tornadoes confirmed in Ohio, 3 in Michigan as severe storms cross US", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- At least eight tornadoes have touched down in Ohio and three were confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nJust outside of Pittsburgh, a weather service team confirmed a brief tornado with maximum winds of 105 mph (169 kph) overturned a trailer and snapped more than a dozen trees early Wednesday in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn northern West Virginia, a tornado with maximum winds of about 130 mph (209 kph) that started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio hit the community of Fairdale about an hour northwest of Pittsburgh. The weather service said it marked the first recorded tornado in Hancock County. It was at least the 11th tornado this year in West Virginia, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said. The twister damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-348412513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "02:50:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T02:50:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T02:49:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.star-telegram.com/news/nation-world/national/article288406760.html", "title": "Severe storms, tornadoes batter Midwest", "body": "By Orlando Mayorqu\u00edn, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christine Hauser NYT News Service/Syndicate Stories\n\nTornadoes ripped through communities in Michigan on Tuesday evening as severe storms battered the Midwest, officials said, bringing more destruction a day after tornadoes in the southern Plains killed at least one person and damaged dozens of homes.\n\nOfficials in Kalamazoo County in southern Michigan said they were responding to a tornado that struck Portage, a city of about 50,000, leaving streets littered with downed power lines, trees and building debris.\n\nThere was destruction throughout the county, including significant damage to a FedEx facility in Portage, according to Andrew Alspach, a spokesperson for the Kalamazoo County Office of Emergency Management. FedEx said in a statement that there were no serious injuries at the facility.\n\nAnother tornado warning was issued for Kalamazoo County, including Portage, even as emergency workers were responding to damage from the tornado that had hit earlier.\n\nOfficials in Kalamazoo County could not be immediately reached Tuesday evening. Roughly 20,000 customers in the county were without power, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nAs storms moved through the region Tuesday, the National Weather Service issued a string of tornado warnings in cities across Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Ohio.\n\nAbout 13.5 million people in parts of Indiana, northern Kentucky and western Ohio were warned about an enhanced risk for severe thunderstorms through Tuesday evening, with the possibility of strong tornadoes and large hail, according to the weather service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe roughly 60,000-square-mile area may also experience frequent lightning and strong wind gusts, according to the weather service.\n\nA larger section of the Midwest, encompassing nearly 16 million people across portions of Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee, was facing a slight risk of severe weather Tuesday.\n\nThe weather service also warned that storms passing over the region would produce heavy rain that may create some localized areas of flash flooding. Urban areas, roads, small streams and low-lying areas were most vulnerable, meteorologists said.\n\nMonday night, at least 15 tornadoes were reported to have struck parts of the Plains. One tornado that was up to 2 miles wide ripped through Barnsdall, Oklahoma, a city about 40 miles northwest of Tulsa, killing one person, an Osage County official said.\n\nOne Osage County official said it had leveled about one-third of the small city, which has a population of about 1,000, and caused multiple injuries. The Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported that up to 40 homes in the town had been damaged.\n\nThe tornado also lifted the roof off a nursing home in Barnsdall, though all residents were accounted for with no injuries or deaths, officials said.\n\nMayor Johnny Kelley said one person was reported missing.\n\n\"We are going through the debris very thoroughly,\" Kelley said at a news conference Tuesday.\n\nConsidering the widespread destruction, it was \"shocking\" there were so few casualties, he said: \"The devastation is pretty substantial.\"\n\nThe tornado also caused power outages in Missouri, Arkansas and Oklahoma. But by early Tuesday, power had been largely restored.\n\nIn Bartlesville, Oklahoma, about 45 miles north of Tulsa, city officials said that emergency responders had rescued people trapped at a Hampton Inn and were recovering downed power lines early Tuesday. Only minor injuries had been reported.\n\nRescue operations were also ongoing at the Osage Nation Reservation, where officials warned residents to stay clear of the roadways and damaged areas.", {"uri": "8117716093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:13:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:13:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:11:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2932363-midwest-braces-for-devastation-as-severe-storms-unleash-fury-shattering-fedex-facility", "title": "Midwest Braces for Devastation as Severe Storms Unleash Fury, Shattering FedEx Facility | Science-Environment", "body": "News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.Hours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and an adjacent community Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.No serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people.\n\nSevere storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck a Michigan city and surrounding area, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and an adjacent community Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\" Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were \"totally destroyed.\" At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" the sheriff said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\" On Wednesday, the buzz of chainsaws and the snap of tree limbs filled the air as cleanup began at a mobile home park.\n\n\"The clean-up efforts are tremendous. ... We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day Wednesday at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\" Pavilion Township is adjacent to Portage and about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\" National Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 am Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the US, the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nOklahoma Gov Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside USD 45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated {"uri": "8118262462", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:55:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:55:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:54:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "A mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo, Mich. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nBy JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington police give no new information after apparent standoff on West Washington Street Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8116804713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:46:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:46:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:42:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/weather-news/cnn-weather-environment/2024/05/07/destructive-tornadoes-and-storms-pummel-michigan-tuesday-and-millions-more-face-a-severe-weather-threat-wednesday/", "title": "Destructive tornadoes and storms pummel Michigan Tuesday, and millions more face a severe weather threat Wednesday", "body": "(CNN) -- Powerful tornadoes and storms swept through southwestern Michigan Tuesday evening, destroying or damaging homes and businesses and injuring several residents - and millions more from northeast Texas to the Carolinas face at least a slight risk of severe weather Wednesday.\n\nAt least a dozen people were injured at a mobile home park in Pavilion Township following a tornado Tuesday, according to a county official. The township is located in Kalamazoo County, where 15 to 20 people had minor injuries and were transported to two area hospitals, according to the county's emergency management spokesperson Andrew Alspach.\n\nIn the neighboring city of Portage, about 7 miles south of Kalamazoo, pictures and videos showed a FedEx facility with significant roof and structural damage after a storm hit the area Tuesday evening. However, there were no serious injuries, a FedEx representative told CNN.\n\nAbout 50 people were trapped in the building due to downed wires, Taylor Koopman, a spokesperson for Kalamazoo County administrator's office, told MLive.com, adding work to clear the wires was ongoing as of 9:30 p.m. ET. However, city of Portage spokesperson Mary Beth Block told CNN in an email the building had been cleared by authorities.\n\nTwo tornadoes hit the Portage area Tuesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\n\"We have significant damage, including damage to residential and commercial buildings, trees down across many roads in the city, and several reports of gas leaks,\" Portage city officials said in a news release.\n\nThe city pleaded with its residents to \"stay home\" and \"please stay off the roads. First responders are stuck in gridlock.\"\n\nThe Village of Centreville was hit hard during a possible tornado on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County officials. Multiple buildings, residential and commercial, were destroyed after a possible tornado touched down in Centreville on Tuesday, according to St. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman. The storm damage ripped off roofs and flattened homes \"completely down,\" Bingaman told CNN.\n\nIn Branch County, about 60 miles south of Kalamazoo, at least seven homes were destroyed, according to Emergency Management Director Tim Miner, who added he was unable to get out and assess damage to other parts of the county.\n\nOne city in the county, Union City, was under a rare tornado emergency earlier that went into effect when \"a large and destructive tornado\" was over the area, about 10 miles northwest of Coldwater and moving northeast at 45 mph, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAccording to the Storm Prediction Center, at least nine tornado reports were made in Michigan on Tuesday. Hail the size of softballs was also reported in some parts of the state.\n\nMore than 34,000 homes and businesses in Michigan were left without power as of early Wednesday, according to poweroutage.us. Elsewhere in the Midwest, more than 16,000 residents were in the dark in Ohio.\n\nGov. Gretchen Whitmer said her heart was going out to those impacted by the severe weather in southwest Michigan. The governor declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties, she said Tuesday night.\n\n\"We will work with emergency teams overnight to monitor the situation and coordinate resources for those affected. Michigan is strong and together we will rebuild,\" the governor said.\n\nAfter Tuesday brought tornadoes, large hail, damaging wind gusts and heavy rainfall mainly across the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley, much of the Eastern US braces for another round of storms Wednesday. Over 140 million people could see some sort of storms Wednesday from Texas to Maine.\n\nSevere thunderstorms are likely Wednesday across parts of the southern Plains into the mid Mississippi, Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, according to the Storm Prediction Center. As severe storms hit, tornadoes, very large hail, and damaging winds are expected over the large area. Some of the tornadoes may be strong, according to the center.\n\nA population of nearly 20 million people will be under the strongest severe storm threat. The Storm Prediction Center has issued a level 3 of 5 enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms from northeast Texas to western Virginia, which includes much of the lower Ohio Valley, Tennessee Valley and middle to lower Mississippi Valley. Cities in the strongest threat for severe storms include Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Louisville.\n\n\"The greatest flash flooding threat also overlaps with the risk of severe thunderstorms, centered over Kentucky and Tennessee as well sections of neighboring states,\" the National Weather Service said. \"Residents and visitors are advised to have multiple ways of receiving warnings and never drive across flooded roadways.\"\n\nLower severe storm threats spread from central Texas to the southern tip of Maine and includes the cities of Dallas, Atlanta, Chicago, Washington D.C., Baltimore, New York City, Boston and Charlotte. There, the threats are more likely to be large hail and damaging wind gusts, but tornadoes cannot be ruled out.\n\nSpring is known for severe storms and tornadoes - and Spring 2024 is no exception. There has been at least one tornado report every day since April 25, a streak of 13 consecutive days, according to the Storm Prediction Center. A total of 287 tornadoes were reported in that time span.\n\nApril to June is peak tornado season across the US, with May traditionally seeing the most tornadoes. This month is coming off a particularly active April, where there were 300 tornadoes, the second most on record, according to the center. The all-time record occurred in April 2011, when there were 757 tornadoes.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. The NWS also declared a tornado emergency in Union City, more than 120 miles east of Portage.\n\nMichiganders join more than 10 million people in parts of Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky who also face storms and tornadoes on Tuesday.\n\nThe severe weather in Michigan follows a deadly tornado and storm in Barnsdall, a small town in Oklahoma that is home to around 1,000 residents, that left one person dead, five injured and dozens of homes damaged on Monday night and early Tuesday morning, according to the local television news station KOCO. This was just one of more than a dozen tornadoes that tore through central US states including Kansas, South Dakota, and Missouri on Monday and Tuesday.\n\nLess than two weeks before this, another tornado ripped through Nebraska and Iowa, with the most damage happening in Omaha, where hundreds of homes and structures and several miles of farmland were destroyed, the Associated Press reports. And in Lancaster county, home to Lincoln, the capital of Nebraska, 70 people were trapped inside an industrial building that had collapsed.\n\nThis most recent devastation in Michigan follows nearly two months of destruction across the midwest, including a cluster of more than 10 tornadoes in mid-March that swept through five states including Indiana and Ohio.
