{"uri": "8117820806", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:30:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:30:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:29:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/08/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck a Michigan city and surrounding area, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured from his southwestern Michigan home Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nWednesday morning, he handed out water and offered to help cut fallen tree branches around the Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\n\"It's community. I can't sit a mile away from here when I was perfectly safe,\" said Wycoff. \"I couldn't sit there in good conscience and not come down to try to help in some way.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and the adjacent Pavilion Township, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nKalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were \"totally destroyed.\" At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" the sheriff said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the buzz of chainsaws and the snap of tree limbs filled the air as cleanup began at a mobile home park.\n\n\"The clean-up efforts are tremendous. ... We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day Wednesday at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nPavilion Township is about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the Portage area, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" Sutton said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-350629320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:36:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:36:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:34:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://thehornnews.com/more-dangerous-storms-pummel-south/", "title": "More dangerous storms pummel South  - The Horn News", "body": "Dangerous storms continued to batter parts of the South on Thursday, following a day of severe weather with damaging tornadoes that claimed the lives of at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms moved into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour, causing delays at busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center warned of an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather spanning from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nSponsored: Gold is SOARING - here's what you need to do\n\nThese storms are part of a series of torrential rains and tornadoes that have impacted the Plains, Midwest, and now the Southeast throughout the week. The death toll since Monday has risen to at least four. The severe weather comes after an exceptionally stormy April, during which the U.S. experienced 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-highest number on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nAs of Thursday, nearly a quarter-million homes and businesses across several Southern states were still without power due to the previous night's storms, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nIn Tennessee, a tornado damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and claimed the life of a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, as reported by officials. A second person lost their life south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nColumbia resident Bob Booth had just returned home from Georgia and was about to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\" He described the scene outside as \"all hell breaking loose\" and mentioned that the top half of one of his trees had fallen across the road. Booth was informed that it would take some time before his power was restored.\n\nHe noted that one neighbor was fortunate, as all of their trees were destroyed except for one that would have destroyed their house.\n\nSponsored: This \"miracle material\" is about to ROCK the market...\n\nIn Spring Hill, not far from Columbia, retired pastor Walter Shell and his wife took their two dogs and sought shelter in the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado. Shell remarked, \"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about about 4 inches. It went around. It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nNortheast of Nashville, torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues. The city's main airport issued a temporary ground stop, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nSeveral Tennessee counties closed schools on Thursday. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times due to storm damage overnight, which included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported in the area.\n\nLynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency, said, \"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round.\"\n\nIn northern Alabama's DeKalb County, a strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes and caused injuries but no deaths, according to officials.\n\nSponsored: New Patented Manufacturing Process Could Be The Cancer Breakthrough We've All Been Waiting For\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car, killing one person inside and sending another to the hospital.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail, and tornadoes that affected parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest bore the brunt of the severe weather, with tornadoes touching down in parts of Michigan, Ohio, and Indiana.\n\nThe Kalamazoo area in Michigan was particularly hard hit, with a FedEx facility being ripped apart and downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas, and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which typically sees an average of two tornadoes per year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been pummeled by {"uri": "8117126094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:05:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:05:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:05:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/local/2024/05/08/officials-say-2-tornadoes-hit-michigan-city-causing-major-damage/", "title": "Officials say 2 tornadoes hit Michigan city, causing major damage", "body": "PORTAGE, Mich. - Officials say two tornadoes touched down in a Michigan city, causing major damage, power outages, and an emergency declaration.\n\nCity officials from Portage, Michigan, reported \"significant damage\" in the area bound by Centre Avenue, Oakland Drive, Schuring Road, and Westnedge Avenue.\n\nNo injuries reported\n\nNo injuries have been reported, but several people are displaced.\n\nThe Salvation Army has set up two shelters for the people who lost their homes. One is at the First Assembly of God at 5550 Oakland Drive and the other is at Radiant Church at 995 Romence Road. Each shelter has a capacity of 100 people.\n\nMultiple gas leaks have also been reported.\n\nFedEx facility destroyed\n\nResidential and commercial buildings were badly damaged during the storm, including a FedEx facility.\n\n\"Our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road,\" a FedEx spokesperson said in a statement. \"We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service. Customers with questions about their shipments can check fedex.com for updates.\"\n\nPower outages\n\nSeveral trees were also knocked down across the city.\n\nConsumers Energy is working to restore power to customers with outages. As of midnight around 20,000 customers remained without power in the Portage area.\n\nMost customers will not have their power back until around 10 p.m. Wednesday, May 8, the company reports.\n\nEmergency declaration\n\nPortage Mayor Patricia Randall issued an emergency declaration that will allow the city to receive resources from the state and federal governments.\n\nOfficials from Michigan State Police, the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office, Kalamazoo Public Safety, the West Michigan 5th District Technical Rescue Team, LifeEMS, and others are currently helping in the aftermath of the storms.\n\nResidents were asked to shelter in place and check on their neighbors. Stay off the roads to keep them clear for first responders.\n\nState of emergency\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch, and Cass counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in Southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"", "source": {"uri": "clickondetroit.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WDIV"}, {"uri": "8118237269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:20:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:20:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:19:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/8-tornadoes-confirmed-in-ohio-3-in-michigan-as-severe-storms-cross-us/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "8 tornadoes confirmed in Ohio, 3 in Michigan as severe storms cross US", "body": "A mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo, Mich. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nBy JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- At least eight tornadoes have touched down in Ohio and three were confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nOn Wednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington police give no new information after apparent standoff on West Washington Street Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nJust outside of Pittsburgh, a weather service team confirmed a brief tornado with maximum winds of 105 mph (169 kph) overturned a trailer and snapped more than a dozen trees early Wednesday in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn northern West Virginia, a tornado with maximum winds of about 130 mph (209 kph) that started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio hit the community of Fairdale about an hour northwest of Pittsburgh. The weather service said it marked the first recorded tornado in Hancock County. It was at least the 11th tornado this year in West Virginia, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said. The twister damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8118260020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:51:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:51:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:50:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/powerful-storms-kill-2-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_26f2e9db-ec59-5b99-b55f-a049101e6b9f.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 2 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing one person in Tennessee and another in North Carolina when trees toppled onto their vehicles.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA tornado warning had previously been issued in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. Radar indicated a tornado struck Jefferson County, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine its rating, said Jeff Craven, a weather service meteorologist in Pittsburgh.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8119901921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:06:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:06:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:06:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/national/storm-battered-south-is-again-under-threat-a-boy-swept-into-a-drain-fights-for/article_148561f5-dcee-581f-bdc0-03048f1708e6.html", "title": "Storm-battered South is again under threat. A boy swept into a drain fights for his life", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Dangerous storms crashed over parts of the South on Thursday even as the region cleaned up from earlier severe weather that spawned tornadoes, killed at least three people, and gravely injured a boy who was swept into a storm drain as he played in a flooded street.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina. An emergency manager reported \"significant wind damage\" from a possible tornado Thursday afternoon in the Vidalia, Georgia, area, a region known for producing onions.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. Since Monday, 39 states have been under threat of severe weather and at least four people have died. On Wednesday, 98 million people were under some sort of severe weather risk, said Evan Bentley, a Storm Prediction Center forecaster.\n\nThe weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nMore than 100,000 homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday afternoon in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the seat of Maury County, where officials said a tornado with 140 mph (225 kph) winds damaged or destroyed more than 100 homes.\n\nTennessee Gov. Bill Lee said the woman who died in Maury County was in a mobile home that was thrown several feet into a wooded area. Lee visited emergency managers and Tennessee Department of Transportation officials in the storm-stricken area Thursday. He thanked workers who spent the night clearing trees and debris from roads.\n\nLater, Lee told reporters that it is \"heartbreaking\" to see families whose lives have been affected by the tornado.\n\n\"To observe another family in a moment of crisis is hard to watch, but it is hopeful to be able to walk up and see their interaction with their neighbors and comments that they're going to make it,\" Lee said.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nA 10-year-old boy was seriously injured in Christiana, southeast of Nashville, when he got caught in a storm drain and swept under streets while playing with other children as adults cleared debris, his father, Rutherford County Schools Superintendent Jimmy Sullivan, posted on social media.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe boy, Asher, emerged in a drainage ditch and survived after being given CPR, \"but the damage is substantial,\" Sullivan posted on Facebook, asking for prayers.\n\n\"Asher needs a miracle,\" Sullivan wrote.\n\nDozens of people gathered at the school district's offices for a prayer vigil Thursday. They bowed their heads and closed their eyes in prayer, and they sang \"Amazing Grace\" together.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday and Friday in Rutherford and Maury. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAssociated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Kimberlee Kruesi, Travis Loller, Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Sarah Brumfield, Adrian Sainz and John Raby.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8117708602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:08:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:08:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:06:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility-5950694.html", "title": "World News | Severe Storms Batter the Midwest, Including Reported Tornadoes That Shredded a FedEx Facility | LatestLY", "body": "Pavilion Township (Michigan, USA), May 8 (AP) Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck a Michigan city and surrounding area, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAlso Read | India Will Offer Alternative To China for Investors With PM Narendra Modi, Mukesh Ambani, Gautam Adani Reshaping Nation to Become Economic Superpower, Reports CNN.\n\nThe storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nAlso Read | Israel-Gaza Conflict: Israel Reopens Kerem Shalom Border Crossing for Delivery of Aid to War-Torn Nation.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and an adjacent community Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nKalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were \"totally destroyed.\" At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" the sheriff said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the buzz of chainsaws and the snap of tree limbs filled the air as cleanup began at a mobile home park.\n\n\"The clean-up efforts are tremendous. ... We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day Wednesday at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nPavilion Township is adjacent to Portage and about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 am Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the US, the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live.\n\nIt should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town.\n\nA 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nOklahoma Gov Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph).\n\nStitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside USD 45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. {"uri": "8118076120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:18:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:18:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:17:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/8-tornadoes-confirmed-in-ohio-3-in-michigan-as-severe-storms-cross-central-us/article_26f2e9db-ec59-5b99-b55f-a049101e6b9f.html", "title": "8 tornadoes confirmed in Ohio, 3 in Michigan as severe storms cross central US", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- At least eight tornadoes have touched down in Ohio and three have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. late Tuesday and early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe National Weather Service says confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in Ohio, including five in Warren County in the state's southwest region. The confirmations came Wednesday after crews were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWeather service meteorologist in Michigan Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nIn addition to the five in Warren County, confirmed tornadoes in Ohio were in the western part of the state in Greenville in Darke County, west of Coldwater in Mercer County and west of New Knoxville in Auglaize County. The weather service says crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nJust outside of Pittsburgh, a weather service team confirmed that a brief tornado with maximum winds of 105 mph (169 kph) overturned a trailer and snapped more than a dozen trees early Wednesday in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier, destroying a bar and damaging the high school. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. {"uri": "8117276450", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:34:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:34:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:34:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/news/2024/05/national-weather-services-damage-surveys-could-take-days-after-tornadoes-blitz-michigan.html", "title": "National Weather Service's damage surveys could take days after tornadoes blitz Michigan", "body": "PORTAGE, MI - After tornadoes reportedly touched down in several spots Tuesday as storms rolled across Michigan, the National Weather Service says investigating the areas of damage could take more than one day.\n\nThe Portage area in Kalamazoo County will be the main focus Wednesday for a survey team from the National Weather Service's Grand Rapids office. Typically, survey field work after a severe storm is done the very next day. The survey team inspects the damage to buildings, homes, trees and even crops so they can determine if a tornado touchdown caused the damage, or if severe winds were to blame.\n\nOnce a tornado is confirmed by the NWS, the survey results include details like its estimated intensity, time on the ground, damage path and more.\n\nBut damage reports from Tuesday's storms came from multiple counties. So it could turn the survey work into a multi-day event if areas outside Kalamazoo County need to be investigated, NWS staff initially said.\n\nRELATED: 'Hell broke loose': Residents in shock after reported tornadoes rip through Portage\n\nThe city of Portage and surrounding townships in Kalamazoo County seemed to be the hardest hit as daybreak revealed the full extent of damage today. While there have been no reported fatalities there, up to 20 people were injured in the storm, sheriff's officials said. In a mobile home park just outside Portage, an estimated 176 homes were damaged and up to 17 were completely destroyed. The storm tossed homes into the road, into other homes, and sent trees down on homes and vehicles.\n\nThis morning, National Weather Service meteorologists in the Grand Rapids office said only one of the reported tornado touchdowns had been officially confirmed so far. That's the twister that hit the Portage area around 6 p.m. Tuesday. It was confirmed via video and radar data. NWS staff said it may be the only place they end up doing an official survey. A second tornado reported by a trained spotter in Portage about an hour later has not been officially confirmed. NWS officials today said they are trying to track down any photo or video evidence of that second Portage twister.\n\nThis has sparked some confusion among forecasters and those who report NWS weather news. This morning, there were questions as to exactly how many tornadoes may have touched down in Michigan on Tuesday. During the hours-long storm system's movement across Michigan, the NWS issued several Tornado Warnings of \"radar indicated\" tornadoes - or twisters identified by their rotation and debris as seen on radar. The NWS also used language for Tornado Warnings in Calhoun and Van Buren counties that \"a large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly tornado is on the ground.\"\n\nAs of now, we're waiting to see if more NWS field surveys are planned to look at damage outside of Portage, and when those might happen.", "source": {"uri": "mlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "mlive"}, "authors": [], As of early Wednesday morning, the National Weather Service, which is responsible for determining whether or not a tornado occurred, reported that only one tornado was confirmed thus far, and it was located in Portage, Minnesota.\n\nDespite the fact that no injuries have been reported, many people have been displaced as a result of the flooding.\n\nTwo shelters have been established by the Salvation Army for those who have lost their homes. In one location, First Assembly of God is located at 5550 Oakland Drive, while in the other location, Radiant Church is located at 995 Romence Road. A total of 100 people can be accommodated in each shelter.\n\nThe storm damaged residential and business facilities, including a FedEx plant.\n\nDespite the damage caused by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, FedEx is grateful that no serious injuries were sustained at its facility located at 6701 Portage Road, the company said in a statement. Our team is continuing to analyze the damage and implementing contingency plans to mitigate any potential disruptions to service. If you have questions about your shipments, please visit fedex.com for the latest information.\"\n\nThere have been no recorded injuries, but many individuals have been displaced.\n\nSalvation Army has opened two shelters for people who lost their homes. First Assembly of God, 5550 Oakland Drive, and Radiant Church, 995 Romence Road, are the two locations. Each shelter has a capacity for 100 people.\n\nIn addition, several gas leaks have been detected.\n\nThe storm caused extensive damage to residential and business facilities, including a FedEx plant.\n\nAccording to a FedEx spokesperson, \"our thoughts are with those affected by the tornado in Portage, Michigan, and we are grateful there were no serious injuries caused by damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road.\" Fedex is continuing to analyze the damage and is implementing contingency plans to mitigate any service disruptions. Customers who have questions about their shipments can get updates by visiting fedex.com.\"\n\nConsumers Energy is working to restore electricity to customers experiencing outages. As of midnight, approximately 20,000 people in the Portage region remained without power.\n\nThe majority of customers will not have their power restored until after 10 p.m. On May 8, the corporation will release its report regarding the incident.\n\nPortage Mayor Patricia Randall declared an emergency declaration, allowing the city to obtain assistance from the state and federal governments.\n\nThere are now authorities from Michigan State Police, the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office, Kalamazoo Public Safety, West Michigan 5th District Technical Rescue Team, LifeEMS, and other agencies providing assistance in the aftermath of the storm.\n\nA shelter-in-place order was issued and residents were instructed to check on their neighbors. To facilitate first responders' use of the roadways, please stay off them.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer has proclaimed a state of emergency in Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch, and Cass counties.\n\nIt is my sincere hope that all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in Southwest Michigan will be able to recover,\" Whitmer said. {"uri": "8119647867", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:49:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:49:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:48:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.local3news.com/local-news/georgia/storm-battered-south-is-again-under-threat-a-boy-swept-into-a-drain-fights-for/article_4304f5c1-e9d7-5327-8f7d-de626c0de97f.html", "title": "Storm-battered South is again under threat. A boy swept into a drain fights for his life", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Dangerous storms crashed over parts of the South on Thursday even as the region cleaned up from earlier severe weather that spawned tornadoes, killed at least three people, and gravely injured a boy who was swept into a storm drain as he played in a flooded street.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. Since Monday, 39 states have been under threat of severe weather and at least four people have died. On Wednesday, 98 million people were under some sort of severe weather risk, said Evan Bentley, a Storm Prediction Center forecaster.\n\nThe weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nMore than 170,000 homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday afternoon in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the seat of Maury County, where officials said a tornado damaged or destroyed more than 140 homes.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nA 10-year-old boy was seriously injured in Christiana, southeast of Nashville, when he got caught in a storm drain and swept under streets while playing with other children as adults cleared debris, his father, Rutherford County Schools Superintendent Jimmy Sullivan, posted on social media.\n\nThe boy, Asher, emerged in a drainage ditch and survived after being given CPR, \"but the damage is substantial,\" Sullivan posted on Facebook, asking for prayers. A vigil was planned for Thursday afternoon at the school district office.\n\n\"Asher needs a miracle,\" Sullivan wrote.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in Rutherford and several other Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAssociated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Travis Loller, Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Sarah Brumfield, Adrian Sainz and John Raby.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-350697602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:13:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:13:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.kadn.com/news/national/storm-battered-south-again-under-threat-boy-swept-into-drain-fights-for-his-life/article_07208def-3d7a-555d-817e-d2bf4cfa1414.html", "title": "Storm-battered South again under threat; boy swept into drain fights for his life", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Dangerous storms crashed over parts of the South on Thursday even as the region cleaned up from earlier severe weather that spawned tornadoes, killed at least three people, and gravely injured a boy who was swept into a storm drain as he played in a flooded street.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. Since Monday, 39 states have been under threat of severe weather and at least four people have died. On Wednesday, 98 million people were under some sort of severe weather risk, said Evan Bentley, a Storm Prediction Center forecaster.\n\nThe weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nMore than 170,000 homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday afternoon in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the seat of Maury County, where officials said a tornado damaged or destroyed more than 100 homes.\n\nGov. Bill Lee says the woman who died in Maury County was in a mobile home at the time the storm hit, which was thrown several feet into a wooded area.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nA 10-year-old boy was seriously injured in Christiana, southeast of Nashville, when he got caught in a storm drain and swept under streets while playing with other children as adults cleared debris, his father, Rutherford County Schools Superintendent Jimmy Sullivan, posted on social media.\n\nThe boy, Asher, emerged in a drainage ditch and survived after being given CPR, \"but the damage is substantial,\" Sullivan posted on Facebook, asking for prayers. A vigil was planned for Thursday afternoon at the school district office.\n\n\"Asher needs a miracle,\" Sullivan wrote.\n\nDozens of people gathered at the school district's offices for a prayer vigil Thursday. They bowed their heads and closed their eyes in prayer, and they sang \"Amazing Grace\" together.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in Rutherford and several other Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAssociated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Travis Loller, Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Sarah Brumfield, Adrian Sainz and John Raby.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nAlso Read | Victory Day 2024: Russia Celebrates Victory in World War II As Vladimir Putin Accuses West of Fueling Global Conflicts.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the US had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nNearly a quarter-million homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nAlso Read | Europe Day 2024 Date, History and Significance: Know About the International Event That Marks the Anniversary of the Historic Schuman Declaration.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said.\n\nA second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbour, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. A temporary ground stop was issued at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this
