{"uri": "2024-05-349424224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "19:18:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T19:18:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:06:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.crainsgrandrapids.com/news/small-business/portage-businesses-scramble-after-tornado-rips-through-area/", "title": "Portage businesses scramble after tornado rips through area", "body": "Businesses in Portage are scrambling to recover, and banding together, in the wake of at least one confirmed tornado that touched down Tuesday night in the city south of Kalamazoo.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Grand Rapids confirmed via radar and on-the-ground spotters that a tornado took place around 5:55 p.m. to approximately 6:15 p.m. in the Kalamazoo-Portage area.\n\nAnother cell went through the Portage area about an hour and 15 minutes after the first tornado, with spotters on the ground saying it was a tornado. National Weather Service Meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the second cell had not yet been confirmed as a tornado as of Wednesday morning.\n\nKeep up with all things West Michigan business. Sign up for our free newsletters today.\n\nStill, the severe weather left a trail of destroyed homes and businesses in its path. Many Portage businesses announced via Facebook that they would not be open until further notice because of the severe damage to their buildings.\n\nThe hardest hit area in the city is bound by Centre Avenue, Oakland Drive, Schuring Road and Westnedge Avenue, according to a press release from the city of Portage.\n\n\"We are deeply saddened to inform you that our building has been significantly affected by the tornado that just hit our Portage community,\" Burn Boot Camp, a gym located at 7545 Westnedge Ave. in Portage, said on Facebook. \"The safety and well-being of our members and employees are our top priority, and as a result, we will be temporarily closed as we assess the damage and work on rebuilding.\"\n\nImages posted of the Portage Centre location of Jude's Barbershop, 2050 W. Centre Ave., showed entire exterior walls destroyed after being hit by the tornado.\n\n\"Our barbershop in Portage on Centre Rd was hit by the Tornado. Luckily, everyone is safe,\" according to the Jude's Facebook page.\n\nMichelle's, a Portage restaurant located at 677 Romence Road, did not face damage or power outages and remains open to the community. The business announced via Facebook that it would be open on May 8 starting at 6:45 a.m. for people to eat and regroup.\n\n\"We're just offering our facility if people just want to come and charge their phone and their phone or just get out, and, you know, out of the elements, and just to regroup,\" Michelle's owner Mark Romstadt told Crain's. \"Whatever they need, we're doing whatever we can.\"\n\nRomstadt said Michelle's is busier than normal. The business typically would have five employees on a Wednesday, but today 11 people are working to help with the increased number of customers, said Romstadt.\n\nLatitude 42, a restaurant and brewery with locations in Portage and Kalamazoo, lost power at its Portage location during dinner service last night, according to Brad Bishop, president of the company.\n\nThe restaurant is back online today. Bishop said Latitude is offering complimentary Wi-Fi, food and beverages to those in need, including a burger bar for first responders, which will be open from 11:30 to 2:30 today.\n\n\"We're hoping we can be there for the community and support them first and foremost,\" Bishop said. \"Anybody that needs help, we're here for them.\"\n\nAs well, a FedEx shipping facility on Portage Road was leveled. At one point during the storm Tuesday night, 50 employees were reportedly trapped inside the facility for a short time because of downed power lines.\n\n\"I can confirm those FedEx team members who initially sought shelter inside the building are all safe and accounted for,\" a FedEx spokesperson said in an emailed statement. \"We are grateful there were no serious injuries resulting from the damage to our facility at 6701 Portage Road. We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service.\"\n\nKalamazoo County Commissioner John Taylor, whose district includes the city of Portage, said residents are being asked to stay off the roads if possible to let emergency crews clear roadways of trees, power lines and other debris from the storm.\n\n\"We're transitioning from trying to save lives, and now we're in the cleanup phase,\" said Taylor, who serves as vice chairperson on the Kalamazoo County board. \"Stay off the roads at least for a little while longer, let emergency crews clear off the rest of the streets, then we can start the process of clearing damaged buildings.\"\n\nDriving this morning, Taylor said he saw entire strip malls \"completely ripped out\" on Centre Avenue near Oakland Drive.\n\nTaylor confirmed that, as of this morning, no known fatalities resulted from the tornadoes, and multiple people with injuries were sent to local hospitals.\n\nResidents who need assistance or access to shelter can call the city's 2-1-1 line. The Salvation Army set up shelters at Kalamazoo First Assembly of God church at 5550 Oakland Drive and Radiant Church at 995 Romence Road. The city of Portage's non-emergency offices are closed today.\n\nAs of Wednesday at 9 a.m., Consumers Energy reported nearly 24,000 power outages in its Southwest Michigan territory, including outages concentrated between Portage and Vicksburg and farther south in Colon in St. Joseph County.\n\nJeruzal, of the National Weather Service, said the strength of the tornado is yet to be determined by storm survey teams.\n\n\"We don't know exactly what the strength of the tornado is yet, but our teams are going to be evaluating that today,\" Jeruzal said. \"Seeing, you know, what type of damage exactly how they were fastened (buildings) ... some of the integrity of the buildings and they'll make determinations on how strong the tornado was from that.\"\n\nJeruzal said the storm survey teams began examining the site of the storm this morning and because of the amount of damage from the storm, evaluations can be ongoing throughout the day and potentially into tomorrow.\n\nIn addition to the damage to strip malls, Jeruzal noted the Portage FedEx facility and mobile home park faced significant damages and were more affected by severe weather conditions because those locations are not on foundations.\n\nMore from Crain's Grand Rapids Business:\n\nFormer Ottawa Beach Inn near Holland to be revived under new owners -- with a nod to the past\n\nDemolition starts for Acrisure {"uri": "8117894246", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:29:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:29:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:29:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.govtech.com/em/safety/cleanup-begins-after-11-tornadoes-in-western-michigan", "title": "Cleanup Begins After 11 Tornadoes in Western Michigan", "body": "(TNS) - A day after as many as 11 tornadoes landed in west Michigan , residents and authorities struggled to deal with the aftermath of significant damage to homes and businesses as well as thousands of power outages.\n\n\"I couldn't believe it,\" said Marilyn Williams , a 69-year-old resident of Portage . \"It's unreal to wake up to it, even after seeing it last night.\"\n\nTwo tornadoes were reported in both Portage in Kalamazoo County and Dowagiac in Cass County, according to the National Weather Service. The weather service said one tornado also was reported in Centreville, Colon, Leonidas , Mendon and Wasepi in St. Joseph County. Another was reported in Sherwood in Branch County, and there was one in Comstock in Kalamazoo County.\n\nThe damage in Portage , among the hardest hit areas, was widespread, leaving several businesses inoperable. City officials, meanwhile, continued to assess the damage on Wednesday.\n\nAt Jude's Barbershop on West Centre Avenue in Portage, the shop is a \"total loss,\" office manager Amanda Renis said.\n\n\"Half the building is ripped off, the ceiling is partially gone and there's a gas leak,\" Renis told The News Wednesday morning. \"Jude's has been open for more than 20 years, but this location on Centre in the strip mall is newer, only four years old. Our other location right down the road is fully operable, thankfully.\"\n\nThe first tornado was reported at 5:15 p.m. Tuesday in Dowagiac and the last at 7:22 in Comstock, NWS said.\n\nThe tornadoes downed trees and power lines and scattered debris from buildings and homes. Late Tuesday, Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller III said up to 20 people reportedly were hospitalized for injuries from blown glass and debris. No fatalities were reported, he said.\n\nOn Wednesday, he said in a statement that the county's government has declared a local state of emergency. He also said Portage Public Safety has reported that door-to-door checks are being conducted in the hardest-hit areas. \"As recovery efforts continue, various agencies and organizations are working tirelessly to restore normalcy to affected areas and assist those in need,\" he said.\n\nThe tornadoes caused substantial damage in several areas, including Centre Street up to Shearing andWestnedge up to Angling Road , according to the sheriff's office. Fuller said Wednesday a FedEx building on Portage Rd. and the Pavilion Estates mobile home park both sustained extensive damage.\n\nAt one point, employees were trapped inside the FedEx building, county officials said. They also said entire homes were destroyed at the Pavilion Estates mobile home park. The county confirmed Wednesday that 176 homes on the property were damaged and 40 percent of those were heavily damaged.\n\n\"Portage first responders have ensured all employees are safely out of the FedEx building,\" the sheriff said. \"And our teams have also completed their search and rescue at Pavilion Estates and have confirmed 16 to 20 injuries at this time, with no casualties.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the Salvation Army has established two shelters: First Assembly of God , located at 5550 Oakland Drive , and Radiant Church , located at 995 Romence Road. Each has a capacity of 100 people.\n\nThe Kalamazoo County sheriff said Portage police were investigating damage to the FedEx facility on Portage Road.\n\nResidents across the street from the site spent their Wednesday morning clearing wreckage on their own.\n\nHarsh winds uprooted trees in Williams' front and back yards on Lansing Avenue in Portage, tearing away chunks of driveway in one fell swoop, she said. No one on the block was injured, Williams said.\n\nAs retired electricians, Williams said she and her husband were just glad to have supportive friends willing to step in and help after the storm passed.\n\nUpheaval from the storm changed Pedro Martinez's plans for Wednesday, forcing him to spend the morning clearing his own driveway, the 67-year-old resident on Ramona Avenue said.\n\nThe violent storm downed several trees and some electrical wires on his street, though he hadn't heard of any injuries or casualties yet, Martinez said.\n\nMartinez and his family thought the alerts on their phones were just false alarms until the storm was practically on their doorstep, he said.\n\nMartinez' grandson, 9-year-old Daniel Martinez , said he was scared of these storm at first but still eager to help his family clean up the next day.\n\n\"I was running to my basement,\" Daniel Martinez said, adding the fear had shifted to excitement as he recounted the experience to friends the next day. \"I sent them a picture of the destruction.\"\n\nMichael Browers, 59, spent his morning with family helping him clear fallen trees, said the Ramona Avenue resident living a few doors down from Martinez.\n\nMore than a dozen pine trees fell in his backyard, while one large tree fell directly onto his roof, he said.\n\nThe damage was incalculable so far, he said.\n\nBrowers and his family were especially concerned their insurance might not be able to cover impending repairs, he said.\n\n\"Being disabled, I can make a couple cuts, go sit for a couple hours, then make a couple cuts and go sit for a couple hours,\" he said.\n\nThe only thing Browers felt he could do now in the aftermath of the storm was to take things one day at a time, he said.\n\n\"I've lived here about 35 years, and I haven't ever really taken it seriously,\" Martinez said of the extreme weather. \"I will now.\"\n\nAs neighbors rushed to clear damage, crews tend to thousands without power Wednesday.\n\nThere were 127 outages reported in Consumers Energy's service area and about 22,000 people affected, mainly in Portage, Colon and St. Joseph . Elsewhere, DTE Energy reported Wednesday afternoon it had more than 5,600 power interruptions, mainly in Fraser, Harrison Township and St. Clair Shores. Power was expected to be restored by 10 p.m.\n\nClean-up crews are on the ground with assistance from Michigan State Police, Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Department, City of Kalamazoo Public Safety, West Michigan 5th District Technical Rescue Team, LifeEMS and others.\n\nThe city of Portage non-emergency offices were closed on Wednesday. Those in need of assistance with sheltering or other human service needs should call 2-1-1.\n\nGov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo , St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Michigan Department of Environment , Great Lakes, and Energy urged residents to follow cleanup guidelines set by the state.\n\n\"In times of significant weather incidents, we are keeping the health and safety of Michiganders at the forefront of cleanup efforts,\" EGLE Director Phil Roos said in a statement. \"Safe debris disposal is an essential part of this storm response process and protective of our state's environment.\"\n\nThe Better Business Bureau In Western Michigan also warned homeowners \"to beware of scammers, sometimes called 'storm chasers,' when looking to hire help to clean up. Homeowners should be wary of anyone going door-to-door offering storm cleanup assistance. They should also use caution when looking on social media for help. These situations prompt good-intentioned neighbors to lend a helping hand. It can also bring out those who are looking to take advantage of people during a vulnerable time.\"\n\nAs cleanup continues, clearer weather is forecast in most of the affected area.\n\n\"After a stormy Tuesday, tranquil weather will return for Wednesday with mostly sunny skies and temperatures in the upper 60s and 70s,\" meteorologists with the weather service's Grand Rapids office said.\n\nRain is expected to return Thursday as high temperatures fall to around 60, according to the weather service.\n\ncramirez@detroitnews.com\n\n@CharlesERamirez\n\n\u00a92024 The Detroit News. Visit detroitnews.com. {"uri": "8117891499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:27:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:27:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:27:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-tennessee-as-severe-storms-cross-central/article_e051f3ef-ec1c-5e05-b046-5d8afe11c02d.html", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the US had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nNearly a quarter-million homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\" \"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\" Booth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbour, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.'' Retired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\" Torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. A temporary ground stop was issued at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said. The storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.(AP) RUP RUP\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/remote.axd?https://devdiscourse.blob.core.windows.net/devnews/16_10_2021_14_05_40_994896.jpg?width=920&format=jpeg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9548085", {"uri": "8119204510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:17:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:17:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:17:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/news/kalamazoo/2024/05/portage-tornado-tied-for-kalamazoo-countys-worst-since-1980.html", "title": "Portage tornado was Kalamazoo County's worst since 1980", "body": "PORTAGE, MI -- The May 7 tornado that swept through Portage was Kalamazoo County's first tornado in 15 years and its tied for the worst since the 1980 tornado that struck the city of Kalamazoo.\n\nThis week's twister touched down around 5:55 p.m. near 10th Street and R Avenue and cut an 11-mile path to N Avenue near 31st Street.\n\nAlong the way, it partially collapsed the FedEx shipping Center on Portage Road, displaced more than 100 families and damaged hundreds more homes and businesses, officials said. Especially hard-hit were the Timberlake Creek apartment complex on Schuring Road and two mobile home parks, Oak Brook Estates mobile home park along Lovers Lane and Pavilion Estates near Sprinkle Road.\n\nMORE: See the 11-mile path Kalamazoo County's tornado took Tuesday\n\nA second reported tornado in the county hasn't been confirmed yet by the National Weather Service, as of Thursday morning.\n\nThe confirmed tornado was rated as an EF2 by the National Weather Service with winds of up to 135 miles per hour, which is one mph less than the threshold for a EF3 tornado.\n\nHowever, no fatalities and only a handful of injuries were reported -- unlike the 1980 Kalamazoo tornado, in which five were killed and 79 were injured.\n\nThe 1980 twister began about 4 p.m. May 13, 1980, sweeping through the heavily populated Westwood neighborhood, damaging more than 200 homes before into plowing into the heart of downtown Kalamazoo.\n\nMORE: Remembering the Kalamazoo tornado 40 years after it struck May 13, 1980\n\nThere, among other damage, the storm demolished St. Augustine Cathedral School on West Michigan Avenue, sheered off the back wall of the seven-story Gilmore Department Store on the Kalamazoo Mall and toppled more than two dozen trees in Bronson Park that were at least 150 years old.\n\nThat storm was rated an F3, with winds of 150 to 175 mph, using the original Fujita scale. The Enhanced Fujita scale was adopted in 2007.\n\nThat was the deadliest storm in Kalamazoo's history, based on National Weather Service records that go back to 1950.\n\nHowever, it wasn't the most severe tornado in county history. That belongs to the F4 tornado on April 2, 1977. But that one resulted in zero deaths and only 10 injuries.\n\nHere's a chart of all confirmed tornadoes on record in Kalamazoo County on record, which dates back to 1954.\n\nThose records show that Kalamazoo County had 25 confirmed tornadoes in the past 74 years before this week. That includes one F4 tornado, two F3s, in 1965 and 1980, and now four F2s/EF2s.\n\nThere were six tornadoes before this week that resulted in injuries: In 1955, 1965, 1973, 1977, 1978 and 1980.\n\nThe county's last tornadoes occurred 15 years ago, on June 19, 2009, a day when there were actually two tornadoes reported around 10 p.m. The first was an EF1 that touched down for a two-mile stretch in Alamo Township. The second, an EF2, touched down for less than a mile but tore the roof off a home in Richland Township.\n\nHere's a map of all of Kalamazoo County's confirmed tornadoes on record, dating back to 1954. This week's tornado isn't included -- here's that map.\n\nAmong the memorable tornado events in Kalamazoo County was the so-called Palm Sunday tornado outbreaks on April 11, 1965, the deadliest day for tornadoes in the Great Lakes region, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nMichigan, Indiana and Ohio were especially hard hit. In all, there were 47 confirmed tornadoes, 271 deaths and 3,400 people injured, the NWS says.\n\nA dozen tornadoes swept through Michigan that day, killing 51 and injuring 800. Most of those deaths and injuries occurred when two tornadoes cut an 80-mile-plus path through Branch, Hillsdale, Lenawee and Monroe counties.\n\nIn Kalamazoo County, an F3 tornado touched down around 6:30 p.m. on Palm Sunday 1965 and cut a 14-mile path of destruction through Cooper, Richland and Ross townships, injuring 17, demolishing four homes and damaging 22 others. Another 14 people were injured in two tornadoes that tore through Allegan and Barry counties.\n\nThe Palm Sunday tornado outbreaks are considered a \"watershed moment in weather history,\" the NWS says. In the wake of that outbreak, the National Weather Service introduced the \"tornado watch\" and \"tornado warning\" system and worked with the media -- particularly television and radio stations -- to publicize tornado watch and warning announcements. In addition, communities began to use civil defense sirens to warn of approaching tornadoes.\n\nThe only F4 tornado ever recorded in Kalamazoo County occurred on April 2, 1977, and was one of two F4 tornadoes in Michigan that day. Although it was 47 years ago, those were also the most recent F4s in the state, according to NWS records.\n\nThe Gaylord tornado in 2022 was an EF3.\n\nThe 1977 Kalamazoo County twister first touched down in Comstock Township around 1:30 p.m. and took at 12-mile path northeast, tearing into Galesburg and Augusta, destroying buildings and injuring 10 people. One witness recalled seeing an Augusta home go up in the air and slam to the ground; another told of finding the roof of the Augusta Lumber Company \"sitting on top of my car,\" according to a WZZM-TV report marking the tornado's 47th anniversary.\n\nMinutes after that 1977 twister died out in Kalamazoo County, a second F4 tornado formed in Eaton County, racing from Bellevue to Eaton Rapids. That storm was even more dangerous, killing one person and injuring 40 others.\n\nThere were three other Kalamazoo County tornadoes since 1950 that resulted in an injury, according to the NWS:\n\nAn interesting side note: In the past 74 years, 12 of the 25 tornadoes recorded in Kalamazoo County occurred in a 15-year span, from 1965 to 1980. That period also includes five of the six tornadoes that resulted in injuries.\n\nIndeed, Kalamazoo had eight tornadoes during the 1970s, compared to no tornadoes since 2009 until this week.\n\nThe table below documents all confirmed tornadoes in Michigan from 1950 to 2020. It's searchable by county and can be sorted by category.\n\nOfficials say that tornado-related deaths and injuries have become less frequent because of better warning systems.\n\nThis week was the first time that a tornado \"emergency alert\" was issued in Michigan. That alert warns residents of a confirmed tornado sighting, with a threat of catastrophic damage and severe threat to human life.\n\nThis week, Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller underscored the importance of emergency alerts.\n\n\"Forty-four years ago, we had a much more tragic event come through and cause five lives to go,\" Fuller said during a May 8 press conference. \"Because they were paying attention last night and hearing the alerts, lives were saved. We heard more than one story where people said, 'We just got out of there.'\"", "source": {"uri": "mlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "mlive"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": At least four people have died since Monday.\n\nThe weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the US had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter of a million customers without power on Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm on Wednesday in north-eastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said.\n\nA second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a tornado had probably touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta cancelled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rain led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues north-east of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared on Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central US on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. {"uri": "8119515896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:59:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:59:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:59:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/wave-of-new-storms-pummel-u-s-south-as-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on", "title": "Wave of new storms pummel U.S. South as week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began crashing over parts of the South on Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nREAD MORE: Ohio valley braces for potential tornadoes after severe weather hits south\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nNearly a quarter-million homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nIn Spring Hill, not far from Columbia, retired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. A temporary ground stop was issued at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8119518146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:03:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:03:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:01:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/article_216f021f-bdb2-5e26-9c7b-d0834931d0b0.html", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "Valerie Bernhardt searches for belongings outside her stormed damaged home Thursday, May 9, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn. Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S., Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing several people in Tennessee.\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began crashing over parts of the South on Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nNearly a quarter-million homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. A temporary ground stop was issued at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nThis version deletes an incorrect reference to Shell living in Spring Hill, Tennessee; he lives in Columbia.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency late Tuesday after a series of tornadoes pummeled the upper Midwestern state, injuring more than 15 people.\n\nThe Democratic governor issued the emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties, stating they will work with emergency teams overnight to monitor the situation and coordinate resources for those affected.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" she said in a statement.\n\nA number of tornado and severe weather warnings were issued throughout Tuesday by the National Weather Service, with several tornados reported.\n\n\"Significant\" tornado damage was incurred by Kalamazoo County, Sherif Richard Fuller said during an update posted online.\n\nThe tornado hit a mobile home park, requiring multiple ambulances, as well as fire trucks, to be dispatched, he said early Wednesday.\n\nAt least 176 homes in the park were damaged, including about 17 that were destroyed, he added.\n\nBetween 16 and 20 people at the mobile park sustained injuries, but none appeared to be life-threatening, he said.\n\nIn Portage, officials said in a statement that two tornadoes hit the city, causing \"significant damage,\" including to residential and commercial buildings.\n\nAmong the collapsed buildings was Portage's FedEx facility.\n\nThe storm downed trees and there were several reports of gas leaks, the city said in a statment, adding about 20,000 customers were without power.\n\nNo serious injuries were reported, though several people have been displaced {"uri": "8117440674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:13:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:13:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:13:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "People leave after a tornado swept through the area of the Pavilion Estates mobile home park, in Kalamazoo, Mich., Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Multiple injuries were reported at the park.\n\nBy ED WHITE, ALEXA ST. JOHN and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nDETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Police clear scene on West Washington Street Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued tornado watches Thursday for parts of Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and Tennessee. An enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms with very large hail was forecast for parts of eastern Texas.\n\nStorms left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where the weather service said a tornado had likely touched down.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nThunderstorms with torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nStorm-damaged mobile homes are surrounded by debris at Pavilion Estates mobile home park just east of Kalamazoo, Mich. Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (Neil Blake/The Grand Rapids Press via AP)\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\n___\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. {"uri": "8119632136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:35:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:35:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:34:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://time.com/6976600/storms-south-deadly-weather/", "title": "Storms Pummel the South as Week of Deadly Weather Continues", "body": "(COLUMBIA, Tenn.) -- Dangerous storms crashed over parts of the South on Thursday even as the region cleaned up from earlier severe weather that spawned apparent tornadoes, killed at least three people, and gravely injured a boy who was swept into a storm drain as he played in a flooded street.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nNearly a quarter-million homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nA 10-year-old boy was seriously injured in Christiana, southeast of Nashville, when he got caught in a storm drain and swept under streets while playing with other children as adults cleared debris, his father, Rutherford County Schools Superintendent Jimmy Sullivan, posted on social media.\n\nThe boy, Asher, emerged in a drainage ditch and survived after being given CPR, \"but the damage is substantial,\" Sullivan posted on Facebook, asking for prayers. A vigil was planned for Thursday afternoon at the school district office.\n\n\"Asher needs a miracle,\" Sullivan wrote.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in Rutherford and several other Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nAssociated Press journalists around the country contributed to this No was was hurt in the collapse, the company told USA TODAY in a statement. Nearby, a tornado hit a mobile home community, injuring 16 to 20 people who were hospitalized with non life-threatening injuries. Around 176 properties were damaged, 17 of which were completely destroyed, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller in a video posted on Facebook.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway, we found homes in neighbor's homes,\" said Fuller, urging residents to stay home as officials continue to search for people and survey the damage across the county.\n\nTens of thousands without power in Michigan after tornadoes\n\nIn St. Joseph County, just south of Kalamazoo, a tornado destroyed seven structures, mostly homes, Branch County Emergency Manager Tim Miner told the Detroit Free Press, part of the USA TODAY Network, adding that there were no deaths or serious injuries.\n\nMore than 30,000 homes and businesses in Michigan, mostly in the southeastern part of the state, were without power Wednesday morning, according to a USA TODAY tracker.\n\nThe looming storm system spun up at least eight tornadoes through the night in Michigan; others were reported in Arkansas, Ohio and West Virginia, according to the National Weather Service. The same storm system battered the Plains region on Monday, spinning up multiple tornadoes that killed at least one person, destroyed homes and caused widespread power outages. Meanwhile, more severe weather is forecast.\n\nTornadoes, hail, damaging wind forecast for parts of central US\n\nTwenty million people from northeast Texas to Kentucky were at enhanced risk of severe storms on Wednesday, according to the Storm Predication Center. The powerful thunderstorms were expected to bring tornadoes, \"very large to giant hail,\" and potentially significant damaging winds, the prediction center said.\n\nThe cities in the areas of highest risk include Nashville, Memphis, St. Louis, Louisville and Little Rock, according to the weather service. A vast swath of the central and eastern U.S., from Texas to Georgia and up through New England is at slight risk of experiencing some of the poor weather.\n\nFlood watches were in effect across {"uri": "8119653328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:54:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:54:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:54:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://journalnow.com/news/state/storm-battered-south-is-again-under-threat-a-boy-swept-into-a-drain-fights-for/article_8f912c35-4454-5804-89f7-bf41790dc1d1.html", "title": "Storm-battered South is again under threat. A boy swept into a drain fights for his life", "body": "By KRISTIN M. HALL and GEORGE WALKER IV - Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Dangerous storms crashed over parts of the South on Thursday even as the region cleaned up from earlier severe weather that spawned tornadoes, killed at least three people, and gravely injured a boy who was swept into a storm drain as he played in a flooded street.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. Since Monday, 39 states have been under threat of severe weather and at least four people have died. On Wednesday, 98 million people were under some sort of severe weather risk, said Evan Bentley, a Storm Prediction Center forecaster.\n\nThe weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nMore than 170,000 homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday afternoon in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the seat of Maury County, where officials said a tornado damaged or destroyed more than 140 homes.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nA 10-year-old boy was seriously injured in Christiana, southeast of Nashville, when he got caught in a storm drain and swept under streets while playing with other children as adults cleared debris, his father, Rutherford County Schools Superintendent Jimmy Sullivan, posted on social media.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe boy, Asher, emerged in a drainage ditch and survived after being given CPR, \"but the damage is substantial,\" Sullivan posted on Facebook, asking for prayers. A vigil was planned for Thursday afternoon at the school district office.\n\n\"Asher needs a miracle,\" Sullivan wrote.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in Rutherford and several other Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nA strong tornado damaged at least 20 homes in northern Alabama's DeKalb County and caused injuries but no deaths, officials said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAssociated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Travis Loller, Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Sarah Brumfield, Adrian Sainz and John Raby.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
