{"uri": "8118322331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:07:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:07:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:06:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/powerful-storms-kill-3-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 3 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "A mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo, Mich. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nBy GEORGE WALKER IV, JOEY CAPPELLETTI and ED WHITE - Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S. late Tuesday and Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington police give no new information after apparent standoff on West Washington Street Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nCrews on Wednesday were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister, which started early Wednesday in far eastern Ohio, was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state that sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Nashville and Memphis, Tennessee -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8119400688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:33:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:33:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:32:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://norfolkdailynews.com/news/national/news_national/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/article_489da22e-0e18-11ef-a872-9f6b9e1b9c5a.html", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. {"uri": "2024-05-350419671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:35:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:35:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:35:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-05-09/deadly-weather-us-south-13804784.html", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, N.C., reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy Tornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio.\n\nMeanwhile, the first-ever tornado emergency in Michigan was issued Tuesday, one of many called across the country in recent weeks as severe weather tears through states in the Plains and Midwest. As massive storms barrel East, homes and property have been destroyed and thousands of people have gone without power.\n\nTornado emergencies differ from tornado watches and warnings. According to the National Weather Service, emergencies are far rarer and are issued when there's an imminent or ongoing severe threat to human life and catastrophic damage. Watches suggest tornadoes are possible and that people in the area should be prepared. Warnings mean a weather radar indicates a tornado is coming, or it's been seen already, and people in the area need to act.\n\nAP photos.", "source": {"uri": "whmi.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-348989044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:16:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://eu.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2024/05/08/tornadoes-tear-through-midwest-with-at-least-2-ripping-west-michigan/73610750007/", "title": "After tornadoes tear through west Michigan, emergency workers searching through wreckage", "body": "Thunderstorms and tornadoes mauled the Midwest, tearing through several western Michigan communities Tuesday evening, leaving a trail of wreckage that weather and emergency officials will have to evaluate more closely in the light of day.\n\nAt least two tornadoes touched down in Michigan, one in Portage and the other in Branch and St. Joseph counties, National Weather Service officials in Grand Rapids said early Wednesday, adding teams would be out later surveying the damage.\n\n\"The early warnings saved lives,\" said Ernie Ostuno, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Grand Rapids, adding that the awareness building up to the dangerous weather event helped. \"The warnings went out and people reacted to them.\"\n\nIn a rare move, a tornado emergency, the weather service's highest alert level, was issued, meaning that catastrophic damage was eminent with a dangerous, perhaps deadly tornado headed toward populated areas.\n\nUtility crews were scrambling early Wednesday to reconnect electricity to tens of thousands of homes.\n\nAnd Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer assured residents that help was on the way.\n\nInjuries, emergency officials said, included at least 20 people who were taken to hospitals and destruction to 176 homes in Kalamazoo County alone, a FedEx facility, and damage to other buildings in Portage and in St. Joseph and Branch counties.\n\nBut no one, it appeared early Wednesday, had been killed.\n\nWhere tornadoes didn't touch down, the threat ended, in most places, by midnight.\n\nHomes flattened, power out\n\nIn western Michigan, first responders in the worst hit areas have been looking for residents whose whereabouts were not immediately known, but as the storms headed east, weather service officials said, they lost potency.\n\nThere was some storm damage in metro Detroit, the weather service in White Lake Township said, mostly along the shoreline of Lake St. Clair and in parts of Macomb County, but it was nowhere near the destruction Michiganders on the other side of the state faced.\n\nOn the state's west side, several homes seemed to have been flattened as if smashed from above, and buildings had parts torn apart, with twisted metal siding and missing rooftops.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those affected by tonight's severe weather,\" Whitmer said around 8 p.m. Tuesday, as she declared a state of emergency for southwest Michigan. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nIn Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Communityw, some of the manufactured homes -- which are especially vulnerable to destructive twisters -- looked in photographs as if they had been rolled over or picked up and tossed about.\n\nKalamazoo County, which includes Portage and the mobile home park, seemed to take the brunt of the destruction, with more tornadoes reportedly hitting Indiana and Ohio, which meteorologists said should be expected this time of year.\n\nIn a Tuesday night news conference, Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said a tornado tore through the county, sweeping across the area from Texas Township, through Portage and into Pavilion Township, with \"significant damage\" to homes, including 15 or more that were \"totally destroyed.\"\n\nHe described a community filled with wreckage.\n\nHomes were in roadways and on top of other homes, as were trees, tree limbs and smashed vehicles.\n\nAt one point, Fuller said, more than 100 first responders were in the mobile home park treating people for injuries and going door-to-door accounting for residents and looking for anyone who might have been harmed or missing.\n\nAnd even as emergency workers were helping residents, another storm cell swept through the area.\n\nFuller, however, said he was relieved to learn that many of the residents were paying attention to the weather alerts and warnings, and as the night went on, the dire forecasts may have helped because there did not seem to be any life-threatening injuries.\n\nHe said the alarms and sirens worked.\n\n\"The good thing is we're hearing more and more,\" Fuller said, adding that first responders have \"done multiple searches to ascertain the information, but there was nobody in those homes that were hurt significantly. There are injuries.\"\n\nMore searches, he said Tuesday night, are necessary.\n\nThe Red Cross, Fuller added, was working to find shelter for residents who lost their homes, and wireless telephone companies were trying to set up temporary networks to allow families -- and anyone who might need help - to communicate.\n\nBy one count early Wednesday, an estimated 32,000 homes and businesses in Michigan were without power, as utilities, mainly Consumers Energy, which said it had about 24,000 customers without electricity, scrambled to secure and reconnect downed lines.\n\n\"Our Storm Response Teams are working around the clock to restore power as quickly as possible,\" Consumers said, urging people to report serious concerns to 911 and by calling the utility at 800-477-5050, to stay at least 25 feet away from downed power lines and \"keep children and pets away.\"", "source": {"uri": "freep.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Detroit Free Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nPeople are also reading... WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin\n\nThe storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, about 12 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nSurvey teams planned to headed out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9548085", "eventUri": "eng-9548085", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3803921568627451, "wgt": 156, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118750521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:20:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:20:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:20:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://statesville.com/news/state/ap/powerful-storms-kill-3-as-tornadoes-tear-through-central-and-southeastern-us/article_a277f304-596d-530b-80b7-5c0de16e3810.html", "title": "Powerful storms kill 3 as tornadoes tear through central and southeastern US", "body": "Emergency crews are seen along Cranford Hollow Road after severe storms tore through the area Wednesday, May 8, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn.\n\nBy GEORGE WALKER IV, JOEY CAPPELLETTI and ED WHITE - Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Severe storms tore through parts of the U.S. again Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee and one person in North Carolina.\n\nA storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nWednesday afternoon, a tornado emergency -- the weather service's highest alert level -- was issued for an area south of Nashville including the towns of Spring Hill, Chapel Hill and Eagleville.\n\nThe National Weather Service had previously reported a likely tornado on the ground in nearby Columbia, about 45 miles (72 kilometers) south of Nashville. People in Columbia were injured and homes were damaged, according to Lynn Thompson, assistant director of Maury County 911. Thompson told The Associated Press that he could not provide any further details: \"We're getting overloaded right now.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Former Statesville football star focused on future with Kansas City Chiefs HIGH SCHOOL: 10 Iredell teams set to embark on baseball, softball state playoffs West Iredell Army JROTC cadets save a life, honored with Medal of Heroism Veteran, 98, connects with B-29 bomber, his past in Statesville Woman's condition deteriorated quickly after fatal dose of insulin. Winston-Salem nurse charged with murder North Carolina Public health restaurant and food-stand inspections in Iredell County, April 18-May 2 North Iredell Middle's Ward earns scholarship to attend UNC basketball camp One dead, another wounded in Clemmons shooting. Dispute began at Truist soccer field Storment signs with Edmonton Statesville Community Appearance Commission honors outstanding efforts with Spring Appearance Awards Ruger eliminates 80 job positions amid lower demand for firearms ROUNDUP: North Iredell secures first softball playoff victory in a decade; Mooresville, Lake Norman win to set up second-round showdown Two teens charged with murder in Mooresville double homicide Plans for 1,200 houses in Statesville draw ire, questions from nearby residents A heckler tried to derail Trevor Noah's speech at Wake Forest University. He answered her question\n\nRita Thompson, Marketing & Communications director with Maury Regional Health, said the hospital had received five patients. One died, another was in serious condition and three had injuries that were not life-threatening.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville International Airport because of the weather, media outlets reported. Northeast of Nashville, a flash flood emergency was issued for Sumner and Robertson counties including the cities of Hendersonville and Gallatin. The National Weather Service said water rescues were ongoing in those areas and described the flooding from heavy thunderstorms as life-threatening.\n\n\"Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order,\" the weather agency alert said.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Nashville on Wednesday evening issued a tornado watch for parts of Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee until 3 a.m. CDT. The weather service continued issuing tornado warnings into the night, mostly in Tennessee, but also in Missouri, Alabama, Georgia and Texas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared for Gaston County Wednesday evening following a large storm. First responders were working to clear roads of downed power lines and broken trees and were helping residents, officials said. The New Hope Fire Department responded to a tree down on a car. One person in the car was killed and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nMore than 135,000 customers had lost power in the state as of Wednesday evening, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in western Ohio: five in Warren County and one each in Darke, Mercer and Auglaize counties. The weather service said crews are still surveying areas in other counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well. The strong storms also brought hail and heavy rains to the state and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nIn Michigan, weather service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed. About 50 people temporarily were trapped inside the damaged facility because of downed power lines.\n\nMore than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation. She said her parents and brother were injured during the storm but survived.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area, and he said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and freed a service dog from a home.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado touched down early Wednesday. The Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures, including homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"It was definitely a scary moment. ... And I'm glad we're alive,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed in Pennsylvania just outside Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nOn Monday, parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes, including a deadly twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Nashville and Memphis, Tennessee -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-350386989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:04:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:04:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:14:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/climate-and-environment/new-storms-pummel-the-southern-u-s-killing-at-least-three-1.6879781", "title": "New storms pummel the southern U.S., killing at least three", "body": "A wave of dangerous storms has begun washing over parts of the U.S. South a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour Thursday. Busy hub airports in Georgia and North Carolina reported delays. Tornado warnings were issued in the morning for parts of Tennessee and Alabama. The storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday.\n\nThe weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbour, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta cancelled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-350226520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:35:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:35:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:48:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/storms-threaten-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-punches-through-the-us", "title": "Storms Threaten the South as a Week of Deadly Weather Punches Through the US", "body": "Columbia: Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could wash over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued tornado watches Thursday for parts of Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and Tennessee. An enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms with very large hail was forecast for parts of eastern Texas.\n\nStorms left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where the weather service said a tornado had likely touched down.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nThunderstorms with torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\n___\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. (CBS DETROIT) - The National Weather Service confirmed on Wednesday that an EF-2 tornado struck Portage, Michigan, Tuesday evening.\n\nWeather officials say the tornado reached an estimated peak wind of 135 mph and touched down near the intersection of S. 10th Street and W. R Avenue. It traveled for about 11 miles, damaging home roofs and sidings.\n\nThe tornado started at 5:55 p.m. and ended at 6:17 p.m. Tuesday, according to the NWS.\n\n\"Along the path, many homes had roof and/or siding damage. Two mobile home parks were impacted with several homes destroyed in each park. A number of business had significant damage along the path,\" NWS said.\n\n\"Multiple apartment complexes were also impacted with apartments on Timbercreek Court seeing the most significant damage. Hundreds of trees were snapped and uprooted along the path. A large section of the roof of an industrial warehouse also collapsed near the Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International Airport.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the city of Portage said there were no fatalities or serious injuries due to the storm and is now going through the cleanup process. Officials say 23,000 customers in Kalamazoo County lost power and Consumers Energy was working to restore power.\n\nThe National Weather Service confirmed that at least two tornadoes struck Southwest Michigan. {"uri": "2024-05-350361054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:38:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:38:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:16:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/article_8debd2a4-c435-5902-b66f-51db1de00dbd.html", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8117898657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:34:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:34:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:33:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-tennessee-as-severe-storms-cross-central/article_26f2e9db-ec59-5b99-b55f-a049101e6b9f.html", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. No was was hurt in the partial collapse, the company told USA TODAY in a statement. Nearby, a tornado hit a mobile home community, injuring 16 to 20 people who were hospitalized with non life-threatening injuries. Around 176 properties were damaged, 17 of which were completely destroyed, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller in a video posted on Facebook.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway, we found homes in neighbor's homes,\" said Fuller, urging residents to stay home as officials continue to search for people and survey the damage across the county.\n\nTens of thousands without power in Michigan after tornadoes\n\nIn St. Joseph County, just south of Kalamazoo, a tornado destroyed seven structures, mostly homes, Branch County Emergency Manager Tim Miner told the Detroit Free Press, part of the USA TODAY Network, adding that there were no deaths or serious injuries.\n\nMore than 30,000 homes and businesses in Michigan, mostly in the southeastern part of the state, were without power Wednesday morning, according to a USA TODAY tracker.\n\nThe looming storm system spun up at least eight tornadoes in Michigan; others were reported in Arkansas, Ohio and West Virginia, according to the National Weather Service. The same storm system battered the Plains region on Monday, spinning up multiple tornadoes that killed at least one person in Oklahoma, flattened homes and caused widespread power outages. Meanwhile, more severe weather is on the way.\n\nTornadoes, hail, damaging wind forecast for parts of central US\n\nTwenty million people from northeast Texas to northern Kentucky were at enhanced risk of severe storms on Wednesday, according to the Storm Predication Center. The powerful thunderstorms were expected to bring tornadoes, \"very large to giant hail,\" and damaging winds, the prediction center said.\n\nThe cities in the areas of highest risk include Nashville, Memphis, St. Louis, Louisville and Little Rock, according to the weather service. A vast swath of the central and eastern U.S., from Texas to Georgia and up through New England was at slight risk of experiencing some of the poor weather.\n\nFlood watches were in effect across Kentucky, Tennessee and Missouri through Thursday morning. Multiple tornado watches were active across the same area.\n\nContributing: Dinah Voyles Pulver; Kylie Martin, Detroit Free Press", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8118070873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:13:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:13:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:12:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/8-tornadoes-confirmed-in-ohio-3-in-michigan-as-severe-storms-cross-central-us/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "8 tornadoes confirmed in Ohio, 3 in Michigan as severe storms cross central US", "body": "A mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo, Mich. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nBy JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- At least eight tornadoes have touched down in Ohio and three have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. late Tuesday and early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nThe National Weather Service says confirmed tornadoes touched down Tuesday in Ohio, including five in Warren County in the state's southwest region. The confirmations came Wednesday after crews were able to survey the damage caused by the strong storms that contained hail and heavy rains and knocked out power to thousands of utility customers.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington police give no new information after apparent standoff on West Washington Street Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nWeather service meteorologist in Michigan Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes there touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nIn addition to the five in Warren County, confirmed tornadoes in Ohio were in the western part of the state in Greenville in Darke County, west of Coldwater in Mercer County and west of New Knoxville in Auglaize County. The weather service says crews are still surveying areas of Franklin and Butler counties to determine if tornadoes struck there, as well.\n\nJust outside of Pittsburgh, a weather service team confirmed that a brief tornado with maximum winds of 105 mph (169 kph) overturned a trailer and snapped more than a dozen trees early Wednesday in Findlay Township, Pennsylvania.\n\nBaseball-sized hail was reported Wednesday in areas just southwest of St. Louis, Missouri. Heavy downpours caused flash flooding and at least one water rescue near Sullivan, a town that was struck by a small tornado just two days earlier, destroying a bar and damaging the high school. Damaging hail also was reported in the Kansas City area.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8119163424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:50:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:50:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:50:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.wvua23.com/storms-threaten-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-punches-through-the-us/", "title": "Storms threaten the South as a week of deadly weather punches through the US - WVUA 23", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could wash over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued tornado watches Thursday for parts of Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and Tennessee. An enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms with very large hail was forecast for parts of eastern Texas.\n\nStorms left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where the weather service said a tornado had likely touched down.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nThunderstorms with torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency late Tuesday after a series of tornadoes pummeled the upper Midwestern state, injuring more than 15 people.\n\nThe Democratic governor issued the emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties, stating they will work with emergency teams overnight to monitor the situation and coordinate resources for those affected.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" she said in a statement.\n\nA number of tornado and severe weather warnings were issued throughout Tuesday by the National Weather Service, with several tornados reported.\n\n\"Significant\" tornado damage was incurred by Kalamazoo County, Sherif Richard Fuller said during an update posted online.\n\nThe tornado hit a mobile home park, requiring multiple ambulances, as well as fire trucks, to be dispatched, he said early Wednesday.\n\nAt least 176 homes in the park were damaged, including about 17 that were destroyed, he added.\n\nBetween 16 and 20 people at the mobile park sustained injuries, but none appeared to be life-threatening, he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn Portage, officials said in a statement that two tornadoes hit the city, causing \"significant damage,\" including to residential and commercial buildings.\n\nAmong the collapsed buildings was Portage's FedEx facility.\n\nThe storm downed trees and there were several reports of gas leaks, the city said in a statment, adding about 20,000 customers were without power.\n\nNo serious injuries were reported, though several people have been displaced by the storm, it said.\n\nIn Branch County, Emergency Manager Tim Miner said seven structures were destroyed, though there were no serious {"uri": "8119308015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:26:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:26:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/", "title": "New Storms Pummel The South As A Week Of Deadly Weather Marches On", "body": "(AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy
