{"uri": "8117884754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:21:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:21:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:21:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/3-tornadoes-confirmed-in-michigan-1-man-killed-in-tennessee-as-severe-storms-cross-central/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "3 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan, 1 man killed in Tennessee as severe storms cross central US", "body": "A mobile park home flipped onto two nearby cars after a tornado struck Pavilion Estates near Kalamazoo, Mich. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.\n\nBy JOEY CAPPELLETTI, ED WHITE and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nPAVILION TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) -- Three tornadoes have been confirmed in Michigan as severe storms barreled through the central U.S. early Wednesday, killing one man in Tennessee when a tree toppled onto a vehicle he was in.\n\nThe storm that rumbled across northeastern Tennessee brought high winds that knocked down powerlines and trees. Claiborne County Sheriff Bob Brooks said a 22-year-old man was in a car struck by one of the trees.\n\nNational Weather Service meteorologist Nathan Jeruzal said the tornadoes in Michigan touched down one each in Kalamazoo, Cass and Branch counties -- all in the southwestern part of the state.\n\nKalamazoo County's Portage area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed.\n\nPeople are also reading... Police clear scene on West Washington Street Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nSamantha Smith clutched a box Wednesday afternoon as she stepped from her mother's partially wrecked home in Michigan's Pavilion Township, about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit. Inside the box were her grandmother's ashes. Being able to recover the most cherished of items offered Smith a rare moment of relief amid the storm's devastation.\n\n\"Finding this box is the best thing that's happened to me these past 24 hours,\" she said. \"The main thing we were all worried about was my grandma's ashes.\"\n\nHer parents and brother were injured during the storm. Her brother suffered a broken pelvis and broken back, but he and other victims all survived, Smith added.\n\n\"I have thanked God probably a billion times since this happened yesterday,\" she said. \"My kids are healthy and good. We just gotta make back up what we lost.\"\n\nIn southern Indiana, the National Weather Service confirmed a tornado with a preliminary EF-0 rating and 85 mph (137 kph) winds touched down early Wednesday, damaging homes in a subdivision north of the city of Sellersburg, located about 12 miles (19 kilometers) north of Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe Clark County Emergency Management Agency said the storm damaged 24 structures.\n\nCandice Holmes, a resident of the Lewis & Clark subdivision north of Sellersburg, said she, her husband and son sought shelter in their bathroom when they heard the approaching storm and \"the wind just picked up all at once.\"\n\n\"My husband and my son stepped outside, opened the door and they slammed the door and ran back to the bathroom. And they held the bathroom door shut, as it came through,\" Holmes told WDRB-TV. \"It was over as soon as it started, but it was definitely a scary moment. And I'm glad we're alive.\"\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nA National Weather Service team also was headed to Hot Springs, Arkansas, to survey damage and determine the strength of a tornado that hit early Wednesday morning, forecaster Tabitha Clarke said.\n\nThe tornado damaged some homes, uprooted trees and downed power lines. There were no immediate reports of injuries from the tornado, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn Portage, Michigan, about 50 people temporarily were trapped inside a damaged FedEx facility because of downed power lines. More than a dozen homes were destroyed in a mobile home park in adjacent Pavilion Township and 16 people were injured, said Kalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" Fuller said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nPower was knocked out to more than 20,000 people.\n\n\"We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nTravis Wycoff ventured out Tuesday night after seeing on radar that a tornado had touched down in the Portage area. About five minutes later, he came upon the aftermath.\n\n\"There were a lot of people running through the streets trying to find people and their pets,\" Wycoff said. \"It was just a lot of chaos.\"\n\nWycoff said he helped an elderly couple out of their partially collapsed home and also freed a service dog from a home whose owner was at work.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-05-349882953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:21:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:21:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:19:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/international/2932932-three-people-die-as-storms-sweep-through-eastern-us", "title": "Three people die as storms sweep through eastern US", "body": "At least three people were killed on Wednesday after strong storms swept through the North Carolina, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky and Tennessee regions of the US.\n\nAt least three people were killed on Wednesday after strong storms swept through the North Carolina, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky and Tennessee regions of the US, causing intense rain, winds and hail in some areas, The New York Times reported. People experienced severe weather a day after widespread storms tore through the Midwest and tornadoes swept through Michigan.\n\nOne person was killed after a tree fell on a vehicle in Claiborne County in northeast Tennessee as storms swept through the area around 10 am (local time), according to the county's office of emergency management. According to officials in North Carolina, there was one storm-related death in Gaston County. One person died in Maury County, Tennessee, on Wednesday after a \"large and destructive\" tornado was spotted near Springhill and the storm hit near Columbia, according to The New York Times report.\n\nRita Thompson, a spokeswoman for Maury Regional Health, a hospital in Columbia, confirmed the death. Pat Woodmansee, the assistant director of the county's emergency management agency, said that the storm left a trail of debris and people trapped in damaged homes. Rita Thompson said people were taken to hospital for treatment of injuries, that were not life-threatening and a fourth was in serious condition\n\nAs storms continued to sweep through the Midwest for third day and moved into the Eastern US on Wednesday evening, the National Weather Service issued tornado warnings in cities like Alabama, Illinois, Missouri, Kentucky and Tennessee. The Weather Service issued a tornado warning in Williamson County in southern Illinois after a \"confirmed large and extremely dangerous tornado\" was spotted on Wednesday afternoon. On Wednesday evening, over 40,000 customers were without power in Tennessee, The New York Times reported, citing Poweroutage.us.\n\nA tornado was confirmed in Huntsville, Alabama, on Wednesday night. According to the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Centre, about 21 million people were under either an enhanced or moderate risk of severe weather -- the third and fourth levels of intensity, out of five on Wednesday, The New York Times reported. On Wednesday, the National Weather Service office in Nashville in a post on X stated, \"Don't let your guard down!\" It added, \"We're in the 'lull' right now before the main line tonight. Our environment is very unstable so any storm that develops ahead of the line this afternoon could turn strong to severe very fast.\"\n\nMore than 20 million people in Kentucky, Missouri, Oklahoma, Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Indiana and Texas were under a tornado watch on Wednesday night. The most intense storms were expected to hit a corridor in cities of Nashville and Clarksville, Tennessee. Meanwhile, about 17 million people from Texas to North Carolina, including the cities of Memphis, St.Louis and Little Rock, face an enhanced risk of severe weather.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Missouri after heavy rains. According to forecasters, flooding had already been reported in cities like Cole Camp and Lincoln in Missouri and could spread to small creeks, streams, highways and other low-lying areas. Over the past two days, nearly 50 tornadoes were reported from Oklahoma to Ohio, as severe storms wrought damage throughout the Midwest. The storms brought strong winds and caused power outages.\n\nAccording to officials, tornadoes damaged nearly 200 mobile homes and winds were so strong that they lifted some homes away in Kalamazoo, in southern Michigan. The authorities said at least 16 people were injured, The New York Times reported. About 50 workers were rescued from a FedEx depot centre in Kalamazoo County as they were trapped inside after a tornado wrecked the building. The authorities in Oklahoma said a tornado caused widespread destruction on Monday, killing one person in Barnsdall, and damaging up to 40 homes in the small town. (WRDW/WAGT) - The CSRA saw a little bit of damage as a thunderstorm moved through the region Thursday morning.\n\nA tree was reported down along Kennedy Road just north of McCormick, and a power line was down along Confederate Drive near Lake Thurmond in Modoc.\n\nTwo lanes of Highway 421 were flooded near Howlandville Road in Warrenville, according to a storm spotter.\n\nIt came during a FIRST ALERT that was issued through early Friday for multiple rounds of storms.\n\nStrong thunderstorm gusts up to 60 mph and large hail are the primary concerns, but an isolated tornado can't be ruled out.\n\nSevere weather was considered most likely Thursday morning, but there will be multiple rounds including a third Friday morning.\n\nTo our west in Georgia, the heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour.\n\nThe Atlanta airport reported hundreds of delays Thursday morning.\n\nOvernight severe weather caused significant damage on Ellington Road at Old Highway 5 in Ellijay. The area was under a tornado warning late Wednesday, but it's unclear whether the damage was caused by an actual tornado.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. One person died in Maury County, Tennessee, on Wednesday after a \"large and destructive\" tornado was spotted near Springhill and the storm hit near Columbia, according to The New York Times report.\n\nAlso Read | Pakistan: PTI Chief Imran Khan Refuses To Apologise Over May 9 Protests.\n\nRita Thompson, a spokeswoman for Maury Regional Health, a hospital in Columbia, confirmed the death. Pat Woodmansee, the assistant director of the county's emergency management agency, said that the storm left a trail of debris and people trapped in damaged homes.\n\nRita Thompson said people were taken to hospital for treatment of injuries, that were not life-threatening and a fourth was in serious condition\n\nAs storms continued to sweep through the Midwest for third day and moved into the Eastern US on Wednesday evening, the National Weather Service issued tornado warnings in cities like Alabama, Illinois, Missouri, Kentucky and Tennessee.\n\nThe Weather Service issued a tornado warning in Williamson County in southern Illinois after a \"confirmed large and extremely dangerous tornado\" was spotted on Wednesday afternoon. On Wednesday evening, over 40,000 customers were without power in Tennessee, The New York Times reported, citing Poweroutage.us.\n\nA tornado was confirmed in Huntsville, Alabama, on Wednesday night. According to the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Centre, about 21 million people were under either an enhanced or moderate risk of severe weather -- the third and fourth levels of intensity, out of five on Wednesday, The New York Times reported.\n\nOn Wednesday, the National Weather Service office in Nashville in a post on X stated, \"Don't let your guard down!\" It added, \"We're in the 'lull' right now before the main line tonight. Our environment is very unstable so any storm that develops ahead of the line this afternoon could turn strong to severe very fast.\"\n\nMore than 20 million people in Kentucky, Missouri, Oklahoma, Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Indiana and Texas were under a tornado watch on Wednesday night. The most intense storms were expected to hit a corridor in cities of Nashville and Clarksville, Tennessee.\n\nMeanwhile, about 17 million people from Texas to North Carolina, including the cities of Memphis, St.Louis and Little Rock, face an enhanced risk of severe weather.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Missouri after heavy rains. According to forecasters, flooding had already been reported in cities like Cole Camp and Lincoln in Missouri and could spread to small creeks, streams, highways and other low-lying areas.\n\nOver the past two days, nearly 50 tornadoes were reported from Oklahoma to Ohio, as severe storms wrought damage throughout the Midwest. The storms brought strong winds and caused power outages.\n\nAccording to officials, tornadoes damaged nearly 200 mobile homes and winds were so strong that they lifted some homes away in Kalamazoo, in southern Michigan. The authorities said at least 16 people were injured, The New York Times reported.\n\nAbout 50 workers were rescued from a FedEx depot centre in Kalamazoo County as they were trapped inside after a tornado wrecked the building. The authorities in Oklahoma said a tornado caused widespread destruction on Monday, killing one person in Barnsdall, and damaging up to 40 homes in the small town. {"uri": "8119055733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:39:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:39:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:39:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.local3news.com/local-news/georgia/storms-threaten-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-punches-through-the-us/article_4304f5c1-e9d7-5327-8f7d-de626c0de97f.html", "title": "Storms threaten the South as a week of deadly weather punches through the US", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could wash over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued tornado watches Thursday for parts of Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and Tennessee. An enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms with very large hail was forecast for parts of eastern Texas.\n\nStorms left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where the weather service said a tornado had likely touched down.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nThunderstorms with torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-350360099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:36:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:36:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:16:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/article_093dd00b-d612-5930-8bf0-9e0a9cee4220.html", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. (WOOD) -- The National Weather Service will be in southwest Michigan on Wednesday to evaluate the strength of Tuesday's tornadoes.\n\nThe Portage area in Kalamazoo County and Centreville in St. Joseph County bore the brunt of the damage from Tuesday's storms.\n\nThe Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office said around 15 to 17 homes at the Pavilion Estates, a mobile home park in the Portage area, were completely destroyed. One mobile home was flipped into the road and needed to be moved.\n\nAnother had fallen into different mobile home.\n\nFuller said injuries at the mobile home park likely were lessened because some residents were aware a likely tornado was headed their way. They took action to take cover or leave.\n\nFuller gave an update on the community's emergency response during a press conference late Tuesday.\n\nFive Kalamazoo Metro buses responded to Pavilion Estates to help shuttle residents out of the area, Fuller said. The American Red Cross is helping with temporary shelter.\n\nAt the FedEx building on Portage Road, there were reports of up to 50 people trapped inside the building at one point. Those people eventually made it out and, according to a FedEx statement released to WWMT, there were no serious injuries.\n\nFuller described the inter-agency cooperation as a \"huge success\" in responding to the emergency.\n\nFor more coverage of Tuesday night's tornadoes, visit mlive.com/topic/portage-tornado/.", "source": {"uri": "mlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "mlive"}, {"uri": "8119301445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:21:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:21:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:21:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://journalnow.com/news/state/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/article_8f912c35-4454-5804-89f7-bf41790dc1d1.html", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "Storm damaged houses are seen along Blackburn Lane, Thursday, May 9, 2024, in Columbia, Tenn. Severe storms tore through the central and southeast U.S., Wednesday, spawning damaging tornadoes, producing massive hail, and killing two people in Tennessee.\n\nBy KRISTIN M. HALL and GEORGE WALKER IV - Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8119093521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:04:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:04:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:03:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://journalnow.com/news/state/storms-threaten-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-punches-through-the-us/article_8f912c35-4454-5804-89f7-bf41790dc1d1.html", "title": "Storms threaten the South as a week of deadly weather punches through the US", "body": "A wheelbarrow is seen lodged in a damaged tree after a tornado leveled dozens of homes near Omaha. Neb. on Friday, April 26, 2024.\n\nBy GEORGE WALKER IV, JOEY CAPPELLETTI and ED WHITE - Associated Press\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Forecasters warned a wave of dangerous storms in the U.S. could wash over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued tornado watches Thursday for parts of Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and Tennessee. An enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms with very large hail was forecast for parts of eastern Texas.\n\nStorms left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where the weather service said a tornado had likely touched down.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nThunderstorms with torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. At least four people have died since Monday. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where the weather service said a tornado had likely touched down.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nThunderstorms with torrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. {"uri": "8116778701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:23:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:23:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:22:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/portage-michigan-tornado-destroyed-mobile-060103196.html", "title": "Portage, Michigan tornado destroyed mobile homes, injured about 12", "body": "PAVILION TOWNSHIP -- Around a dozen residents of Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Community in Pavilion Township on the outskirts of Portage were injured when a tornado ripped through their community Tuesday.\n\nAccording to multiple neighbors of the hardest hit homes, at least one woman was trapped inside her decimated home and later rescued and taken to the hospital.\n\nNeighbors said her husband, who was outside when the tornado touched down Tuesday evening, was also injured and transported by paramedics to a nearby hospital with minor injuries. The identities of the two were not immediately available.\n\nOfficials were still assessing damages late into Tuesday evening, but reported no fatalities.\n\nNick Armold, director of public safety for the city of Portage, said emergency personnel would work through Tuesday night to get a full accounting of residents and ensure no one is still trapped inside a home.\n\nMore: Tornadoes reported in west Michigan; multiple buildings in Portage damaged: Live updates\n\nJackie Knerr, a 30-year resident of the mobile home community, had just sat down at her dinner table to eat supper when the tornado hit.\n\n\"It sounded like a lot of debris hitting the house and I thought all the windows on the north side of my house would be damaged,\" Knerr said. \"Fortunately, I only have minor damage.\"\n\nHer neighbor, Larry Allgaier, was down the road at a nearby senior center playing pickleball when the tornado hit. He sheltered in place there.\n\nAllgaier's return home proved difficult as he navigated downed power lines, large trees blocking a main entrance to the community and ruptured natural gas lines.\n\n\"I was hoping for the best, but I had heard that the new FedEx building was hit badly and I knew that was only a mile from the trailer park,\" Allgaier said.\n\nSix doors down, Allgaier's neighbor's home was thrown 30 feet from its foundation and debris impaled a parked car.\n\nAs firefighters worked with utility workers to seal off the natural gas lines, community members began the long process of cleanup.\n\nTerry Zeiler, who lives six miles away, brought in heavy equipment from home and began working to clear roadways around the trailer park. Nobody had to ask him.\n\nSubscribe Now: For all the latest local developments, breaking news and high school sports content.\n\n\"It's just the right thing to do,\" Zeiler said. \"Growing up, we had a sense of community here. Everyone looked out for their neighbors and their community. I'm just doing my part.\"\n\nWhile many residents left the mobile home community to stay overnight with friends and family, others sought out one of two emergency shelters opened by the city of Portage.\n\nArmold, the public safety director, said the city is opening a hotline Wednesday morning for residents affected to ask questions about storm cleanup, utility concerns, etc. The number for the hotline was not available as of Tuesday evening.\n\n\"We're pretty fortunate that, as of right now, we have no reported serious injuries or fatalities,\" Armold said late Tuesday evening.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for several counties in Southwest Michigan following the storm. Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch, and Cass counties were included, according to a release from the governor's office.\n\n-- Contact Reporter Corey Murray at cmurray@hillsdale.net or follow him on X, {"uri": "8119298042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:19:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:19:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:18:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.dailypress.com/2024/05/09/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on", "body": "By George Walker IV | Associated Press, JOEY CAPPELLETTI | The Associated Press and Ed White | Associated Press\n\nBy KRISTIN M. HALL and GEORGE WALKER IV (Associated Press)\n\nCOLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- A wave of dangerous storms began washing over parts of the South early Thursday, a day after severe weather with damaging tornadoes and large hail killed at least three people in the region.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays Thursday morning. Tornado warnings were issued for parts of Tennessee and Alabama.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and, now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nStorms had already left more than a quarter-million customers without power Thursday in North Carolina, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama and Missouri, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nA storm Wednesday in northeastern Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, the Maury County seat, where officials said a tornado had likely touched down and homes were blown off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nBooth said he was told it would be a while before his power was restored. One neighbor, he said, lost all trees except one that would have destroyed his house: \"So that guy is blessed.\"\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in several Tennessee counties. Some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville. The Federal Aviation Administration issued a temporary ground stop at Nashville's main airport, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nIn North Carolina, a state of emergency was declared Wednesday night for Gaston County, west of Charlotte, after a storm that toppled power lines and trees, including one that landed on a car. One person in the car was killed, and another was taken to a hospital, officials said.\n\nThe storms followed heavy rain, strong winds, hail and tornadoes in parts of the central U.S. on Monday, including a twister that ripped through an Oklahoma town and killed one person. On Tuesday, the Midwest took the brunt of the bad weather. Tornadoes touched down in parts of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to the weather service.\n\nMichigan's Kalamazoo area was hard hit as a FedEx facility was ripped apart, with downed power lines trapping about 50 people.\n\nTornadoes were also confirmed near Pittsburgh, in central Arkansas and in northern West Virginia. The West Virginia twister was at least the 11th tornado this year in the state, which sees two tornadoes in an average year.\n\nCappelletti and White reported from Detroit. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Jeff Amy, Joey Cappelletti, Ed White, Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy, Alexa St. John, Adrian Sainz, John Raby and Lisa Baumann.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. More than 30,000 customers were still without power in Michigan, and 18,000 in Arkansas, on Wednesday morning, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nAmong the hardest hit counties was Kalamazoo, in southern Michigan, where officials said that tornadoes damaged nearly 200 mobile homes and winds were so strong that they lifted some homes away. At least 16 people were injured, the authorities said, though none seriously.\n\nAbout 50 workers were rescued from a FedEx depot center in Kalamazoo County after a tornado wrecked the building and stranded them inside. The authorities in Oklahoma said a tornado that was up to two miles wide caused widespread destruction on Monday, killing one person in Barnsdall, and damaging up to 40 homes in the small {"uri": "8117171089", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:31:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:31:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:31:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/news/kalamazoo/2024/05/13-photos-from-reported-tornadoes-in-kalamazoo-county.html", "title": "16 photos from reported tornadoes in Kalamazoo County", "body": "KALAMAZOO COUNTY, MI -- A pair of reported tornadoes swept through Kalamazoo County Tuesday evening, May 7, wreaking havoc on homes, businesses and more.\n\nThe storms rolled through around 6 p.m. and 7 p.m., causing thousands to lose power. Some of the heaviest damage was concentrated around Westnedge Avenue, Centre Avenue and Oakland Drive, according to Portage city officials.\n\nThe FedEx building at 6701 Portage Road sustained a direct hit from one of the reported tornadoes. The roof of the building caved in, leaving the interior exposed. After the storm passed, 50 employees were trapped inside as crews worked to remove dangerous wires so rescue efforts could commence. First responders eventually helped them all out of the building, Tuesday night.\n\nMORE: Trapped workers at FedEx building escape after reported tornado\n\nAnother spot with major damage was Pavilion Estates Mobile Home Park, 6830 East N Ave. in Pavilion Township, just east of Portage. About 17 of the homes were totally demolished and 173 had some degree of damage, according to the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office.\n\nSee the immediate aftermath of the storms in the 16 photos, below.\n\nDown the road from the FedEx building, the reported tornado decimated trees along Romence Road Parkway and Lovers Lane. The storm caused a gas main to rupture and downed multiple power lines.\n\nPavilion Estates, a mobile home park at 6830 East N. Ave., sustained significant damage. Multiple homes were destroyed.\n\nResidents evacuated Pavilion Estates and convened at a nearby gas station. They were transported to shelters set up for those displaced by the storm.\n\nFarm buildings near Pavilion Estates also sustained damage.\n\nSeveral homes on Lovers Lane and Romence Road sustained significant damage. Two homes almost leveled by fallen trees were both unoccupied at the time of the storm.\n\nJeff Heath, a resident on Lovers Lane, was in his home when the storm hit. A tree came through his roof, but he and his six cats didn't sustain serious injuries.\n\nHeath's neighbor was trapped in her home following the storms. Several trees had gone through her roof. Neighbors helped her get out of the house.\n\nSeveral cars were trapped on Romence Road Parkway by fallen trees as the storm came through.\n\nMany Portage-based businesses were affected by the storms. Several industrial locations were in the vicinity of the storm, including Stryker and Pfizer.\n\nCentre Avenue in Portage also sustained serious damage, as seen in this photo of a strip mall at Centre Avenue and Oakland Drive.\n\nFirst responders were on scene at Pavilion Estates shortly after impact. All occupants of that building are alive and accounted for, according to the company.\n\nElsewhere, multiple homes have been damaged in places like Fairhaven, West Virginia; Irondale, Ohio, Charloe, Ohio; and Garland County, Arkansas.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, a new batch of energy will kick off storms in mid-Missouri and St. Louis and there is a likelihood that Wednesday could be the third day of a multi-day tornado outbreak, the fourth such event in a just the span of a month.\n\nThe energy from this storm will likely create numerous severe thunderstorms over a widespread area throughout the afternoon and evening hours from Texas to the Ozarks to the Ohio River Valley to the Mid-Atlantic.\n\nThere is a moderate risk -- 4 out of 5 on the severe scale -- for an area from just east of Springfield, Missouri to Nashville, Tennessee with strong tornadoes possible here. They are also possible outside of this area with an enhanced risk of 3 out of 5, but this moderate risk is mainly for the increased risk for giant hail and destructive winds.\n\nThe moderate risk includes the city of Mayfield, Kentucky -- the site of the December 2021 deadly tornado with 57 deaths -- the deadliest since Joplin, Missouri in 2011. No other tornado has had as many deaths since 2021.\n\nMajor metros in the path of potentially damaging storms today include St. Louis, Cincinnati, Louisville, Nashville, Memphis, Springfield in It's maximum width was 300 yards.\n\nThe tornado first touched ground near 10th Street and R Avenue in Texas Township at 5:55 p.m., moving northeast and crossing U.S. 131. It then crossed Centre Avenue and Oakland Drive, continuing over Westnedge Avenue and Schuring Road.\n\nIt passed over the FedEx building near Stryker's campus on Portage Road before traveling over the southern end of the Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International Airport and Sprinkle Road.\n\nIt cut into Pavilion Township, where it destroyed 17 mobile homes and damaged 173, before ending near East N Avenue and 31st Street at 6:17 p.m.\n\nNo one was killed in the tornado, but more than 100 families have been displaced from their homes, said Portage Mayor Patricia Randall. The Red Cross is operating a shelter at 5550 Oakland Drive for those impacted by damage to their homes or loss of power.\n\nRELATED: Sheriff shares positive message after tornado causes 'mass destruction'\n\nAbout 30,000 Consumers Energy customers were without power following the storm, Vice President of Operations Chris Laird said. Crews worked around the clock to restore the majority of power by midnight. The remaining 4.9% of Portage customers without power are likely in the hardest hit areas.\n\nA second reported tornado in Portage on Tuesday hasn't been confirmed yet by the National Weather {"uri": "8118405604", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "03:41:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T03:41:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:41:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.clickondetroit.com/weather/2024/05/09/officials-confirm-4-tornadoes-hit-michigan-heres-where-and-how-strong-they-were/", "title": "Officials confirm 4 tornadoes hit Michigan -- here's where and how strong they were", "body": "4Warn Weather - The power of Tuesday's storms in Southwest Michigan is becoming clearer as teams survey the damage in hard-hit communities.\n\nCrews from the National Weather Service and emergency management offices assessed damage across the region on Wednesday, but surveys were expected to continue into Thursday.\n\nAs of Thursday evening, the National Weather Service had confirmed four Michigan tornadoes spawned by severe storms on May 7.\n\nDowagiac Tornado\n\nStorms started leaving their mark on the state in the afternoon. An EF1 tornado touched down by the Dowagiac Municipal Airport and moved northeast for nearly 12 miles. It lifted near the border of Cass and Van Buren counties about 27 minutes later. At its strongest, it had winds estimated at 95 mph. At its widest, it was 950 yards or nearly the length of eight football fields. Trees took the brunt of the damage.\n\nUnion City Tornado\n\nA brief EF1 touched down at 6:07 p.m. southwest of Union City in Branch County. It was on the ground for just one mile and one minute but destroyed a machine shed and reached winds of 95 mph.\n\nSt. Joseph and Branch Counties Tornado\n\nThe survey of a third and larger tornado was expected to continue into Thursday. Preliminary information from the National Weather Service indicates that it touched down in St. Joseph County and traveled into Branch County during the early evening. The agency said it would release the rating and path of the tornado after fully assessing the damage, but some of the damage was said to be consistent with a strong tornado.\n\nPortage Tornado\n\nA strong EF2, which packed winds as high as 135 mph, caused considerable damage in Portage. Meteorologists said it formed at 5:55 p.m. west of US-131 and traveled east-northeast for about 11 miles. It struck two mobile home parks and multiple apartment complexes, ripped the roof off of a FedEx building, and snapped and uprooted hundreds of trees. No one was reported hurt.\n\nApart from the tornadoes, thunderstorms brought damaging straight-line winds to Southwest Michigan and Southeast Michigan.\n\nIn Southeast Michigan, tornadoes are most A suspected tornado downed a grain silo in Butler County, blocking part of a road, WLWT Channel 5 reports.\n\nWCPO Channel 9 reports that radar confirmed two tornadoes in Warren County. However, the National Weather Service has not yet confirmed any tornadoes.\n\nThe National Weather Service did issue multiple tornado warnings and watches Tuesday night as severe weather moved through the southern and central portions of Ohio. There have been no reports of injuries in Ohio from the storms.\n\nIn southern Michigan, suspected tornadoes collapsed part of a FedEx facility in Portage, trapping several workers because of downed power lines, mlive.com reports. Areas of Rockford, Loves Park and Machesney Park saw flash flooding Tuesday.\n\nA barn collapsed in Harvard, Illinois, Tuesday afternoon as severe storms and high winds passed through the region. Four animals were killed. Dozens of animals were saved. No people were injured.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service, a survey team is on its way to Harvard to determine if it was a tornado or straight-line winds that caused a barn to collapse.\n\nMultiple reported tornadoes caused extensive damage in Michigan and Oklahoma this week. Homes and businesses were destroyed. A FedEx facility in Portage, Michigan, was heavily damaged. About a dozen people were injured in a mobile home park in Kalamazoo County.\n\nOne person was killed and several other injured in Barnsdall, Oklahoma Monday night when a tornado caused widespread damage.\n\nDozens of tornadoes were reported across the Midwest Monday and Tuesday.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service, severe storms are possible Wednesday and Thursday for central and southern Illinois as well as the eastern Great Plains with possible tornado winds and hail. More storms, but not as severe, are possible for the Great Lakes region.\n\nChris Green is a Rockford Register Star general assignment reporter. Weather experts believe a tornado touched down in the city about 40 miles south of Nashville.\n\nAnd in North Carolina, the storms knocked a tree onto a car with two people in it, authorities said. One of the occupants was killed and the other was hospitalized after the incident in Gaston County, just west of Charlotte.\n\nMore than 130,000 people in the two states still didn't have power as of Thursday morning, according to Poweroutage.us. The storms also knocked out power and brought devastation to parts of Alabama and Georgia.\n\nA tornado touched down in Henagar, Ala., late Wednesday, injuring at least two people and trapping dozens of others in their homes about 40 miles east of Huntsville, according to CBS News.\n\nSeveral school districts northeast of Atlanta canceled classes Thursday due to storm damage, including reports of trees falling on houses.\n\nThe severe weather was expected to continue Thursday, with tornado watches in effect throughout vast portions of Alabama and Georgia, as well as parts of South Carolina.\n\nStorm systems have wreaked havoc across the Great Plains, Midwest and South all week. On Monday, a tornado killed one person in the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, Okla. All occupants of that building are alive and accounted for, according to the company.\n\nElsewhere, multiple homes have been damaged in places like Fairhaven, West Virginia; Irondale, Ohio, Charloe, Ohio; and Garland County, Arkansas.\n\nThere is a Flood Warning for the Cincinnati, Ohio, area until 10 a.m. ET on Wednesday where up to 3 inches of rain fell, closing numerous roads in the area as law enforcement reports ongoing flooding.\n\nStorms are expected to continue Wednesday morning even though a Tornado Watch in parts of Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi and Illinois is set to expire at 7 a.m. ET.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, a new batch of energy will kick off storms in mid-Missouri and St. Louis and there is a likelihood that Wednesday could be the third day of a multi-day tornado outbreak, the fourth such event in a just the span of a month.\n\nThe energy from this storm will likely create numerous severe thunderstorms over a widespread area throughout the afternoon and evening hours from Texas to the Ozarks to the Ohio River Valley to the Mid-Atlantic.\n\nThere is a moderate risk -- 4 out of 5 on the severe scale -- for an area from just east of Springfield, Missouri to Nashville, Tennessee with strong tornadoes possible there. They are also possible outside of this area with an enhanced risk of 3 out of 5, but this moderate risk is mainly for the increased risk for giant hail and destructive winds.\n\nThe moderate risk includes the city of Mayfield, Kentucky -- the site of the December 2021 deadly tornado with 57 deaths -- the deadliest since Joplin, Missouri in 2011. No other tornado has had as many deaths since 2021.\n\nMajor metros in the path of potentially damaging storms Wednesday include St. Louis, Cincinnati, Louisville, Nashville, Memphis, Springfield in {"uri": "8116861757", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "07:26:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T07:26:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:21:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://rsoe-edis.org/eventList/details/620140/0", "title": "Severe weather - United States - Chicago weather: 4 animals die in north suburban barn collapse, other severe storm damage reported", "body": "Strong thunderstorms raced through the Chicago area Tuesday afternoon, leaving some damage in their wake.\n\nA first round of storms began moving in to the western part of the Chicago area at 6:30 a.m., and then moved into the city later in the morning, bringing rain and winds.\n\nAround 8 a.m., ground stops were issued at both O'Hare and Midway airports due to the weather. The ground stops were lifted by around 9:30 a.m.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center upgraded the risk for much of the area late Tuesday morning. Much of the Chicago area was at a Level 2 risk and a 5% tornado risk, with Northwest Indiana at a Level 3 risk and a 10% tornado risk.\n\nABC7 meteorologist Larry Mowry said storms began flaring to the west and the south of the Chicago area by 12:30 p.m., moving northeast at 50 miles per hour.\n\nBetween 1:30 and 6 p.m. strong storms brought with them a threat of tornadoes. The highest tornado threat was to the southeast of the city, especially in Northwest Indiana.\n\nOn Chicago's Far South Side, the inbound lanes of I-57 at Parnell Avenue were blocked for a time by flooding, the Illinois Department of Transportation said. All lanes were back open by about 5 p.m.\n\nIllinois State Police said three cars were stuck in flooded waters at 99th Street on the same stretch of inbound I-57, but no other issues were reported.\n\nStorm damage reported in suburbs; barn collapses in Harvard, Ill.\n\nA storm tore through Chicago's southwest suburbs, dunking buckets of quarter sized hail over Palos Heights.\n\n\"I got skylights on the house and it was just cracking against the glass there. It was pretty loud,\" said Palos Heights resident Scott Allen.\n\nThe fast-moving storms left damage in their wake, especially from the heavy downpour of large hail. There were also reports of some road flooding in Joliet and in Orland Park, where Cook County officials said some roads were closed.\n\nMost storms lasted less than half an hour, sometimes even less than 10 minutes, as they raced through, but they brought intense downpours of large hail in areas like Palos Heights. The hail ripped down the leaves of newly-bloomed trees, and the strong winds in some cases knocked down branches.\n\nSome trees were uprooted, and backyard equipment like trampolines twisted and overturned, but more serious damage and power outages were not reported.\n\nIn McHenry County, near Harvard, Ill., the storms apparently caused a barn to collapse and knocked over a large tree at the roots. It was not known how many animals, who lived on the lower level of the two-story, century-old barn, were inside when it collapsed, but the way it did created a void on the lower level that allowed nearly all the animals inside to survive. Harvard fire officials said firefighters were able to rescue 24 sheep, 18 goats, one cow, and multiple chickens and ducks.\n\n\"Just debris on top of them. They found spaces within the collapse they were kind of hiding under,\" Harvard Fire Department Chief John Kimmel. \"Straight-line winds is what we're assuming, because there was debris several hundred yards away.\"\n\nFour animals were confirmed to have died in the collapse, and two more are unaccounted for. No human injuries were reported.\n\n\"It started hailing really hard. It got dark and within a minute it was gone,\" said neighbor Mary Stefely.\n\nThere were reports of inch to inch-and-a-half-sized hail in the south suburbs, which is roughly the size of a ping pong ball.\n\nStorm downs large tree in Porter, Indiana\n\nMeanwhile, as the power started to buzz back to life in Porter, Indiana on Tuesday evening, the spotty extent of the most severe damage became clear. The afternoon spring storm there was short and mighty.\n\n\"We're just getting ready to panic to go to the basement and it stopped so fast. But the damage had been done,\" said Porter resident Joanne Tubbs.\n\nIn the silence of the storm's wake, Tubbs cautiously emerged from her home, carefully turning the corner and surveying the lot. A towering tree, easily four stories tall, had collapsed, merely clipping the gutters and a fraction of the roof.\n\n\"When I looked out the window, I just saw this branch and then I come out and I see all this, and it kept going, and I could not believe it. It's scary,\" Tubbs said. \"God was so good. It went right between the house and the garage.\"\n\nThe combination of the rain-saturated ground and high-force winds were enough for the decades-old tangled tree root system to give way, taking a good 6-foot chunk with it and leaving a steep hole behind.\n\nTornadoes leave damage behind in Portage, Michigan\n\nAnd in Michigan, the rain and winds whipped violently as multiple tornadoes hit the Portage area on Tuesday.\n\nA FedEx shipping center sustained heavy damage, with much of the roof torn off, and part of the exterior wall collapsed. Emergency officials said an estimated 50 people were trapped inside.\n\nFedEx later told ABC News that all of their team members are safe and accounted for and no serious injuries were reported.\n\nElsewhere in that area, others were pinned in by downed power lines. Residents were left shaken by the damage, but the mayor of Portage said there were no injuries on Tuesday night.\n\n\"Listen, just, and don't think it won't happen here, but it can happen anywhere to anybody. In our community, they're all older people and they all stayed in their homes,\" one resident said.\n\nWith debris across the region, the Portage Department of Public Safety asked people to stay away.\n\nOne man expressed gratitude in the face of destruction.\n\n\"We're not in the position of these people here. Everything is gone. At least we can go in, take things out, wait for the insurance,\" he said.\n\nMore than 21,000 people in the Portage area lost their power.", "source": {"uri": "rsoe-edis.org", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-05-349568941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:51:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:51:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:44:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://eu.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2024/05/08/tornado-damage-residents-workers-cleanup-portage/73618692007/", "title": "Community repairs damage after tornadoes rip through west Michigan town", "body": "Severe damage was reported in Portage, Michigan, less than a day after tornadoes tore through communities in Oklahoma.\n\nHuddled together in basements and even a bathtub, families took cover in west Michigan on Tuesday night as tornadoes raged outside.\n\nResidents sheltered in place, following alerts and sirens advising them to take cover. Several residents told the Free Press they did their best to get to safety before coming out to assess the damage.\n\nCody Capp, whose home doesn't have a basement, took refuge in his bathtub.\n\nThe 27-year-old factory worker lives in a Portage neighborhood with fallen trees and power lines. He said he appreciated the swift community response to clear the neighborhood.\n\n\"After the storm was over, everybody came out here and worked together to clear everything,\" Capp said. \"It was really nice to see everybody out and helping each other.\"\n\nOn Wednesday evening, National Weather Service offices confirmed that three tornadoes touched down in Michigan. One was in Portage. A second touched down in Union City, in Branch County and Centerville, in St. Joseph County, said Senior Meteorologist Nathan Marsili.\n\nHe said a third touched down in Barrien and Cass counties.\n\nThere were no deaths or major injuries from the tornadoes, the Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office said in a news conference Wednesday.\n\nThe severe weather knocked down trees and power lines in neighborhoods, over railroad tracks and at busy intersections, destroying local businesses and damaging homes and neighborhoods. Power outages caused significant traffic delays in Portage, with crews working to repair traffic signals at intersections.\n\nSome residents said power had returned by Wednesday morning, while others were still without power by midafternoon. Detroit Free Press reporters saw crews clearing debris from fallen trees and restoring power to traffic intersections Wednesday afternoon.\n\nMelissa Emmons, 58, lives in Portage with her husband and five Great Danes. Her home and yard had severe damage, with downed trees and power lines in their yard and driveway, and blocking the street in front of their home.\n\n\"We didn't have a whole lot of time to think about it,\" Emmons said. \"I was vacuuming, trying to keep an eye on the TV and then I see that it was confirmed touchdown headed toward I-94 so I freaked out a little bit.\"\n\nEmmons, who grew up abroad while her father served in the U.S. Air Force, said Tuesday's tornadoes were worse than living through earthquakes in Japan when she was young.\n\n\"I said, 'Wow, oh my God.' It looked like a war zone,\" Emmons said.\n\nSadpal Nimana owns a shopping center containing six businesses at the intersection of Centre Avenue and Oakland Drive in Portage. The structure is severely damaged, with the roof caved in over several stores, back walls gone and glass and debris scattered throughout the parking lot. Trees fell around nearby businesses and over a bus stop, the intersection's traffic light is out of power and signage for Nimana's strip and a nearby gas station are destroyed.\n\nThe shopping center will need to be demolished and rebuilt, Nimana said. The damage is a major loss to the community, leaving 35-40 employees out of work and residents without their local shops, he said.\n\n\"It was a livelihood for those businesses, convenience for some,\" Nimana said.\n\nNimana will now have to start over, drawing up architectural plans for a new structure, getting city approval and finding tenants. He also owns an automotive business strip mall nearby, which had less severe damage and will be repaired.\n\nJames Wilson, 74, of Portage, was at his property in South Haven watching news reports on television Tuesday evening and returned home Wednesday afternoon to assess the damage.\n\n\"All my trees are gone. I had a nice woods,\" Wilson said. \"It just devastated all of them and the neighbor's trees fell in my yard, that's what took out my barn, my 24-by-24 steel barn.\"", "source": {"uri": "freep.com", {"uri": "8119615933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:20:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:20:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:20:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.wdef.com/new-storms-pummel-the-south-as-a-week-of-deadly-weather-marches-on/", "title": "New storms pummel the South as a week of deadly weather marches on - WDEF", "body": "COLUMBIA, Tenn. (AP) -- Dangerous storms crashed over parts of the South on Thursday even as the region cleaned up from earlier severe weather that spawned apparent tornadoes, killed at least three people, and gravely injured a boy who was swept into a storm drain as he played in a flooded street.\n\nA heavy line of storms swept into Atlanta near the end of the morning rush hour. Busy hub airports in Atlanta and Charlotte, North Carolina, reported delays. The National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited an \"enhanced risk\" for severe weather from Texas to South Carolina.\n\nThe storms continue a streak of torrential rains and tornadoes this week from the Plains to the Midwest and now, the Southeast. At least four people have died since Monday. The weather comes on the heels of a stormy April in which the U.S. had 300 confirmed tornadoes, the second-most on record for the month and the most since 2011.\n\nNearly a quarter-million homes and businesses still lacked power Thursday in several Southern states after storms the night before, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nOne in Tennessee damaged homes, injured people, toppled power lines and trees, and killed a 22-year-old man in a car in Claiborne County, north of Knoxville, officials said. A second person was killed south of Nashville in Columbia, where officials said a likely tornado blew homes off their foundations.\n\nBob Booth had just gotten home to Columbia from Georgia and was sitting down to watch television when he heard a \"crazy racket.\"\n\n\"I get up and look out, and it was all hell breaking loose outside,\" Booth said. \"Then the top half of one of my trees goes down across the road.\"\n\nRetired pastor Walter Shell said he and his wife grabbed their two dogs and headed for the basement when his phone alerted him to a tornado.\n\n\"It missed where me and my wife were standing by about 4 inches. It went around,\" he said. \"It pays to pray, I can tell you.\"\n\nTorrential rains led to a flash flood emergency and water rescues northeast of Nashville, and the weather service issued a tornado emergency, its highest alert level, for nearby areas.\n\nA 10-year-old boy was seriously injured in Christiana, southeast of Nashville, when he got caught in a storm drain and swept under streets while playing with other children as adults cleared debris, his father, Rutherford County Schools Superintendent Jimmy Sullivan, posted on social media.\n\nThe boy, Asher, emerged in a drainage ditch and survived after being given CPR, \"but the damage is substantial,\" Sullivan posted on Facebook, asking for prayers. A vigil was planned for Thursday afternoon at the school district office.\n\n\"Asher needs a miracle,\" Sullivan wrote.\n\nSchools were closed Thursday in Rutherford and several other Tennessee counties. In Georgia, some districts north of Atlanta canceled in-person classes or delayed start times because of storm damage overnight that included fallen trees on houses and vehicles around Clarkesville. No injuries were reported there.\n\n\"We're just trying to clean up right now and wait for the next round,\" said Lynn Smith, director of the Habersham County Emergency Management Agency.", "source": All occupants of that building are alive and accounted for, according to the company.\n\nElsewhere, multiple homes have been damaged in places like Fairhaven, West Virginia; Irondale, Ohio, Charloe, Ohio; and Garland County, Arkansas.\n\nThere is a Flood Warning for the Cincinnati, Ohio, area until 10 a.m. ET on Wednesday where up to 3 inches of rain fell, closing numerous roads in the area as law enforcement reports ongoing flooding.\n\nStorms are expected to continue this morning even though a Tornado Watch in parts of Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi and Illinois is set to expire at 7 a.m. ET.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, a new batch of energy will kick off storms in mid-Missouri and St. Louis and there is a likelihood that Wednesday could be the third day of a multi-day tornado outbreak, the fourth such event in a just the span of a month.\n\nThe energy from this storm will likely create numerous severe thunderstorms over a widespread area throughout the afternoon and evening hours from Texas to the Ozarks to the Ohio River Valley to the Mid-Atlantic.\n\nThere is a moderate risk -- 4 out of 5 on the severe scale -- for an area from just east of Springfield, Missouri to Nashville, Tennessee with strong tornadoes possible here. (WOOD) -- Houses were torn from their foundations and overturned as a likely tornado ripped through the Sherwood area in Southwest Michigan Tuesday.\n\nA News 8 crew saw at least eight destroyed homes in the village in northwest Branch County and a path of damage tracking nearly 2 miles northeast toward Union City.\n\nLynn Burns told News 8 she was parked in her Chevrolet Silverado in front of her friend's house as the storm approached. They watched as the house was ripped away from its basement. Neither she nor her friends who were hiding in the basement were injured.\n\nHer relative, A.J. Burns, said he, his wife and two children took cover in the bathroom of their finished basement. He said he held the door closed, felling it shaking and debris hitting it like shrapnel. He and his family are OK.\n\nTheir home, however, sustained serious damage, with the upper level mostly destroyed. Their fifth-wheel camper was flipped over and tossed into their garage.\n\nNext door, a couple was in their Dodge Durango as the storm moved through. They said it went quiet, as though the tornado had sucked up the sound. A tree snapped and their prefabricated home was toppled over onto its side. They were not hurt.\n\nOn Wednesday, they used a hole in the roof to go inside and see what they could salvage.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a tornado emergency for Union City on Tuesday -- the first such alert ever in Michigan.\n\nThe storm left behind more damage in Portage, where another likely tornado ripped through.\n\nNo deaths have been reported as a result of the storm, though some people were injured.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Gov. Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch and Cass counties.
