another in St. Joseph and Branch counties; and a third near Dowagiac in Cass County, National Weather Service officials in Grand Rapids said early Wednesday.\n\nGovernor Gretchen Whitmer issued a state of emergency after at least 20 injuries were reported out of Kalamazoo County Tuesday night, including the destruction to 176 homes, a FedEx facility and damage to other buildings in Portage and in St. Joseph and Branch counties.\n\nSt. Clair County\n\nColony Marine, a boat dealer at 24530 Jefferson Avenue in St. Clair Shores, lost an exterior wall in the storm, exposing the boats stored inside.\n\nAlgonac resident Robin Stevens said in addition to Colony Marine's exterior wall, the neighbor's garage is also missing.\n\n\"It blew right through the front yard, took out a barn and a garage, yet did not knock the potted plants off the railing on the porch,\" Stevens said.\n\nMacomb County\n\nHarrison Township in Macomb County was one of the hardest hit metro Detroit communities on Tuesday.\n\nCoincidentally, this week is the 60th anniversary of the only F4 tornado to touch down in Macomb County's Chesterfield Township, according to a post by Macomb County Emergency Management. The tornado on May 8, 1964, was responsible for 13 fatalities -- the strongest in county record. \"This tornado touched down north of Mt. Clemens and moved across Chesterfield Township near the Lake St. Clair shoreline before entering Lake St. Clair southwest of New Baltimore,\" according to the post.\n\nHalf of the Lambrecht Marina, at 31300 North River Road, was blown away by Tuesday's storms, according WXYZ-TV (Channel 7).\n\nPhotographs posted Wednesday morning from the Macomb County News Scanner on X say DTE is assessing damage and working to restore power. that used to belong to Mears' grandmother - on Arney Road was turned on its side and destroyed.\n\nTheir belongings were scattered and mangled across the yard among overturned trees, dirt and debris.\n\nAs the storm on Tuesday approached Mears and his fianc\u00e9e dashed out to their car to take shelter as they don't have a basement.\n\nAs they watched, the tornado swept through, picking up the home and throwing it onto its side.\n\nMears returned to the house on Wednesday to try and salvage some of his belongings.\n\nHe said, 'We have obviously lost a lot of what my grandma had throughout her lifetime here and her house being one of them, you know it is just rough.\n\n'I understand that people say it can all be replaced, but how do you replace the memory that came with the house? Like, you can't.'\n\nAs the storm on Tuesday approached Mears and his fianc\u00e9e dashed out to their car to take shelter as they don't have a basement\n\nTheir belongings were scattered and mangled across the yard among overturned trees, dirt and debris\n\nThe family said they just felt lucky to get out alive. One of their neighbors was trapped in rubble, but Mears managed to dig him out and take him to hospital.\n\nHe had a few broken ribs but is recovering.\n\nTwisters were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nCrews are working to clean up a mobile home park that was ripped into pieces by the storm in Kalamazoo, Michigan.\n\nKalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were 'totally destroyed.' At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n'The clean-up efforts are tremendous. 'They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.'\n\n'We found homes in the roadway,' the sheriff said late Tuesday. 'We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.'\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and an adjacent community Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. It ripped an 11-mile path through Portage, Texas Township and Pavilion Township, leaving a trail of destruction. It first touched down at 5:55 p.m. Tuesday in Texas Township and moved northeast. Winds reached 135 mph and its maximum width was 300 yards.\n\nNo one was killed in the tornado, but officials said 100 families have been displaced from their homes.\n\nA Michigan State Police helicopter flew over the tornado's path, capturing aerial footage of the destruction.\n\nThe video begins in a mobile home park where many homes are damaged with siding and shingles ripped off and insulation showing. Some homes are completely obliterated, scattered to a pile of rubble. Trees behind the homes are flattened.\n\nThe tornado then moved across a main road where it knocked down more trees, many of which landed on top of homes.\n\nNext, the video shows a business district where utility vehicles are gathered. Another shot shows four homes with their roofs almost completely ripped off, then more homes covered in trees.\n\nIn inner walls of some homes can be seen as the helicopter passes above. Finally, a commercial building that lost half its roof is shown.\n\nA second reported tornado in Portage on Tuesday hasn't been confirmed yet by the National Weather Service.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8118125974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:10:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:10:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.crainsgrandrapids.com/news/food-drink/portage-breweries-receive-outpouring-of-love-after-tornado-destruction/", "title": "Portage breweries receive 'outpouring of love' after tornado destruction", "body": "Portage breweries receive 'outpouring of love' after tornado destruction\n\nAfter a tornado swept through Portage Tuesday evening, breweries are supporting and being supported by the community around them as the area starts to recover.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service in Grand Rapids, the tornado took place from 5:55 p.m. to approximately 6:15 p.m. in the Kalamazoo-Portage area, leaving a swath of destruction that has damaged dozens of homes and businesses.\n\n\"It brought us to tears today when we were finally able to get out of our neighborhood (both entrances are still blocked by downed trees and live wires), driving through our city and seeing the immense damage that the tornado left in its path,\" said Kayleigh Lohse, owner of Presidential Brewing Company, located at 8302 Portage Road.\n\nRELATED: Portage businesses scramble after tornado rips through area\n\nLohse, who owns the brewery with her husband Jake, said that one of the primary touch-downs for the tornado was less than a half-mile from her home.\n\n\"It was a scary night,\" Lohse wrote via email Wednesday.\n\nKeep up with all things West Michigan business. Sign up for our free newsletters today.\n\nPresidential Brewing lost power in the storm, one of nearly 24,000 power outages Consumers Energy reported Wednesday morning as a result of the storm in its Southwest Michigan territory.\n\nIn a bid to salvage some of its cold storage products, the brewery put out a call on Facebook for a generator, hoping to borrow one until power was restored.\n\nWithin minutes, dozens of people offered the brewery a generator to use, including an offer from fellow brewery Longship Brewing Company in nearby Lawton. Lohse said the display of care and concern was \"humbling.\"\n\n\"Amidst the fear and devastation, though, we have seen such a beautiful outpouring of love from our community,\" she said. \"Our business contacts, industry peers, staff, neighbors, and customers all reached out to make sure we were OK. We received a flood of offers to help however we needed it.\"\n\nWhile the business ultimately had to throw out its products in cold storage after the coolers went without power for too long to keep food safely, Lohse said the building, beer garden and all staff and customers who were in the building during the storm are safe.\n\n\"We know that many of our peers are not in the same place today, and we will be doing whatever we can to help them through this horrific event,\" she said. \"We're forever grateful to live and do business in a place like Portage.\"\n\nRELATED: Tornado in Portage displaces an estimated 100 households\n\nLatitude 42, a restaurant and brewery with locations in Portage and Kalamazoo, also lost power Tuesday night during dinner service at its Portage location, President Brad Bishop told Crain's Grand Rapids Business.\n\nToday, the restaurant is back online and looking to help the community.\n\nBishop said Latitude is offering free Wi-Fi, beverages and a burger bar for first responders and those displaced by the storm, from 11:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. today.\n\n\"We're hoping we can be there for the community and support them first and foremost,\" Bishop said. \"Anybody that needs help, we're here for them.\"\n\nMore from Crain's Grand Rapids Business:\n\nFormer Ottawa Beach Inn near Holland to be revived under new owners -- with a nod to the past\n\nDemolition starts for Acrisure Amphitheater", "source": {"uri": "crainsgrandrapids.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Crain's Grand Rapids Business"}, "authors": [{"uri": Even so, the homeowner considers himself lucky.\n\n\"Incredible that we sustained so little damage considering every single tree on our property came down,\" he posted on social media.\n\nThe doorbell camera caught the wind picking up. A flag waved furiously. Then, one by one, trees fall. Amazingly, the flag and pots survived.\n\nSURVIVORS OF PORTAGE TORNADO RECOUNT PANIC, FEAR DURING TWISTER THAT DEVASTATED MICHIGAN CITY\n\nAnother post read, \"50 foot trees can't handle the heat, but those potted plants sure can.\"\n\nMore comments marveled at the lack of home damage.\n\n\"You still have a roof? Who built your house?\" someone posted.\n\nThen there were the good-news-bad-news posts.\n\nGood news: \"Well...at least you have firewood for the rest of the decade.\"\n\nBad news: \"I'd be sad because have you seen tree prices recently?\"\n\nEnding with the good news: \"On the positive side, no more leaves to clean up during the fall.\"\n\nSIGNIFICANT DAMAGE REPORTED IN MICHIGAN AS SEVERE STORMS, TORNADOES SWEEP ACROSS MIDWEST, OHIO VALLEY\n\nFOX Weather asked for an interview. But the homeowner said he had no time because he was too busy cleaning up the damage.\n\nKalamazoo County officials declared a state of emergency. The tornado, followed by another one hour later and accompanied by softball-sized hail, did a lot more damage to other areas of Portage.\n\nThe local FedEx facility sustained major damage. The company reports only minor injuries to the dozens of employees sheltered inside.\n\nHOW TO WATCH FOX WEATHER\n\nAcross the county, there have been no fatalities, but about 20 people were injured. In one mobile home park, 176 homes were damaged, some destroyed.\n\nThe NWS issued the state's first-ever Tornado Emergency for Union City, less than 30 miles east of Portage.
